I've tried the lobster ravioli, the duck (err... canard), the potato dumplings, the salmon, the sea bass, and a couple of the desserts. All were either very good or great. For some extra Frenchness, they refused my sister's simple meal modification request- no, the sauce could not be had on the side. Authentique!
The best part is that it is so inexpensive. Considering how good the food is, 8 quid for a main course is a steal. That means you will have some money left over to treat your special lady to a couple drinks at that most romantic of bars just down the street- Slim Jim's Liquor Store! No way will that date not end well, eh?

1684.review:
Good decor, good food, great prices.  Had the crayfish and lobster ravioli starter and the ribeye steak (mixed vegetables).  My friend ordered two starters:  the ravioli and the calamari.  I believe the ravioli was the star here as it was served along a buttery seafood sauce that was balanced very well with the spinach in the dish.  
Tried my friend's calamari and to be candid, it wasn't the greatest (doesn't match the fantastic fried Calamari I exprienced at the Capital Grille in Philadelphia, absolutely tasty!!!).  Seasoned ok, a bit cold for my taste.
Out came my steak and it was so flavorful and tasty!!  Downside here was that it could've been more tender (ordered it medium) and it felt like it was warm, but not hot.  Next time will tell them to bring everything out as its ready so it's nice and hot!!
We didn't have desert as we were too full.  Final verdict: nice decore, good food, can't beat the prices for a nice, sit down French meal in London.  With some fine tuning this place would be amazing and I would definitely return (to try the Seabass and desert!!).

1685.review:
I gave Le Mercury 5 stars because It's great food, well cooked by nice people for an excellent price. That's got to be "as good as it gets". 
I ordered the goats cheese salad to start, the duck with garlic mash (which i can't recommend enough) for my main coarse and an espresso to end the evening.
I would recommend making a reservation if you plan on going on a Friday or Saturday night. It's an extremely busy restaurant, nevertheless they maintain a high standard of customer service (CS)

1686.review:
This is one of those cases when I wish Yelp allowed reviewers to rate with half stars. I would give this place 3.5 stars if I could. It's definitely not the most bomb-diggity French food I've ever had, but for the price and the atmosphere, I think this place is worth a try. 
I had mussels to start and the lamb for my main. The mussels were good. The lamb was a tad chewy, but pretty good. I only got it because it was recommended to me by the waiter.
My friend ordered the gnocchi, which was sub-standard. 
My other friend had the foie gras and the duck. Due to the only-child syndrome, she didn't offer to share, so I'm not sure how those tasted, though I'm assuming she enjoyed it since she licked her plate clean. 
All in all, I think this place is a good find just because affordable, decent French food is hard to come by. Just don't expect your taste buds to be blown away.

1687.review:
Oh how I love having phenomenal restaurants within walking distance from my flat. I took girlfriend here on a Friday night - luckily called ahead and made a reservation.
I actually got this establishment off of Yelp - ahh how this website never steers your in the wrong direction. 
We sat down and ordered a bottle of Rose and their fantastic mussels. It was a long drawn out dining experience, and I cannot think of anywhere else I would have rather spent two hours eating and drinking.
For our main courses I ordered their Duck breast while girlfriend ordered their braised shank steak. Both dishes were fabulously prepared to our lofty expectations.
When we were complete, another bottle of Rose came out along with their Cheesecake.
Two hours and about 2000 calories later - and we were both smiling ear to ear.
Bravo Le Mercury.

1688.review:
Overall an excellent experience. I came here on a Friday night (with a reservation) with two other people. This restaurant has some sort of "shift" system, I think, where all the diners come in at once. I arrived a little before 9:15pm (for a 9:15 pm reservation) and the place was empty; by 9:20pm it was full and buzzing. I've never seen this system before but I suppose there could be some advantages.
The restaurant itself is lovely. We sat on the first floor, where large windows look onto the street. Nicely arranged tables and decor. I would say it seemed a bit noisy at times, but I am sometimes a bit sensitive to loudness. (I loathe most night clubs.) The bathrooms in the basement are a bit lackluster, so I didn't spend much time down there.
The servers were good and attentive. We ordered a very nice bottle of merlot and to start shared mussels and poached pear with walnuts and blue cheese; all were very good. I had the roast chicken as entree and it was great, very tender and moist. I sampled my companions' dishes as well - sea bass and duck - and both were succulent to say the least. The portions did not seem like much but the richness of the foods really filled me up. We also squeezed in some dessert - creme brulee and the dark chocolate tort. Delicious they both were.
The main draw of Le Mercury, though, has to be the prices. Wine: appx. £15 for a bottle, starters £3.95 each, entrees £7.95 each, desserts £2.95 each. For London these prices really are unheard of. 
I will recommend this place to everybody, and I hope to go back soon.

1689.review:
Décor: Dark, romantic but not stuffy-uncomfortable. What's amazing is that this place has like 3-4 floors! (How come no one mentioned that???) It's amazing what they did here! The first floor, I could tell was more date-ish, but the second/third floor I was on was great because it was groups of friends (Some dates, not all) and it was just a great friendly atmosphere.
Service: Fantastic. Nothing to complain about!
Food: 
- Appetizer: Mussels in a broccoli sort of soup? It was good! Good amount and the sauce/soup it was in was delicious. I've had moules frites (in Belgium!) and this was definitely good in comparison to it.
- Pork with confit: I thought it was a bit dry. I ate all of it.. minus a bit of the pork. My friend go the lamb which she enjoyed and I thought had a good flavour to it.
- Dessert: Pear- YUM. 
Bottom Line: Decent prices, decent food. Even though I went with just a girl friend, we liked to say that it was definitely a 'romantic' dinner date, ahahha ;)

1690.review:
A starter and a main for little under £12. Splendid. Almost everyone who comes here likes it and I'm afraid I'm part of the crowd now.
An intimate and ambient restaurant which spans three floors (apparently anyway, I entered at ground level - as you may expect - and stayed there), Le Mercury does the romance without the finance.
The menu isn't particularly extensive but manages variety with main meals like steak, duck, chicken and a couple of fish dishes as well as two or three vegetarian options. I had a goats cheese thing for a starter and a pork belly thing for a main - lovely. There are many drinks choices. A place I'll definitely return to.
TTFN, Ian

1691.review: A visit to Le Mercury was inevitable as I watch this little gem fill up every night without fail. The blue and yellow interior might lead you astray however with a simple menu and excellent prices, Le Mercury is everything French and nothing less. The crayfish and lobster ravioli was minutely salty for my liking but was succulent enough to still enjoy. At £2.95 a plate, it's alright to order the entire dessert menu.. if only I could stomach everything, I would. Mascapone cheese Cake - a lighter alternative but still as rich and as enjoyable as a normal cheesecake. Love, love, LOVE!

1692.review:
Yes, yes and yes. And yes.
Friendly staff, intimate seating, outstanding food, decent prices, fantastic wine... you can't really go wrong can you? 
Sure it's not the best french food in the capital, of course it's not, but it is ridiclously good and it tastes even better when you appreciate how little you're paying for it. 
We had three courses... why the devil not?
I might just be in love with their garlic mash. I could marry it.
Omnomnomnom.

1693.review:
I went here once years ago and it was amazing (!) and then I immediately forgot about it. Why would I forget?   Probably there is a curse on the entrees like in a French fairytale that goes like, "The food here will be so great and amazing you will feel like you have found the perfect food, BUT you will forget about its amazingness shortly after digesting it". Curses!
But, this is one of my favorite spots in London- so long as I remember it exists. The entrees are delightful. I had pork belly on a bed of (not over cooked) cabbage covered in a berry sauce that my taste buds singing the opening of "The Sound of Music". Actually, I refer to this place as French-ish, because I'm not sure if it is supposed to be totally French (mainly because its such an unassuming and friendly place. Ooooh burn, France!)
The most magical thing about this restaurant are the prices.... you will do a double take when you get the bill. I heard somewhere that this place is like a training restaurant for chefs or something but I don't care.... I really don't. I just want to go there again and again. 
I think I may be in love with a restaurant....
I think it gets pretty busy on the weekends so you may want to make a reservation but it does stay open until 1 so its perfect for a late, late dinner.

1694.review:
I'm going to sound like a broken record here, but when you sit at a buzzy romantic restaurant, drink delicious wine, interact with friendly staff, eat so much French fabulousness you want to le burst, and to top things off you then receive a bill for three people that you'd expect to be for one, you can't resist that big 5. 
(Seriously: Bottle of wine, two entrees and two starters for under £30 including tax and tip. WORD.)
Le yes.

1695.review:
Le Mercury is a great find. The food is really great and the service outstanding. The restaurant is right across the road from the Almeida Theatre which makes it a great place for pre or post theatre dining.
If you tell them you have a show to see, the service is even faster.

1696.review:
WIN! this place was so cheap and STILL REALLY GOOD! i heard that it's hard to get a seat, but it was open late so we rocked up and they made a bit of a fuss but then they seated us.
The atmosphere was so French and romantic, I was a bit embarrassed to come stumbling in after an upper street drink session... but the lights were so dim I don't think anyone noticed. I still can't get over how much food we got for how cheap it was! I think I will come back when I intentionally want to bring a date...

1697.review:
Went to Le Mercury as a last minute decision with a friend. We got served straight away which was great. This also meant that we got our food very quickly ( a bit too quickly..we were in and out of the door within 40 minutes). Saying that the food was very nice. The prices are so reasonable because of the fast turn around and it is obligatory to order sides with your mains as you won't get any veg or carbs on your plate.
 All in all a nice little place to go if you don't want to spend hours on your meal or have a play/film to catch.

1698.review:
It's crazy how quickly this little restaurant fills up at night, but I'm not surprised given the prices of the food. Starters are all £3.98 and mains are £8. For starters my partner and I ordered the lobster & crayfish ravioli and the fried calamari. The lobster and crayfish ravioli was a bit overpowered by the dill stuffed inside and wasn't amazing. The fried calamari is horrendous and I can make better at home but for not even 4 pounds a pop I guess I can't complain. I ordered the duck, and it was very overcooked, but the flavors were good. The garlic mash is delicious. My boyfriend had the lamb and also said it was good but overcooked. I would probably return and ask them to cook everything a bit less than they normally would. The price is terrific and a 5 min walk from my flat, so what's not to love?
If I could I would rate it 3.5 stars

1699.review:
We made an unplanned visit to Le Mercury a few weeks back and we'll definitely be back.
I had the calamari to start and porkbelly for mains, my girl had the pear and blue cheese salad and the veg. cassoulet. We couldn't really fault the food - we really enjoyed everything we ordered. 
It's not mind-blowing - just really soild food at a great price.
It was busy and the service was efficient - we didn't book and managed to walk in and get a table, but other people after us weren't so lucky. Would definitely recommend making a booking.
If you're in the area Le Mercury is definitely worth checking out.

1700.review:
fantastic French bistro amidst the already awesome Islington Upper Street fare. Prices are VERY good considering the quality and variety of the food offered (£7 for main courses, £3 for dessert, a bit more for the daily specials). Went for a flatmate's birthday dinner with a party of about 10 or so, and the service was below average -- we literally asked for a pitcher of water FIVE times before they finally listened ... and it was at the end of a meal.
Otherwise, a perfectly good restaurant!

1701.review: I recommend this place to anyone. I've been eating here for over 20 years. It's great for a quiet lunch or a full on dinner gathering with 20 mates. Three floors, drippy candles in old wine bottles, simple, quality French food. Amazingly reasonable prices. They have always maintained a fixed price for starters (£3.95), mains(£8.95) and puds (£2.50) .It's maintained it's quirky, unique, old-school Islington vibe. I hope it never changes.

1702.review:
My guy works late, so if I am lucky during the week we can have dinner together if we can find a restaurant with a kitchen open past 10 and one that won't rush us out at 10:59.  So I was thrilled to find that Le Mercury stays open late!  Thank you!  
I love authentic French bistros serving up foie gras, chevre chaud, duck breast, entrecote steaks, etc.  And I love it when it tastes delicious.  And I love it when the bill comes to £40 for two, we ate lots, and that tab included a very nice bottle of wine!    
We had a nice secluded table in the corner by a nice round window and had an extremely pleasant meal.
It reminds me a bit of Grumbles by Victoria Station--I guess I am just a fan of authentic French bistros at an affordable price.  
Could this be my new fave in Angel?  I think so!

1703.review: The food here is pretty good even for my french friend's standards. The place is nice and bright, the prices are exceptionally cheap and the food is great. Definitely a must try if you are in the area!

1704.review:
I'd heard great things about Le Mercury and it didn't let me down. Although it's best to book, we were lucky to get a table upstairs on the spur of the moment one evening.
 My God, it's so cheap! It's a simple menu with lots of French classics to choose from, but the food is delicious.
 OK, the service isn't the best, but Le Mercury still has charm and atmosphere, and at those prices you really can't grumble.

1705.review:
Comparing this to the type of service and food I would have in the States, an incredible value. For tourists, its a bit out there (~ 21 GBP from victoria by taxi), but def. worth a visit.
I went with a few other friends from across the pond and we all loved the atmosphere (nice, but not pretentious), service, and food. None of us were French food snobs, but we all thorough enjoyed the lamb, salmon, gnocchi, and casserole (though the casserole was a bit bland and very heavy on the beans). 
The apps were great, and paired very well with our French wine.
Overall, we were pleasantly surprised with what a nice dinner like this cost us. Check their website for details. Also, I would recommend setting reservations for parties larger than 2, even on a weeknight as many people have found this gem.

1706.review: What an absolutely delightful restaurant! Went there with my Mum and sister. Beautifully prepared French food. I had the blue cheese and walnut for starter, with delicious light salad dressing. My Mum had the prawns which she found delicious. For mains I had the sea bass, the staff were so accommodating allowing me to swop one side for another of my choice. Overall food was decadent, decor was elegant, staff were superb, and atmosphere relaxing allowing us to immerse ourselves in wonderful food and conversation. Would highly recommend Le Mercury.

1707.review:
I went to Le Mercury {Deuxieme} which is less than 200 feet from Le Mercury and has exactly the same menu.
The first thing you notice about the menu are the prices, they are so reasonable! And with each course all dishes are the same price: starters £3.95, mains £8.95 and puddings £2.95, so it is perfect for a group of friends sharing or a date going dutch.
And the restaurant had a good mix of groups, friends and dates, so it appears to be suitable for every occasion.
Portions are not big, so those with big appetites might want to add some sides which are again very reasonable at £1.95.
I had the duck, in fact most of my group did, and it was delicious. The meat was so tender, and it came with a creamy garlic mash and a rich jus. I would definitely recommend.
Additionally: One of our party was 40 minutes late, and although they did keep asking us how much longer they thought she would be, they were very good about it. They refilled our (complimentary) bread while we were waiting.

1708.review:
I really enjoy Le Mercury. 
It's simple as that. The food is good and for great prices. And I just love the atmosphere. I love to come on lazy Sundays and have the roasts. On a nice day, the large windows let the street right in. But if you're coming for a romantic dinner, don't forget to make reservations and the buzz throughout the place.

1709.review:
Tucked right on the corner of Almeida Street and Upper Street, this little French Bistro is a wonderful little find. It's no fine dining establishment, but if you are looking for cheap, tasty and typically French cuisine - this is your Ronseal. (Does exactly what is says on the tin).
 Its dark enough to be intimate, but romantically lit with candles enough to see your dinner (and guest). The waiters are very efficient... some may say a little too eager to get you in, served and out, but I'm quite partial to a bit of efficiency on a cold wintery night when I'm starving. A three course meal will set you back £17. And that's the entire menu - starters, mains and desserts are all the same price.
 Toilets are fairly interesting... but clean.
 We dined on Carpaccio of Beef, Fois Gras, Sea Bass, Belly Pork, Marscapone Cheesecake and Sticky Toffee pudding. Delicious. Can't comment on the booze as we were driving, but French wine isn't really my thing anyway. Oh - driving - easy peasy. You can park on Almeida Street and the streets behind the restaurant from 6.30pm Pay and Display. Biking? Bike bay just on Napier Street - it couldn't be more convenient!
 Go on - have an indulgent Monday night out - and keep your wallet happy at the same time.

1710.review:
Brilliant prices. Brilliant prices!!
This is the place to be - because it is so very credit crunch friendly..and whats not to like about that!
It is warm and wooden and for some strange reason makes me think of a restaurant in a ski village (mostly because it has that 2 door thing going on)..it is candle lit so adds a bit of romance..so be sure to take 'your lovely' there.
I was delighted to pay £15 for 2 courses and a glass of wine - was nice nosh too

1711.review:
Plumped for Le Mercury having never before been. Pack them in (with little room to move and waiters crashing into my chair) and serve it cheap is the name of the game. Decor is lovely and service efficient so expectations were high. 
The Brie starter was adequate however the Moulles was excellent, in a delightful creamy sauce which was swiftly despatched. 
The food went downhill when we received our main courses. The meat of both the Rib Eye and the "special" of the day, not veal or pork but thick slab of beef Weinersnitchel, was inedible and akin to chewing gum. We both left most of our mains and when we commented to waiter on quality of meat we were met with a "would you like to order anything else from the menu", implying we pay for another main. We declined, polished off our wine and left.

1712.review:
Time and time again this place does not disappoint.  Just to add to everything that they do fabulously, I celebrated my 25th birthday here and was a bit obnoxious about the reservations because I started with 9 and called them almost every day for a week to up the number to 15. 
As it was a Monday night, there was no problems and we were pretty much given the entire top floor (maybe because we were also pretty happy, loud and drunk).  We all got 2 or 3 courses, the food came out promptly, had about 8 bottles of wine, a few beers and the total came out to £21/person. 
I can't stress how amazing it is to have GOOD food for such a great price, it's really a good place for large groups as it keeps things cheap but a fabulous meal!

1713.review:
This is a lovely little place, we went before going to see a movie on Upper Street. The food was delicious and reasonably priced, mains were 6.95 - you could have a side dish as well for £3.50, which we didn't have as trying to cut back but the mains were things like pork belly and greens, so obviously if you wanted some carbs with that it would be a tenner for a main..
But good service and atmosphere, and gorgeous food.

1714.review:
Cheap French food?  What?  Looking for a relatively inexpensive place to eat in Islington, I came across Le Mercury.  All of their entrees are priced at £7.45, appetizers are a mere £3.95, and the wines and other drinks are more than reasonable (around £3-4 for a glass of wine).
I opted for the crispy-skinned sea bass, which came with some really delicious potatoes and pesto.  It was all perfectly cooked and a perfect portion size for me.  My friend ordered the steak and he loved it...a rarity for him, since he's usually got something to complain about no matter where he goes!
Although we came in quite late without a reservation we were still seated immediately with a quick warning that they were closing in 45 minutes or so...though that didn't end up mattering much at all, since the service was incredibly quick.
The atmosphere is a bit romantic-y, with candles and all of that, but it wasn't filled with the kind of gooey lovey couples who might make a night out with a platonic male friend a bit awkward.
I just wish I'd tried something from the dessert menu...Oh well.  Just gives me an excuse to go back!

1715.review: Le Mercury is an amazing hidden gem in London.  The food is delicious, the atmosphere is cozy, and the prices cannot be beat.  I suggest trying the duck entree and the poached pear dessert, both of which are some of the best dishes I have ever experienced.  Every time I am in London I will be eating at Le Mercury.

1716.review: Not bad...not bad at all....and when I say not bad, I really mean, really quite amazing actually. Would be a perfect place to go this Valentines on a special date!!  The duck was lovely and as for the garlic mash it came with.....OMG...wow!!! mmmm i know what all the fuss is about now! And cheap tooooo...

1717.review: The atmosphere, the location & service was very good, the food was excellent, abit on the pricy side for the food on offer though in my opinion. The portion sizes was adequate, good place for a romantic meal for 2!!!

1718.review:
A romantic candlelit French restaurant which stands out from the crowd on Upper Street - go there with a good looking person to gaze at over candlelight and unwind with a good bottle of French wine.  The best thing about this place is the value for money compared to other restaurants in the area, a glance at the menu may leave you feeling a little nervous about the cuisine but don't be put off by the almost too modest prices. 
The food would have been excellent if it had been hotter, but this is a restaurant that's packed almost every night of the week and the highly efficient waiters are rushed off their feet to deliver food to all three floors of the restaurant (you will probably have to book - try to get a table on the ground floor).  A great place to take someone if you're on a budget - because you won't feel like you are.

1719.review: This place is seriously amazing - i'm genuinely stunned by its existence. The food is fantastic bistro fare (heavy on duck, pork belly etc), the service wonderfully welcoming, the place is always packed yet i've never failed to get a table without booking, it is astonishingly good value and it is the epitome of a candlelit romantic setting that adapts to every season and it is not far at all from Angel Tube. If I lived in North London, I would be there all the time.

1720.review: Excellent value, flavoursome French food. Candle lit for a warm ambience. Perfect for dinner with a partner, to impress without a big price tag, or a small group of friends. With most dishes priced the same its easy to split bill between a group, without any tight fists getting their knickers in a twist over who's meal was more expensive!

1721.review:
Le Mercury is a good solid restaurant with tasty food and reliable service.  When I can't get a reservation at Ottolenghi across the street, I'm not disappointed by Le Mercury as a backup.  I have them saved in my phone. 
The moules marinieres are perfect and not rubbery, the duck is always cooked to perfection, the salmon juicy, the lobster ravioli is a winner, and although I've never had it, the pork belly always seems to make my husband very satiated.  The deserts are nice, but their strengths are their starters and mains.  The wine list has a fair mix of options, most worth buying by the bottle and none too offensively priced. 
The last two times I have been there I've been seated upstairs which is more private, but I prefer the seating downstairs for a cafe/french style atmosphere.

1722.review:
Pics@Chopstix2Steaknives
chopstix2steaknives.blog…
 
Do you like to be tasked with choosing a place to eat or are you one of those who like to leave it to others?
For me, I'm happy either way. These two restaurants serving French cuisine were suggested by friends I was catching up with and that I haven't heard of. One was to celebrate a birthday and the other was visiting friends in town.
Let's start with a birthday dinner at Le Mercury. It was a cold windy evening and I was walking with a fast pace dreaming of the warmth that will greet me when I open the doors of the restaurant. In I went and was led up a flight of narrow wooden stairs to my table.
It was a very reasonably priced menu with all starters priced at £3.95
We ordered a trio of starters starting with the Calamars Fris which is deep fried calamari with home made tartar sauce and dressed French leaves on the side, Beef Carpaccio with capers and red peppers relish and finishing with the Ravioli de la Mer, a crayfish and lobster ravioli with spinach and shellfish sauce.
For mains which were all price at £6.95, there was the sea bass fillet with crushed new potatoes and minted pesto, a rib eye steak served with shallot sauce and a Scottish salmon with sautéed spinach and lobster sauce.
We all had a great time soaking in the atmosphere and vibe. It can indeed be quite a romantic place. The food may not be outstanding but is decent and with those prices, reflects a good value. An unassuming place that might not reside in your memories for long but will be thought of fondly if this happens to be part of your local eaterie.

1723.review:
OK I know I'm going against the grain here but bear with me.  I went a couple of weeks ago for the first time with Lucy who raves about it so I had high expectations. A major bonus was the fact that due to volcanic activity (what else?), mutual friend's flight was seriously delayed so we arrived about 45mins after we had the table booked for.  There was no problem with this, despite the fact that it is nearly always fully-booked so that was great. Lucy noted that the prices had gone up since the last time she'd been, so while still cheap (7.45, specials of the day around 9 or 10 pounds), not as cheap as they used to be.  My starter was great, my steak was cooked to perfection but not of the highest quality as I was still chewing it over literally 10 minutes after Lucy and friend had finished. Not a good look! The sticky toffee pudding (a passion of mine) was a little dry and not as sticky as it should have been.
I thought I'd give it another go for boyfriend's birthday meal as everyone else seems to think it's amazing so I wondered if I'd gone on an off-night. 
Not so, sadly.  The maitre d' sat us, a waiter brought over some wine (complementary wine! How thoughtful!) but it wasn't ours and turned out to be the first of many errors of the evening.  After some time, the maitre d' took our order without writing it down (why do people do this? I've been a waitress and could NEVER remember orders without writing them down - it turns out that this guy couldn't either) so when the starters came, I got the soup I'd ordered, boyfriend got something he didn't.  It was replaced quickly though and we had complementary bread and butter to keep us going which is a plus. 
My soup was a disappointment though. French onion is another passion of mine but I make it far better than what I was given - watery, thin, with little flavour.  Boyfriend's poached pear with blue cheese was lovely though. 
Some 45 minutes after we had had our starter, I asked where our main courses were and they arrived soon after. I think 45 minutes is a very long time between courses and we were filling up on bread.
Anyway, for main I had pork belly which I'd expected to be a slice of meat layered with fat and with a nice chunk of crackling on top. Again, not so. It was a huge lump of tasty pork, not a scrap of crackling to be seen and not enough jus to counteract the dryness of the meat.  I ended up drinking so much water with it (I can't leave meat, an animal has died for this so I'm not wasting any of it!) that by the end of the meal I was absolutely full to bursting. So much meat and you only get vegetables / chips etc if you order them (1.95 on top) which presented another problem. I ordered a side salad (mixed leaves, 4 slices of cucumber with only the slightest hint of dressing, 1.95 seems very steep for that) while boyfriend ordered chips and a vegetable selection which it seems the maitre d' forgot.  When we reminded him, we were shortly presented a plate of beans, new potatoes and the oddest carrots which looked like they had been boiled, then left in a low oven for many hours so that all the water had been removed from them. Wrinkled, dehydrated and burnt around the edges. Very strange and not nice to eat! 
By the end of all that, I wasn't hungry for dessert which is just as well as it took another 20 minutes to get the bill.  
Not bad in that the whole thing was 35.00 for 2 people with a glass of wine and a beer but I wonder if we're all mistaking good value for cheap?
Let me know if I'm wrong, but I'm not charmed by Le Mercury.

1724.review: Intimate, romantic, and delicious.  All the elements that define French cuisine.  Affordable is the one missing element Le Mercury adds to the formula.  I love the friendly waiters and will be back whenever I celebrate with my special one!

1725.review:
Wow! Now this is a rare find - gourmet quality for mainstream prices! I almost don't want to review this place so that people don't flood it, but I want them to continue doing their beautiful thing!
 We went here after a week in Dijon, where we were sickened by the high prices for relatively little quality. Coming back to London to find this awesome little place was such a contrast.
 We started off by only wanting main and perhaps dessert, but ended up having wine and all three courses! Every single course was amazing. I recommend this as one of my favourite places in Angel!

1726.review: I love this place with absolutely all of my heart. Although the food probably only warrants a 4-star rating, I love this place enough to rate it a 5-star. Honest, unpretentious French food at ridiculous prices, a fantastic atmosphere, and decent wine - and on Upper St.

1727.review:
Hello new favourite restaurant!
 Seriously, is there nothing this place doesn't offer? When someone suggests a French restaurant, you immediately think it's going to be pricey, but this couldn't be further from the truth. All of the mains are under £7, desserts under £3.
 So what did we have? Well we shared a starter of Crayfish and Lobster ravioli which was yummy. really nice. I think we were both a bit annoyed that we didn't order one each.
 But the mains were ace too - it's not a huge selection, but it's a good one. I had duck breast on garlic mash with cabbage. It had a great sauce, although I can't remember what was in it. The mash was really too garlicky for my taste, but the duck was perfect. Yummy yummy yummy. We didn't get a side of veg with our meals, but we did spie roasted potatoes and green beans on a nother table and were instantly jealous. My friend's mushroom rissotto was yummy too. Dessert was a mascarpone cheesecake. YUMMY!
 There was nothing bad about this place, it's a gorgeous little find. We booked ahead, and we might have been lucky but it's not a bad idea. The service isn't the best, but my friends and i were catching up so we didn't really mind that they didn't take our order for a while - in fact I think they were waiting for us to shut up! In the meantime we ate all of the bread that they gave us. Freshest bread eve. The place is open very late (1am on weekdays, 2am on weekends) so you could even pop in after going to the cinema. It's a little further up Upper Street than the main drag, but that's a good thing. If I was just looking for somewhere to grab a bite to eat, I wouldn't have walked up this far. I'm so pleased I did!
 So one starter, one dessert and two very yummy mains, plus a couple of glasses of wine costs us £26. Very impressed indeed.
 Do come here! On a date, with friends, whatever. Just come here. We were in such a mood for all things French that we've booked the Eurostar to Paris next month! Doesn't get much better

1728.review: Friendly service and delicious food.  And don't be put off if you walk in and it seems full, there are tables upstairs.  Will be back next time in the area for sure!

1729.review: I love the simplicity of the prices of this place.  All appetizers, entrees and desserts are a set price.  Whether you get the duck or beef it is the same.  It is not Michelin star but the food is really good and the price is right.  French food and candle lights, just don't screw it up by saying something dumb and it is the recipe for a really good romantic date.

1730.review: Whilest the French food here is amazing, their roasts weren't so hot. I had the beef roast and it was...meh. Not bad. Not good. Rather mediocre. If you're  coming to a french restaurant, don't eat the British food. Common sense I should have had then but now consider a learned lesson in my culinary adventures.

1731.review: Reasonable quality food, hence the price.  If the credit crunch is hitting you hard then this a good place to take that special someone without having to spend too much.  It is pretty much always busy, maybe I am being too harsh on the food quality rating but I have been to many french restaurants and have had better, because I've paid more.  The starter was the best out of the three dishes, it was the mussels in white wine (not as fresh, but they were only £3.95).  The salmon was tasty with the lobster sauce but I was let down by the food's temperature, as if it had been left on the side for a bit before serving it.  Other than that, decent candle lit place with many tables cramped in a small-ish area but you will be surprised when you realize it is actually a three storey building.

1732.review:
Le Mercury is a great cheap and chic French restaurant situated on Upper Street. The prices really are unbelievable with starters beginning at just £3.95, mains at £6.50 and deserts at £2.95.
The crab and lobster ravioli or the calamari are two of my favourite starters although it is is difficult to choose from such a wide selection
It has a romantic feel and is certainly an ideal place for a date with food that is impressive but prices that won't break the bank. From the outside the dimmed lighting and minimalistic decor gives the impression of Le Mercury being an expensive snooty restaurant but it certainly is not.
Another great thing about Le Mercury is the very fast service- an added bonus when you're feeling hungry and watch the other diners tucking into their delicious meals.

1733.review:
This French restaurant has a wonderful philosophy of quick service, excellent food and at very reasonable rates. Its no wonder that its always packed - but you don't have to wait long for a table. The steak was the best I've had in a while, soft and tender with a shallot sauce. At only 6.50 pounds, it was an absolute bargain! Starters are also very good, and around 4 pounds each. A bottle of wine is pretty reasonable at 10.50 as well. 
The restaurant gives the atmosphere of an intimate high end eatery, and the dim lighting and soft candles save it from looking like a bistro. This is a perfect place to go for a pre-theater or cinema meal, as the fast service won't keep you waiting long for a great meal. The Creme Brulee is still a simple favorite that is on the menu. Have with an espresso for the perfect meal!

1734.review:
Le Mercury is a real gem. It's not very fancy, but it has loads of atmosphere with the lighting provided by candles in wine bottles and street lights coming through the windows. Things can get packed in pretty tight, so it's best to make a booking (even on a Monday night at 8pm we wouldn't have been able to get a table if we hadn't already reserved one).
 The food is quite good, even if the menu isn't terribly extensive. My sea bass was fantastic, nice a crispy on the outside but really moist on the inside. Their desserts are really nice too, but don't expect anything on the lighter side. But the portions are perfect, just enough to leave you feeling satisfied without feeling stuffed. And things are relatively cheap with three courses costing only about £15 (excluding drinks).
 It's a really good late night spot as well; they're open til 2, and they won't rush you if you want to sit around and chat after your meal. It can get a bit noisy in there, but still a good place to bring friends.

1735.review:
Adequate French restaurant in Angel. There are many to choose from but if you want something cheap then this is ok. You do get what you pay for though.
 On the standard menu starters are £3.95, mains £6.95 and desert £2.95. There are always specials as well with prices going up to £10. Salmon was nice, steak was gross.
 Service was prompt but disinterested & I wouldn't return. I did in fact leave without leaving a tip because our waiter gave a bit of a mad serial killer impression.

1736.review: Great food and service is also good... decor a little drab these days.. still a favourite of mine though

1737.review:
I really like this restaurant. My boss put me on to it a couple of years back, and I have been numerous times since.
 The combination of good value with high quality food and a nice location / layout really make this worth going to.
 The menu is always varied and changes frequently. As I said, the great value makes it even better. You don't get massive portions, but more than enough to do the job. There is always a specials menu (no, not just the leftovers) which has some stunning dishes. Haven't had a bad dish yet!
 There are a few French restaurants in Angel, this being my second favourite. A very close second, mind

1738.review:
My favourite little restaurant in Islington. I almost want to be selfish and pretend I hate it so that it doesn't get any busier! But in the spirit of paying it forward - GO TO THE MERCURY!! 
It does get very busy so make sure you ring ahead.
Anyway, the food is unbelievably delicious, which is exacerbated by the excellent prices and good sized portions. I cannot say enough to recommend this restaurant. The candle light and the warm atmosphere all add that little extra special something.
I remember the lamb main course being particularly yummy, but the menu keeps changing and I haven't had a bad experience yet.

1739.review:
I went here with a french person and apparently it is incredibly authentic. The food was lovely (steak cooked to perfection) as was the wine. No problems with the service.
 It's in a very busy area so you will be lucky to find a seat, I definately recommend booking in advance.

1740.review: I'm just going to second what everyone else is saying.  This place is cheap, and the food is good.  I'm not expecting food cooked to level of a good Parisian bistro, but for how much you have to pay, this place is amazing.  Gets super packed though, so make reservations at least a few days in advance.

1741.review: Very unpretentious little place along Upper street. We casually popped in one evening. We had to wait a while, as the place was full and apparently, you are advised to make reservations. Considering the price level, my expecations were low, but I was positively overwhelmed. They keep a simple menu, reproduced in high volume, which is probably the recipe for success. Its not a top class French restaurant, but it is extremely good value for money.

1742.review: Reasonable priced, quick service, nice atmosphere, decent food.  Within their price range, I cannot expect anything better.  All the tables have candles, the windows are lined with plants and other decorations.  The food wasn't anything amazing but you can tell some care went into the preparation and it surpassed expectations

1743.review:
I sit down and am promptly ignored until Meg comes in. The vibe is very French bistro and a bit like Lucien in NYC which used to be our favourite place for a mildly celebratory dinner so that's good. The restaurant is crowded but unlike a crowded NYC restaurant you aren't putting your elbows in your neighbour's soup.
 Tiny paper napkins and diner-standard flatware/glasses are all that's on the table. Meg arrives, we get the menus, and order drinks. We get glasses of tap water, which are never refilled, and a bottle of chenin blanc which turns out to be a 2008 from Long Beach winery in South Africa. This is a little sweet, but very nice - I like it a lot. The bread is pretty plain-jane white bread, but it has poppy seeds on the outside which make it better than expected.
 Meg has Tian au Crabe which is described on the menu as Tian of crab and avocado emulsion. What is a tian? We don't know which seems as good a reason as any to order it. It turns out to be something like crab salad. Meg seems to enjoy it.
 I have Chevre Chaud, grilled goat's cheese with fresh leaf salad and basil pesto. This is quite good although I think rather too heavy on the goat cheese and not heavy enough on the pesto as it's a little dry. The salad is nothing special and in fact I was hoping for more leaves. Weirdly, I guess, I'm asking for them to have more of the cheap ingredients in this dish.
 For mains, Meg gets Supreme de Poulet Roti - roast breast of chicken, garlic mash, green peppercorn. She seems to like it. I have Filet de Loup de Mer - sea bass with cauliflower puree, raisins, and chili lemon zest. Everything individually is good but they don't seem to go together that well.
 And that's it. We're tired, Meg seems to be coming down with something, so we skip out after just over an hour for under 40GBP. A great deal, convenient, decent food. We'll definitely be back.

1744.review: Had passed this place a lot and never got around to calling in until one night when 6 of us decided to go for food and every where was absolutely packed out around here. With empty grumbling bellys we made it to a really busy looking La Mercury and luckily were able to get a table upstairs. We couldn't believe how cheap the food was, we got a set meal and the food was stunning. We were all well impressed and would definately head back soon.

1745.review: You really can't fault Le Mercury for what it is. All starters are the same low price. All entrees are the same low price. And yes, all desserts are same low price as well. It's incredibly cheap, yet still tasty. Probably the best value for money you can find in the area. It does get quite crowded though, so call ahead and make a reservation. And also be prepared for it to be a tad noisy on the weekends, but certainly not overwhelming.

1746.review: This is a friendly and inexpensive French eatrie perched on the corner of Upper St and Almeida street.In my opinion it has carved a good niche for itself in a market where there are hordes of over-priced and over-rated restaurants. The management has particularly laid back attitude towards customers and the food is inexpensive. Starters cost around 3.95 and main course around 6.45. A starter of gnocchi with butternut squash was light and delicious,the steak and chips was cooked just to right level and the banana shortcake with strawberries completed the meal nicely. It has pictures of Paris all over the walls and lit by candle light stuck in arty bottles.

1747.review:
The best ramen I've ever had!
The cleanest Ramen restaurant I've yet seen
The friendliest staff you can imagine
The (1 of) best finds we stumbled upon in Soho London
We both had the special tonkatzu broth with marinated ground pork. And the pork belly bun.. Both Soooo good!!
Highly recommend this place from this girl that's been to many many ramen places from the west to the east.. and some places in between.

1748.review:
There wasn't many ramen restaurants in the area when we were visiting but we gave this one a shot and it did not disappoint! The staff was friendly and the space was pretty standard. 
The ramen was super tasty and had a perfect broth. I loved how you can order the tenderness of your noodle!
Sushi apps were pretty good too!

1749.review:
Good food, terrible service.
A week ago we went to another Shoryu location (Carnaby street) and after a short wait in line we were promptly seated and served impressively quickly.
At the New Oxford location today, we arrived and were seated without a wait but then we waited over 25 minutes to have a server show up and take even our drink order. This was despite asking various servers multiple times to place an order and always being deferred. The place was almost full but not really busy so the poor service was pretty inexcusable.
After eating (tasty food), our bill had major issues twice (once it was just unrelated; the second time it had a number of extra items). Finally, a manager had to help correct the bill. We had to ask twice for the service charge to be removed.

1750.review:
Heatwave in London. Warmest summer ever and what better than a super hot face melting bowl of Ramen!  Gambate! Itadakimaaaas!
I peeked over the door noren and I see this place is packed already. I guess I wasn't the only one mad in the brain to eat hot ramen on a hot day. Anyhoo.. I held up 4 fingers and the hostess seemed to know I meant .. table for 4.  So she led me to the tiniest of tables, crammed next to 2 of the tiniest of tables, and with a quick Hai Dozo.. I was left there.  But,... but.... I cannot possible traverse the tiny space between the tables to get my seat on the inside.  I mean.. people were already eating , and their bowls of ramen was perched on their tables, and I would most def, either knock their table over... or even worst.. go past the tables sideways and put my butt right over their table.. So I gave the hostess a helpless look.. ehh...sumimasen... but she looks away.  Fine.. be like that.. so I proceed to wedge myself between table and takes seat.. So uncool. Tho my wife rolled her eyes at me.  
I needed ramen, I needed something to restore my center.  The walking and sightseeing and meal decisions while visiting London has been exhausting.  I needed ramen to get back to basic.  We got us, Dracula Ramen, Regular Tonkotsu, I think there was Spicy Miso too.  tldr;- None was spectacular. It wasn't bad.  But it lacked an identity.  The noodles was text book, the broth standard, the chashu pedestrian, the toppings bleh.  In a sea of ramen.. Shoryu ramen did not stand out one bit.  
Service was so-so.  I don't expect it at a Ramen-ya anyway.  So I was fine with bare minimum.  
I don't know if there is better Ramen in London.  This isn't bad, but I would search harder the next time for something better.

1751.review: Tasty ramen with the beautiful chew to the freshly made ramen.  Stumbled upon this place since we couldn't find the place we were looking for but, we love finding new gems.  Food was really good, broth was very tasty.  The calpico mojito was very refreshing since it was blistering hot in London.  The chicken karage bun was good but I loved the tonkotsu ramen.  I would have had another bowl of just the broth.  Love the find and will be back the next time I'm in town.

1752.review:
After a cold day walking around London, the idea of a hot bowl of noodles sounded great. There was a bit of a line to get in so that was a good sign. Turns out this is a chain. To some, that's off putting or inauthentic. But when done in a respectful way - and tasty way, who cares? When you finally get called for saying they hit a drum and yell something that's supposed to be in Japanese. Cute and sets the Japanese motif. 
I like that you are able to request noodle doneness for the ramen. In general, I found the ramen (we tried two different ones) to be a little bland but otherwise really good. It had the nice soft boiled egg (but with a slightly reddish yolk). The BBQ pork bao was pretty delicious with a substantial piece of meat. The Soho platter was a pretty posh sampler of food including sashimi, tempura, and Kara age chicken for two. They even had a near-frozen Asahi beer that really hit the spot against the fatty broth of the ramen. We skipped the cocktails but they looked really delicious.
We skipped dessert but overall, it was a pretty good meal and surprisingly inexpensive vs. expectations. Would definitely recommend this place for ramen cravings!

1753.review:
Who would have thought that there would have been such an awesome ramen place in London? Shoryu Ramen definitely surpassed my expectations.
The broth was flavorful, and the noodles cooked to perfection. Service was great for us, as we came before the rush, as they quickly took our orders and brought out the food in a timely manner. The restaurant is a bit small, but it is nice and cozy. I would try to get here before or after it gets really busy.

1754.review:
It was our last night in London....and knowing that we had a long night ahead of reluctantly packing to head back in Atlanta....Hubby and I opted to stop by here for a simple warm dinner, and romantic walk under the Christmas lights on Regent street. 
Shoryu came highly recommended by friends and yelpers. It was a cold night so a warm bowl of ramen seemed like a perfect option. We hopped in a uber and arrived with no reservations made prior. Luckily, it was not too busy despite being a Friday night. We were able to find cozy two seats at the front right corner so we could people watch (very fun on a Friday night). 
I love the detail of purse hooks under the table. 
They offer specials such as seasonal set menu, Bun Monday, and Happy Sake hour. 
Shoryu Ramen started in Nov. 2012 and recommend in the Michelin Guide since 2014 (you still see the sticker at the entrance). They specialize in Hakata Tonkotsu ramen (aka, rich-thick- white pork broth with straight ramen noodles). Ricky and I both ordered the same Shoryu tonkatsu ramen ....and the broth was amazing! You can tell it has been cooking for many hours with great quality ingredients. And do not forget about the noodles made from fresh Shoryu flour! Fresh, bouncy, and chewy. You can request different textures to your liking. The ramen comes with the traditional toppings of a soft boiled egg, pork, and veggies,and nori. All the toppings were excellent as well.....but I am a BIG soup and noodles person so those are the items that grabbed by attention the most. 
The gyoza is supposed to be really good here but unfortunately no one told me -_-. I didn't find this out till after I left the restaurant. The uber driver asked me if I got the dumplings on the ride back to the hotel. We got the takoyaki instead which was so-so. 
Another popular item is the HIrata Bun. Hubby got the wagyu beef filled bun. They names it the Shoryu bun to bring prosperity to you when you eat it :) Very cute. 
This location also has quiet an extensive alcohol selection. Def check this out. There was a reason everyone inside was drinking lol. 
Highly recommend. Great place for ramen.

1755.review: Went for early dinner,  and got four bowls of ramen. All were good. The Curry Ramen was very spicy. My son, who can handle almost anything, could not eat the whole bowl. Mine was good, too, but needed a little soy sauce to heighten the flavor. Drinks were a little high.

1756.review:
Loved this place so much my first time in London I made my group come back on my next visit. The ramen is tasty and authentic and leaves me satisfied every time.
We came in Monday which turned out to be Bun Monday (buy one get one free)! We came in around 2 pm and we're seated right away. Keep in mind the later it gets the more crowded because my first time was a 45 minute wait in the evening.

1757.review: I've never had ramen before but boy was I missing out. This place was absolutely delicious, very flavourful and surprisingly affordable. Service was amazing and you could tell the staff was really passionate about their food. Will definitely come back again

1758.review: oVery busy and famous ramen restaurant, still have to wait after 10:00 in the night.. ordered the signature ramen and soft shell crab, it was not bad, but little bit disappointed because the taste not as good as o thought

1759.review:
I had such horrible service here which is why I am only giving it 3 stars although the food was a strong 4. 
Service: Took several minutes to get our order taken. Then when we were ready to pay, there was a staff member talking to another staff member on her break at the table next to us. Completely ignored us although we tried getting her attention. Finally got the attention of our waitress (the only one serving the whole place), to ask a question about a discount we had. She gave us an explanation then walked away for another several minutes when we had to flag her down for the bill. Again, staff seated to our left acted oblivious. I don't know how they run a business here.
Food: Very tasty, full of flavour and good portion size. I enjoyed my Dracula tonkatsu ramen. It was hearty and delicious. 
Verdict: I would return to another place gladly, given this poor service doesn't extend to all their locations. Clearly they have good food, they just need to work on hiring good people.

1760.review:
There were two main reasons for dining here: it had been recommended by the Michelin guide and, if you're a fellow Street Fighter fan, then you'll understand the other reason why.
 
Along with our respective bowls of ramen (one Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu, one Dracula Tonkotsu), we also ordered a couple of the Shoryu buns.
Personally I wasn't a huge fan of the buns as they actually had quite a bit of mayo on them. They were still tasty but I would probably pass on them on any subsequent visit.
The ramen was quite good and you have the choice of how you would like your noodles prepared. The broth of the Hakata Tonkotsu was flavorful, savory, and rich. The double nitamago egg was eggsellent. The Dracula Tonkotsu is filled with tasty garlic bits and flavour but may require an after-meal mint. 
3.5 stars overall.

1761.review:
Was visiting London with my fiance, and after a long day of walking, we were craving a carb-heavy meal like ramen. We stopped by shoryu, which was decently busy on a weekday late afternoon. We were asked to wait outside for a few minutes as they were cleaning the tables. 
I got the dracula tonkotsu and my fiance ordered the tonkotsu with the more intense/ thicker broth. We both enjoyed our meal - you can order the noodles cooked to your preferred doneness (standard, firm, etc.) and the egg that came with the noodles was cooked perfectly. My soup base was a little too garlicky for my tastes, but that was my fault since the description clearly detailed that it was for garlic lovers. My fiance said this was probably one of the better ramen places he's eaten at (and we've been to plenty in Chicago and NY)
The meal was a little pricey for what it was, but we were in the heart of London so I expect part of it was due to location so can't really complain there.

1762.review: Hey man this joint got no flavor. I wish I can ask the chef for a refund. I should've stopped by tesco express to add some spices and real ingredients. Please save your money and go elsewhere.

1763.review:
Best Ramen ever!!
Curiously, when taken apart the individual ingredients are really good, but not my favorite.  I prefer thicker noodles, the perfect egg and more Kimchee.  However, it is this combination that adds to perfection.
I had the Spicy Seafood Tonkotsu.  I am delighted by these scallops that have a firm texture and full-flavor (being used to farm-raised ones).  The Ramen is not spicy and you can add chili oil and grind fresh sesame seed to taste.
My companions have the pork version that they love.  With a bit extra, you can have a Shoryu bun and a boozy cocktail with your meal.
Great if you love Ramen!

1764.review: Super rich broth...very tasty. I have actually never had someone ask me how I like my noodles cooked...that was a nice touch. I've had really good ramen and this place is up there in the ranks of the best. The service was good, attentive, friendly. Skip the frozen beer slushy...it just makes it take longer to get to your actual beer. Definitely a must taste if you're in the area and hungry or jetlagged or hung over. It's a comforting bowl of brothy meat love to cradle your heart!

1765.review:
Stopped here for lunch because I was craving a bowl of ramen. 
I ordered the Origin Tonkotsu (£10). I had my noodles cooked normally and the ramen came topped with pork belly, mushroom and green onion. That was actually perfect because I wouldn't eat the egg anyway. The noodles here are the thinner kind, not the chewy thick ones (I prefer the thicker noodles). The bowl was kind of small. Normally, when I eat ramen, I get a bigger bowl with more soup. 
The soup was good, but nothing mind-blowing, especially when they advertised their soup to be 12 hour soup.
The service was quick and efficient. I really liked how if you asked for tap water, they gave you a whole bottle, even though I was only 1 person.  
Overall, the ramen was good. I don't have a lot of experience eating ramen in London, but I do have a ton of experience eating ramen in SF and this was ok compared to the kinds I've had in SF.

1766.review:
Went to London on holiday came here, and now I'm depressed that I'm back home in Cardiff instead of being able to eat here every day.
Honestly - if I lived in London and could afford to do so, I would eat here EVERY DAY. NO. JOKE. I'm STILL thinking about those perfectly seasoned eggs. No wonder they're on the Michelin recommended list two years in a row!
~ Atmosphere:
Cute atmosphere - nothing fancy. The wall has a great description of the parts of ramen, if you're new to this amazing dish you can read up on it! Even though I'm a ramen fanatic, I still learners a bit about the ramen styles of different regions in Japan.
~ Customer Service:
Really lovely. The waitress who served us was very sweet and friendly, and our food came out at a decent time (not alarmingly quick like they do in Japan, but still at a relatively decent time). They also provide fresh garlic you can crush right into your ramen if you're a garlic fanatic like me.
~ Food:
This where the 5 stars comes from. Everything else could be literally GARBAGE and I would still give this place 5 stars. We ordered Pork Belly Buns to start off with and they were fantastic. I'll be honest - I've had better baos elsewhere so next time I come I'll probably skip on the baos and go straight to the ramen just to get a better taste value for money.
I ordered the Dracula Ramen (garlic tonkotsu ramen) and it was out of this world. You can order extra toppings so I opted for an extra seasoned egg. After I finished my first plate of eggs I wish I had no shame and order an extra plate. You're also allowed to ask for extra noodles or meat - all at a price of course but I'm definitely glad they had that option available.
Choose the firmness of your noodles and you're ready to go - the result? The most AMAZING ramen. The depth of flavour of my ramen was immense and you can definitely bet that I slurped up all the remaining broth after I was done. If you're a ramen snob and here to compare Shoryu to the other ramen powerhouses of the world, I would say that the broth is what sets this place apart. The char siu was forgettable, but the broth and eggs were UNFORGETTABLE. I'll be thinking about this ramen for years to come.
---
Do yourself a favour and get to Shoryu Ramen. Probably the best in London.

1767.review:
Service is pretty poor.
Went with a few of my colleagues and we all ordered the Ramen and some drinks.  It actually took about 15-20 minutes for us to get any type of drinks and we had to remind the waiter about our drinks.  After we had the sake and it helped a little bit more.
Ramen:
No taste, no flavor.  BLAND.  Noodles were good.  That's it.

1768.review:
Clean contemporary restaurant.  They announce each groups arrival with a beat of a mini Taiko drum.  
I ordered the Tonkotsu Ramen made with a 12 hour Pork Bone stock.  The bowl of Ramen was served with Nitamago - soft boiled egg well executed, Kikurage - wood eared fungus adding a good crunch, Nori - seaweed - adding crunch and umami flavor, generous amount of fried Shallots, a bit of spring Onions, a dollop of red ginger with a sprinkling of Sesame Seeds.
The Pork Bone Broth had the requisite umami flavor, without being too salty.  The Ramen Noodle were excellent- the Noodles were al dente and the Noodles captured the flavor of the broth well.
The best part of the bowl was the BBQ Pork, thin sliced, delicious Perhaps a more generous portion would make the experience more enjoyable
Bottom line - This is a Ramen I could eat several times a week.  It was delicious, not overly salty, has a sophisticated home made quality to it.

1769.review: This is one of the best places I've ever eaten! Too much to write, I had the soy based ramen, hard noodles. It was absolutely delicious. Go there you will love the food and atmosphere. In the heart of Carnaby Street. This place is really special.

1770.review: This was not only so flavourful but coupled with great service! The noodles were perfectly cooked and the broth was so packed with flavour. I had the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu, the signature ramen and definitely promises. This was paired well with their saki flight. The place was packed and yet we still didnt have to wait long for our orders. Our server was able to make sure we enjoyed our meal!

1771.review:
I really enjoyed the ramen here! I came here a broken & hungover person and emerged a new flower. I had the signature shoryu ganso tonkotsu and the person I was with had the kotteri hakata tonkotsu and both were really really good... just nothing *mindblowing*. We did also get the two most plain ramen bowls though. The service was also outstanding (we wanted to get in, eat, get out and they were super fast/accommodating).
Overall I will definitely return here and try their other menu items!

1772.review: Such tasty food! Was in the mood for ramen and hoped they'd have a vegetarian option. I don't always love tofu in ramen but the way they made it was superb - not too soft or bland. Also loved the broccoli inclusion. Servers were very responsive while not overbearing. Would definitely recommend it!

1773.review: Nice ramen joint in London. They offer the typical tonkatsu as well as some interesting varieties like seafood kimchi, white vegetarian and curry. I went for the double tonkatsu broth and had a side of the black sesame tofu as a starter. The tofu was inter sting and a very instagrammable dish but not a must order. Tasted like a black sesame jello as it needed a little more sauce/wetness to it. The ramen itself was very solid. Large portion and tons of noodles. Noodles are hard and perhaps the best I've ever had. The fact that you can pick your thickness is awesome to me and really gives each ramen dish it's own rather than churned out in a factory. Chasu was thick but I wouldn't necessarily call it pork belly as mine had virtually no fat. Broth was thick and meaty, but lacked spice. Even with the piri piri side sauce I was still hoping for more. The ramen did not disappoint and it's no surprise they've expanded throughout the city. Biggest complaint was that they charged for still water when all I want d was tap. An upsell like that hurts and seems very seedy. But food wise, one of the better ramens I've had.

1774.review: Inaccurate advertising. No gluten free options whatsoever. Not sure why that's posted or why this keeps coming up as the number one spot for gluten free Noodles. Will keep on looking....

1775.review: From the States and thought this place compares. Could use more salt for my taste. Had the Kottari and enjoyed. The Tempura Shrimp was good but bland. Again, needing a bit of salt.

1776.review:
Service is horrible!!! 
Yelp said they close at midnight but when we walked in at 10:45 they said they close in 15 minutes and we can only order off the ramen menu but no sides... they seated 4 other parties besides us and gave everyone else a menu but my boyfriend and I literally had to wave down a server to get a menu. 
The ramen came out fast which is good and it was delicious.
However when the check came they had the audacity to add service charge to the check without my consent. Coming from America I know to tip!! The service charge was a huge turn off not to forget to mention illegal!!!!

1777.review:
We had spent four hours at Houses of Parliament already, so by the time we were done at 2:30 pm, we were hangry. We found Shoryu Ramen via Yelp and immediately looked for the closest red double decker bus to take us there. Even though ramen is not the first thing you think of in terms of British cuisine, we were happily surprised to find the food worthy in the name of Japanese ramen. BF found it better than some of the ramen places in Los Angeles, and that's saying something! 
We ordered two bowls of the tonkotsu ramen (which includes char siu barbecue pork belly, nitamago egg, mushrooms, spring onion, sesame, ginger, and nori seaweed) and the recommended shoryu buns (2 for £7.50). We loved the ramen more than the buns and a bowl of ramen will do more than enough to keep you full. Sit by the window for people watching!

1778.review:
Very good.  After a long day of touring and a long week of pub food, Shoryu was a great relief.  Funny enough i never had ramen before coming to the UK and it made me a fan.
Service was good, it was a busy day for them and they still knocked it out of the park with us.  Next time in London i'll be back!

1779.review:
2nd time ar Shoryu but 1st time at the Regent Street branch and its still in my top 3 ramen place in London!!!!
This time I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and still an amazing broth really meatier as advertised 
Plus the happy hour on all cocktail is worth it had the new seasonal wake me up in Tokyo

1780.review: Ramen is not bad but side dishes are bad! Chicken karaage is made of white meat, very dry. Why not try red meat? Seaweed salad has a whole bunch of other things in it. Can you just serve a simple seaweed salad? And no wasabi in it please.

1781.review:
One of my favorite ramen in London.
Delicious ramen with good service
Their salad is great!
Fair priced

1782.review:
1. Service - our waiter was awesome. Funny guy, and deserves a tip! He recommended what beer to get, and gave us a little run through of what to eat as well. There, you wait to be seated, order at the table, and pay at your table.
2. Price - Prices may vary depending on what you order. But regarding on Ramen dishes only, it can be from 11 to 15 pounds. 
3. Ambiance - Awesome decoration. Looks fitting and petit.
4. Food - My wife and I both had the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu. This is their signature ramen noodle soup. We thought it was flavorful and very filling. It is prepared in Pork broth, Char Siu BBQ Pork, Nitamago Egg, Kikurage Mushrooms, Spring Onion, Sesame, Ginger, Nori Seaweed, and fried shallots. 
5. Cleanliness - Food and tables were clean, but toilet didn't flush so nicely that night I was there.

1783.review:
Got our fill of ramen. The tonkatsu was flavorful and the ramen itself firm yet springy as i like my ramen. 
Order the miso with karage chicken ramen and slurp every drop of the soup. The chicken crispy yet moist.. very yummy. 
Disappointed we didn't try the signature bun.. another trip for sure. 
Seating was fast and easy for lunch.. will be back

1784.review: Really really good ramen place in the heart of London. It apparently was nominated for a Michelin star?! I've been to ramen everywhere in the States, and I have to tell you, this was some of the best I've ever had. We ordered the karaage and spicy mentaiko appetizers as well, which were wonderful. The karaage had the perfect amount of crunch and the mentaiko was delicious without being overbearing (p.s. add some soy sauce to this if you'd like!). The ramen noodles had good texture and the broth was perfect without being too salty or heavy. I honestly ended up drinking the entire bowl. The prices are very reasonable (€8 or so for a bowl) and honestly I'm sad we don't have one in the States. A must-stop place for ramen lovers.

1785.review:
Travelling from out of the country and needed to try some local ramen. I ordered the Piri Lori Tonkotsu - extra heat, jalapeños, and a secret spicy sauce. Overall I enjoyed the meal. The broth is definitely near the top of my list for the ramen I've tried, and spiciness was a slight kick without being overbearing. The pork was average, and could have used more flavoring and tenderness in my opinion. Variety of noodle selections as well with choices of varying chewiness.
The location itself was nice, with a tendency for couples or intimate dinners, but options for mid-sized and individual stool seating as well. All the staff were very friendly.
Unfortunately they were out of the frozen Kirin when I went, but would definitely be interested in trying if I get the chance to return.

1786.review:
Ramen is one of my favourite foods to go out to eat, especially back in my hometown of Vancouver where there is certainly no shortage of ramen shops! 
Since moving to London, I've tried both Ippudo and Shoryu a few times, trying to figure out which one I liked more, and I've come to the conclusion that the broth at Shoryu is definitely tastier. The Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu is fantastic here (the broth, the noodles, and the charsiu all taste great). Sprinkle on some sesame seeds and garlic, and your bowl will taste even better! Service here has also been consistently good, even when the restaurant is busy. 
My only minor complaint is that their ramen eggs aren't as good as what I've had elsewhere (strangely they seem less flavourful?), but still not bad. Certainly not a big enough complaint to detract from the rest of the dish.
I really don't have much else to say that the other 200+ reviews here haven't already said. Shoryu is probably my favourite ramen shop in London, and I will definitely return!

1787.review:
Are you serious? Ridiculously good ramen and we've had great ramen! There's a reason this place is 3x Michelin recommended. This takes the great ramen we have had and bumps it into gourmet. Even what seemed like a boring choice, the origin tonkatsu, was surprisingly amazing, full of flavor. My 8 & 10 yo kids left nothing behind. (And they know their ramen.) I had the tan tan ramen as I always order at ramen houses and the egg is organic as evidence by the super orange yolk. The broth had depth and complexity. They use bones and you can tell. 
We were here on Monday so we got the 2for1 bun deal. The prawn buns were the real deal prawn size! The buns were large too, big enough to hold the prawns. The only complaint is that the buns took a long time to come out.

1788.review: Having lived in NYC and LA, I've had some pretty bomb-ass ramen and unfortunately this just didn't match up. I had the most popular tonkotsu ramen  with supposedly extra rich broth. However, I had to add a little more chili oil and soy sauce than I would have liked in order to make it more flavorful. It wasn't terrible but it also wasn't the best and I'm not sure that I'd return. On the positive side, the guy who brought us our water was really nice and friendly :)

1789.review:
Delicious! 
Server wasn't the most knowledgeable or confident but the ramen more than made up for it.

1790.review:
It seems like Shoryu Ramen is quite a big name in London, they got the restaurant in couple places. I hadn't heard that yet till when I was in London with my hubby. We were hungry for Asian cuisine, the Shoryu Ramen was one of the few which close to us. Since we both like Ramen, so we decided to head to this one. The restaurant was quite close to Piccadilly Circus and located right on the main street, so quite easy for us to find it. Inside the place was also really nice, It gave me a really nice feeling, the place is clean and modern but also got a Japanese culture in it. Although the restaurant wasn't big, we just like it here. 
When we were here, it was quite busy. It is always a good sign for a good restaurant. And luckily they were still managed a table for two for us, that was nice. After we sat down, we got a look of the menu, wow, lots of nice food in there, I would like to order. Well, I just wanted to try out the Ramen here first. And I forgot that outside of Germany, it is quite common that restaurant will gave free water on the table. We ordered extra drinks, well, got more options anyway. 
I really like the Ramen here, it tasted really good. But again still something was missing compared those I had tried back in Asia, I couldn't really tell what. But again it tasted still really great. I got the idea why this place was well-known here. The price was alright, quite reasonable. I did remember that will recommend to give tips 18%, that was quite a bit much, I think. There was also WIFI in the restaurant, quite convenient for people who need it.

1791.review:
One of the better ramen places I've been to in the world, I stumbled upon it accidentally while returning some keys to a friend - proof that there's a silver lining in everything.
The first thing you should know is that this place gets very busy, so you might need to wait a bit. The second thing is that the waiters are going to explain the entire menu to you if you say you've never been there before, down to every last detail. It's kind of patronizing.
I love spicy ramen and will almost always pick it over the others. Their menu lists a traditional tonkatsu, but then it also lists a Kotteri Hakata Tonkatsu ramen that has a richer and thicker sauce. There was an unnecessary amount of confusion when I asked if the spicy Piri Piri Tonkatsu was made with the traditional tonkatsu, or the Kotteri - the waitress explained to me what tonkatsu was three times in a row. So I just ordered it.
If you like spicy ramen, the Piri Piri is the way to go. The broth was smooth and silky and had just enough heat to make your forehead sweat a little, but not enough to burn your tastebuds into oblivion. The noodles were perfect, smooth and not overdone. I didn't like that they added raw jalapeno and ginger though. The ginger kind of threw off the rest of the flavor and I avoided the jalapeno because I didn't want my mouth to catch on fire.
If you're in London and have a ramen craving then this is your place. Just be prepared to wait and/or be spoken to as if you were a child.

1792.review:
Pretty good ramen - not on par with Ippudo but overall pretty good.
Space is super small (cozy) - you'll be sitting shoulder to shoulder with other customers. There wasn't a wait when I went but since the place is small - I wouldn't be surprised if there was one. 
The pork belly buns were just ok - they put way too much mayo in the buns which took away from the pork belly itself. I'd suggest omitting the mayo all together.
The cucumber dish was alright - just a small cucumber with some sesame oil and hot flakes on top - super bland. It would have been so much better with a little vinegar.
The ramen itself was good - decent portions - toppings were limited and expensive for extras. The noodles were cooked well as was the poached egg. Soup was flavorful and came with good slices of pork. 
Service was nice and friendly. There is free wifi which is always a plus!
Decent place to get your ramen fix - prices are ok for the city - about £40 for a meal for 2

1793.review: I got the special saki flight and the tonkoysu bowl. Perfect flavours. The saki flight at 12 pound was worth the price, it was basically three double shot glasses full of the best saki brand you can buy.

1794.review: We were able to get a table right away. The waitress was helpful explaining to us their menu as it was our first time there. All the food that we ordered were good. We ordered Halloumi & Avocado bun, Shoryu Chicken bun, Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen, White Natural Ramen.

1795.review: The ramen had lots of flavor and was a very big portion.  The pork buns were a little small but the pork was delicious. The scallions and red ginger give the ramen a fresh taste while adding heat. There is white pepper. A sesame seed grinder. Hot oil and  sauce to add to your ramen. They only thing that was annoying is they had a gong that was very loud and they banged it every time someone came in.

1796.review: Great ramen place. We came late on a Thursday night and the place was still busy with a nice atmosphere. We started off with a chicken bun each first -- they were great. A thick pancake with cucumber and hoisin sauce with a nice big piece of fried chicken in it. Next we both had a ramen dish, I had the recommended Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu -- which was a nice filling dish. We also had the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu, which was similar to my dish but spicy -- it was really good. If you like spicy food I'd chose this dish over the other one. A nice meal out, about £12 for a bowl of ramen. Not to bad of prices, seen though it's right down the street from Piccadilly Circus. Easy walk to and from the tube.

1797.review:
Um, no again.
This place was just as bad as Kanada-Ya but for different reasons. The tonkotsu ramen was so bad we couldn't finish it. The pork buns were smothered in sauce we couldn't finish those either.

1798.review:
Wish I could give this place a 3.5
