+ Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu was pretty tasty. Broth was thick and rich. Slightly too salty for my taste but overall well done. The noodles were fantastic and with firmness cooked to order. Pork pieces were nothing special, but the egg was better than most. Minor gripe - the ginger mixed in instead of on the side.
- Gyoza wasn't anything special and overpriced.

1799.review:
I'm only giving it 4 stars because I don't know sh*te from shinola when comes to Raman BUT this place was really good.  It was 2 for the price of 1 bun Monday when my son and I stopped in - Bun-tastic was the phase used, bonus points for that.!!!
My son ordered the Gyoza - He loved 'em.  I ordered the raman with pork as well as the pork bun with the chicken bun; all of the above was fantastic.

1800.review: I love this place!!!! Great value for money, staff is very nice, quick service and ramen are just delicious here! My fav is white natural with super hard noodles! A must try is the black sesame tofu!

1801.review: Incredible ramen!! Kids loved the gyoza (potstickers) and chicken Kaarage (like nuggets)!

1802.review: Not the biggest fan of the soup that they use but the noodles are good. Their curry dishes are pretty good and for Japanese food the price is decent. However the service at this place is pretty bad. Very slow to respond so be prepared to wait 15-20min for them to even get some drinks.

1803.review: Shoryu was a solid place to get ramen. Everything was flavorful, but it did leave a bit to be desired. The buns were great, and the sake was authentic. The soup I got was good, and I liked the spicy sauce available on the table, but something was a bit off. Although the pork belly was good, it was obvious that it was not very fresh. It was seasoned well, but it shared a similar flavor with the turkey that you'd have a few days after thanksgiving. That being said, I had a good experience here and would definitely recommend going here.

1804.review: Damn fine ramen of the creamy tonkotsu variety which would merit 4 stars but for the terrible service.  Waiters and the manager seemed to ignore our eye contact and repeated polite hand signals, so I had to get up from the table to ask for a menu.  After another several hand signals we were able to order, and received our food after yet another delay.  Unless you're desperate for ramen (no shame in that), I'd recommend avoiding it.

1805.review:
Having been spoiled silly this year with highly anticipated trips to both Ippudo (
yelp.com/biz/ippudo-ny-n…
) and Momofuku (
yelp.com/biz/momofuku-no…
) over in New York city, I was thrilled to see what the city of London had to offer in terms of pork buns and ramen. Behold: Shoryu. The verdict? Better than Momofuku Noodle Bar, but just shy of Ippudo.
Star 1: How were the service and atmosphere?
One thing I will say regarding the atmosphere is that Shoryu does an excellent job of walking the fine line between authentic and fusion. Many of the staff are clearly japanese, but the atmosphere is such that you'll be comfortable even if you're a local or a non-Japanese tourist. Seating is both varied and abundant, so you'll be good whether you're a larger party of just an individual like I was. While the ramen can take a bit of time to come out, know that's because it's made to order, and in the meantime you can dig into a pork bun, which you absolutely should. Star Granted. 
Star 2: How were the portions relative to the cost?
Prices here at Shoryu are comparable to what you'll find elsewhere, with everything inflated just a bit to adjust for currency. Ramen? Twelve pounds. A pork bun? Just shy of a fiver. Considering that these portions are sizable, these are fair prices across the board. Star Granted. 
Stars 3 and 4: How was the food?
I went with a mix of traditional and contemporary here at Shoryu, and the result was a classic pork bun and a more modern 'Peri Peri' spicy ramen. I ended up with a bit of a mixed bag, with top notch ramen and a pork bun that was good but not what I would call elite. 
First? The pork bun. Good? Again, yes, this was a good pork bun, but I was a bit surprised at the simplicity of the auxiliary ingredients. The lettuce was standard iceberg, and while the pork was good, the entire thing was drowned in a chipotle mayo of some source that cleaned out a lot of the flavor. Good, but not the best I've had (that's you Ippudo). 
Now, the ramen I will say was easily top tier. I have a pretty exceptionally high tolerance for spicy food, so when I was warned that the peri peri ramen was spicy I more or less brushed it off. Wow. A word to the wise? This is some spicy ramen, and when it came down to drinking the broth I had to stop shy of finishing off the whole thing on account of my throat burning with jalapeno seeds. Having said that, the chicken and seaweed and egg and noodles were phenomenal, and this was pretty close to being on par with the best ramen I've had over at Ippudo.  Excellent. Single Star Granted. 
Star 5: Would you eat here every day if you could?
While it's not the best ramen and pork bun combo I've ever had, for now Shoryu is the best I've found in the city, and that warrants a fourth star overall. Star Granted.

1806.review: At first I thought it's a good place to bring friends there, showing them Japanese food style, but the problem is I only ordered one set but the restaurant charged me extra one , that's 22pounds! And no one remind me there is something wrong with that!

1807.review: I'm gonna give this place a 3 unfortunately as they kept messing up our bun order (it arrived 3 times!). Also, I asked for some spicy sauce and they chargd me £1 for it. If it wasn't free (which it should be in a ramen place) then at least give a heads-up to the customer so they can decide.

1808.review:
Must try!! The service was great and the food was excellent! My new favorite ramen place in London! 
Shoutout to Georgia our waitress for being awesome! :)

1809.review: Came here via Yelp late at night 23:00 and it did not disappoint. Service was friendly and the food was great. Ordered Salt and Pepper chicken which was hot and crispy, Waygu Beef Bun and BBQ Bun and they were delicious- especially the Waygu. Also had the Curry ramen and it was tasty (not as spicy as I would like but very good anyway). The only "negative" thing was the drum - they hit it twice for every party that came in or left. But not annoying enough to not rate this tasty place a five star.

1810.review:
After watching a certain Youtuber rave about this place, I decided to go check it out. Unfortunately, the taste was not as spectacular as the way the Youtuber sold it-- or maybe we just have different taste buds. 
The spicy ramen was not that spicy. It didn't have a particular "kick" to it. It was too bland. The vegan option was interesting because the broth was made of soy. I got the original. It was good but it wasn't something that stood out to me. The meat, tho, blew me away. It just melted into my mouth when I took the first bite. 
Overall, the service was great and the food wasn't bad! It's just that I've had better in my day.

1811.review: I'm kind of disappointed at this restaurant. First, I waited 45 minutes to eat ramen at around 9pm on Saturday night. They say they are recommended by Michelin in different years but I don't seem to find them on the Michelin website. I tried the recommended Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu ramen. I'm so disappointed. The soup is not think, the meat is bland, the egg is bland. They say they marinate the pork and egg for a long time but they don't taste like that. The takoyaki is different from the ordinary ones as they are deep fried. So it's crispy outside. It's £6.9 for 5 pieces but in each one, there's only a tiny piece of octopus. The rest is just dough. It doesn't worth the price. It doesn't worth the wait.

1812.review: First time and the ramen is delicious and the service is good.  The drinks are superb.  Very happy customer!

1813.review:
The wait was long and they left us in the cold outside!
The staff gave us the wrong information about the Valentine's menu and forgot my order!
The worst was the supervisor who ignore our calls and pretended we didn't exist. Only saving grace was the ramen which was nice.
Will not recommend becoz of terrible service. The Japanese way has been totally ruined by the supervisor.

1814.review:
I love ramen on chilly nights and that's where we headed after church on a Sunday evening. We got seated fairly quickly, although by the door. We found out how odd that was after we went to washroom and found the entire back of the house empty. Oh well. 
The food was delicious, hearty and warming to the belly. I got the spicy ramen and it was a little spicier than I anticipated but yummy nonetheless. The only thing I'd say I don't like is that the portions are smaller than any other ramen restaurant I've been to and the prices are a tiny bit higher, so the value isn't quite there. Usually, I have difficulty finishing my portion but I probably could've eaten a few more bites after I was done this time. Maybe don't come if you're starving but it's a good small meal if you're not terribly famished.

1815.review:
A lovely place with a good and fast service.
It was fully booked when we we there, but we got a fast service.
We took two ramen, one of them was vegetarian. And two buns to taste with cheese was perfect and with shrimps was less tasty. But overall I'll recommend this place.

1816.review:
The best ramen I had in London so far! This place is amazing if you want to try the original ramen and feel the taste of the rich broth they made. 
I've ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and was amazing! from the broth to the pork and the noodles were just perfect. You can also choose how you want the noodles to be cooked (from standard to soft to hard). Portion was big enough, staff is nice and friendly, place is not too loud so you can enjoy a chat before and after. This place is also located in a nice spot: not far from Piccadilly circus but not in the heart oh Soho = no queue! That made our Thursday dinner perfect!
If I want to be super picky  (as I am,unfortunately) the only cons is: only one toilet for the entire restaurant!You will see people queuing  in front of it which is not great as it is close to the tables so if you are not lucky enough to be close to the bathroom you could end up with people behind you queuing for the loo. 
Apart from that, great experience and great food!Will definitely come back soon.

1817.review: I've been to Kanadaya, Bone Daddies, and other ramen places but this is my favorite! Had the thicker broth version of tonkotsu ramen, and the soup was thick and flavorful. The noodles are went perfectly with the broth ! (Which wasn't the case for some other ramen restaurants) The waiters and waitresses are also very welcoming and nice :)

1818.review:
One of the best tonkotsu ramen in town. Highly recommended! They beer range is also very good. Polite and informative staff, decent prices and nice atmosphere. 
I like the fact that this chain keeps expanding in London!

1819.review:
Michelin Guide "recommended" my ass. Six hours after eating I woke up all nauseous in the middle of the night. Proceeded to rush into the bathroom with mud butt diarrhea and then vomit. 
Aside from the bout of foodborne illness I'm currently experiencing, the food was less than mediocre at best. This was my first time here and I ordered the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu. The tonkotsu broth is nothing to write home about (incredibly bland for boasting that it takes 12 hours to cook), the chashu was flavorless, and the noodles were... well, comparatively similar to everything else that's supposedly good about their ramen. When the ramen was brought out, the broth and egg were cold but the noodles were hot. At the end, I couldn't bring myself to finish the bowl and that's rare as I normally devour ramen instantly.
Overall, 10/10 would AVOID this place like the bubonic plague.

1820.review:
I've been coming to Shoryu for years so this recent visit was extremely disappointing because I am familiar with their usual level of service and quality of food. 
When I was seated I sat there for maybe ten minutes before I had to ask someone for a menu, while other parties were sat after me and given menus right away. These same parties were also given the opportunity to order before I was. I made eye contact with several waiters, signaling that I was ready to order and they ignored me, continuing to chat to each other behind the counter. It wasn't until another ten minutes that I was given the opportunity to order. 
I ordered my usual prawn tempura shoryu bun and a piri piri tonkotsu. When the shoryu bun comes out, there is usually a wrapped wet wipe so that you can clean your hands before you pick up the bun but they didn't give me anything and I had difficulty getting anyone's attention again so I just gave up and ate the bun which tasted great, as usual. When my tonkotsu came out, the nitamago was really overdone to where there was no runny yolk quality, and about 90% of the yolk was a crumbling yellow rather than a silky orange. When I asked for another egg, the waitress asked what was wrong with it and I told her it was overdone and how it's supposed to be soft boiled (I had to explain to her what a proper nitamago looks like while I'm sitting in front of a chalkboard with the definitions of the different elements that make up a ramen, one of which is a definition of a nitamago). She came back with another egg that was still over cooked but better than the my initial egg claiming "this is the best we've got".  Other than the egg, the ramen was delicious. 
Finally, when I asked for my check they brought me the bill right away and I sat with my credit card in my hand for maybe 15 minutes before I had to again ask if I could pay. A new waitress came and asked if I wanted to pay by card, and I asked her if the 12.5% service charge could be taken off because out of all the years I've been here I've never experienced such awful service. She just sulked away and came back with an adjusted bill, not once making an attempt to ask why I felt that way or inquire as to what they could do to improve. She merely processed my transaction in complete silence and then walked away. 
I would also like to add that I was not the only one experiencing poor customer service. There was a six-top of Australian diners behind me who asked for water from at least three different waiters and also said they were ready to order, to which the waitress who processed my bill replied in a really harsh and rude tone "it's coming! I've already asked!" And another waiter turned up and told them "you're just going to have to wait!"
I usually go to the carnaby branch so maybe it's my mistake for going to a different location but I've been to this location in the past too. I don't think I will return to this branch but look forward to going to another branch soon

1821.review:
I was actually at the location at Carnaby St. and when I went to go check this place out on yelp, I didn't realize that Shoryu was a small franchise and that there were several locations around London. The place on Carnaby St was small, but cozy and pretty lively on a Sunday night. I was seated at the booth and started to chat up with the bartenders. It was my first time, so they explained that they specialize in tonkotsu ramen and went through the pretty large menu with a lot of different ramen options and side dishes. I decided on the Kimchi Seafood tonkotsu because I love spice. I was also able to customize the texture of my ramen (standard, hard, super hard) which I thought was interesting as I have never had that option given to me before. I also got gyoza (because obviously you should get that with every ramen dish) as well as a steamed pork belly bun to start. Also, if you like lychee, definitely try the pink lychee jasmine tea, you won't regret it! 
The steamed bun came on the mini wooden steamer which I thought was super cute and the pork belly was super flavourful and the bun was also very soft and delicious. The gyoza I absolutely loved!! The crispy layer on the dumping as well as the filling were SO good and not overly salty. I definitely wish I ordered more. The ramen itself was definitely good, but I found the broth to be standard and definitely not as spicy as I wished it to be. It was very mild. I loved that they were very generous on the seafood and I had a lot of it in my ramen. Great sized portion and reasonably priced! 
While it wasn't busy, I found the service to be a little slow. Overall, I was pretty happy with the place and I probably would return if I could!

1822.review:
We went to a Japanese restaurant in soho and found it shut earlier this evening. It may been closed due to the bank holiday plus gumball 3000 was on in regent street. 
We ended up walking round and found this place! I went in to ask for a table for three and was told it was bout 15 min wait, and the queue was outside, as no room inside to stand! 
They do have a heater outside so it's not too bad. 
When we got our table, they explained how the menu worked with the different styles of noodle and the bun offer where you can get 2 for 1 if you order ramen noodles.
We decided to try the buns, and ordered one pork one and a chicken one. We each had noodles and two of us ordered an extra half boiled egg each. You can have the noodles al dente, standard or soft. The original ramen dish was nice, I really liked the egg, it was soft boiled.
I had a mocktail strawberry kusu mojito which was very refreshing. 
The place is small, but looks great, the staff are nice though we found our waitress a little hard to understand and had to go back and ask her what she meant.
My friend did order more buns to take home to her husband as they were nice.

1823.review:
Wow! It was a toss up between here and Bone Daddies and we settled on this beauty. Being relatively new to Ramen I was excited to try another place and another type.
We arrived and had to wait 10 minutes for a table. Be warned: You do have to wait outside for tables so maybe not the best option if freezing or raining but we were happy to wait as it was a mild night and it smelt so god damn good!
We were seated on a long bench by the wall, at first we were a bit disappointed not to have a proper table but in the end we quite enjoyed it.
We ordered the gyoza and pork and prawn buns to share. Then I ordered the curry ramen in the others section.
The sides came first which I was glad about being staring. The gyoza was freshly cooked and mouth-wateringly good. The pieces of meat inside were chunky and they just went down a treat!
Now, to the buns, it was the first time I'd ever had a 'bun' and I absolutely LOVED them. Whatever that weird type foldy bread is, it's amazing and the toppings were superb. I particularly liked the belly pork! NOW.
Next, the ramen. Gosh it was good - garlic, curried soupy goodness with bites sized pieces of friend chicken breast, veg, seaweed and egg floating within. Just perfection. The curry had an almost katsu taste to it which I enjoyed and with the extra clove of garlic, I was in a ramen dream. It was slightly salty but I am a fan of salt so no complaints here! 
Service was fantastic and the overall ambience of the restaurant is relaxed and warming. We left full, satisfied and saying we'd definitely be back again.
Happy Saturday!

1824.review:
Typical Tonkotsu place.  Nothing special, frankly, it's really over-hyped.  Ramen could have been out of preserved or dried packages, Kimchi was not especially tasty (probably made more palatable for unsophisticated western's taste) and the shrimps on the seafood's Tonkotsu seemed straight out of the refrigerator, they were cold inside the warm soup which was an unpleasant contrast.
I finished ordering a Macha ice cream which didn't certainly taste artisanal.
If you want to get real Japanese ramen in Europe I'll suggest trying in Düsseldorf.

1825.review:
Pretty disappointed by this place. It looks very sexy with decor etc, but service was really poor - and I was there for dinner at 5.30pm before a show.  I finally got a menu and realised there wasn't much veggie choice (which I guess is to be expected, so that's not a biggie) but I opted for a pancake which sounded intriguing. 
Well, we waited 40 mins for food, and only after enquiring were brought an undercooked and frankly bizarrely chewy dish, minus the advertised salad. I would normally have sent something like this back, but by this point we were in a rush and there seemed to be no point, so I just graciously ate, then tried and failed to pay using Apple Pay. I think this is just not for me, and won't return,,,

1826.review:
This place is nice and comfortable inside. We only waited about 15 minutes to be seated.
I ordered the pork belly bun and the spicy tonkatsu ramen. The pork belly bun had a great flavor profile that was different from most that I have had. It had a sweet, smoky, and light spice to it.
My ramen was quite good except for the pickled ginger. I was not a fan. I ordered my ramen standard, but will opt for the firmer option for chewy purposes.
If you are in the mood for ramen then you can't go wrong here.

1827.review: This was my first authentic ramen experience. Beside top ramen and the local noodle bar, I had a very limited taste palette. As soon as you walk in you get this awesome sense of surrounding. The space is beautifully decorated. Very chic. We sat by the front to get a view of the street and the life outside. Our started was some pot stickers. They came out still sizzling. Very crispy and full. Great way to start. For my main I got the Origin Tonkostu. And wow. Ike nothing I ever tasted. And it was huge! There was no way I could finish it.....but I tried! By the time we left, our bellies were full and swishing. Extremely satisfied with our meals. If you like unique and authentic ramen, this is your place.

1828.review: Just what I needed when touring the Trafalgar Square area. I enjoyed their signature ramen (pork, egg, mushrooms over noodles) and others had the sashimi which was fresh and filling. Excellent service too. Would definitely recommend.

1829.review:
We were around Regent/Piccadilly Circus after watching a musical in this area so we stopped by this place to eat Ramen. Their selection of dishes on their menu is wide, so you will find something you like. If you are not familiar with Japanese food, they also have a glossary on their menu in case you have trouble with finding out what you want and need a closer explanation. 
We ordered a Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu, their signature dish with extra meat, and also some fried gyoza. We finished our ramen and also our beer, and waited long for the gyoza. So we had to ask, and it seems they had forgotten about this order. They apologized and made the food right away when we pointed that out, so it was not the end of the world. But normally the gyoza should have come before the ramen as gyoza is considered more as an appertizer. 
So in short this a good place to eat Ramen with good service, but it is not the best Ramen place around this area as they have a lot of competition here.

1830.review:
We got there by sunday lunchtime on a cold day and there was already a couple of people queueing. it didn't take too long though (luckily it wasn't raining) and we were shown to our table. the place is rather small and these were two tables joined together, with table 2 already occupied. i don't know why they couldn't have separated the tables before we took our seats but that's fine, we did it ourselves.
I had a steamed pork bun as a started and the price was quite steep for what is essentially a mini sandwich. The meat was somewhat flavoursome, but a bit dry and sat awkwardly inside the bun, trying to escape as I bit into it. I don't know, presentation wasn't great and I felt there was little value for money. 
I had the traditional ramen with two lovely half eggs and bits of pork that were ok, but not mind blowingly good as the ones I had in Tokyo. The broth was substantial and nicely flavoured, but I must be honest and said I've had better here in London. The price is honest for what you get, though, and I've heard you can get a second portion of noodles free if you still have lots of broth left. For drinks I've ordered a frozen kirin but it came mildy warm and without the foam cap it was supposed to have. I was disappointed to say the least.
Overall the food ain't bad, it's just not awesome enough to make me queue or even go for another visit. And I believe you could have better elsewhere.

1831.review:
GLUTEN FREE RAMEN!!! And also gluten free sides including chicken karaage (Japanese fried chicken) and steamed buns! 
I didn't go full GF as I got the Shoryu ganso tonkotsu but with rice noodles instead of egg noodles. For full GF you have the choice of two soy milk and white miso ramen. My ramen was so deeeelicious and the egg was just perfect. Really good pork too. All in all amazing. 
My husband had the Dracula ramen...woah, he stunk so bad afterwards and we were going to the theatre, hahaha! And yep, it was even worse the morning after. Prepare yourself for the most garlicy dish ever. It was delicious though. 
We also had the traditional Japanese chicken wings on ice for starter, just because it sounded cool. The wings were nice though I'm not sure why they are served on ice...
My husband also got the winter sake flight, 3 types of sake (35ml each I think) for £6.50 with an explanation of what each one was. A great idea to educate people about sake!
There were so many other interesting things here, the sides, the drinks. What a great meal! Will definitely be coming back...is tomorrow too soon?!

1832.review: Perfect, no-nonsense ramen. The soup is not insanely thick like some other competitors'. I like it. Also, their octopus appetizer is fantastic.

1833.review: A nice broth, good taste to the pork, fun staff who rings a gong and meets you with a happy greeting upon entering, and a delicious matcha latte.  I honestly prefer Kanada-Ya, but I may go back here to give it another try (and this time, I will specify my noodle preference because they were much too soft for my taste).

1834.review: Was starving and indecisive so when I turned the corner and saw a large line of people waiting outside of Shoryu, I knew it must be 1.) a new favorite yelp spot or 2.) super good...either way that made up my mind and I joined the line. I ordered their classic Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and it was just delicious. Aghh buttery and rich and flavorful....aghh im salivating thinking of it all over again. It was about 11 GBP (around $16 USD) for a bowl which is a little more expensive then the $12 bowls I am used to in DC (I guess both are kind of expensive for a bowl of soup when you think about it), then again this is London and everything is expensive here. ANYWAY back to the food. It was delicious and I would definitely give it my recommendation!

1835.review:
I don't live in London. I was only visiting for a week. Stumbled upon this little gem. Loved it so much that I haaaad to dine here twice. No shame. Had the pleasure of trying their Tantan, Spicy Miso, Piri piri and Curry. Piri piri was my favorite, but it's definitely spicy. Prepare yourselves! The jalapenos give it an extra kick! Tan Tan would be my second fave. The boiled egg is perfectly made every time too! 
Deco is trendy and modern. Service is hospitable and quick. Lucky for us, when we went both times, there wasn't really a wait. Shoryu is right next to Piccadilly, so perfect for a stroll before or after you wine and dine!

1836.review:
London's best ramen restaurant. I like their food. 
But I don't understand why they make people queue even if they have enough tables. That's unfair. That's why I can't give them 5stars.

1837.review:
Small ramen shop in Piccadilly. We were lucky to have a short wait since they don't take reservations.
Attentive and polite staff await you in this busy restaurant. I had the kotteri ramen, which was well prepared, flavourful and rich. I decided to go with the extra hard noodles and they were a good choice! The shoyu pork bun did underwhelm a bit; the strength of the sauce and mayo (?) didn't allow you to enjoy the pork. Not worth it in my opinion, but the ramen is worth going back for!

1838.review:
The Shiitake & Konbu Gluten Free Soy Broth, Tofu, Kikurage, Seasoned Beansprouts, Sweet Corn, Spring Onion, Sesame, Spinach And Menma Bamboo was some of the best ramen I have ever had. Bursting with so much flavor. It was perfection. I am vegetarian and it is hard and quite rare to encounter ramen that is this yummy. I highly recommend this ramen spot for anyone looking for some quality food with a nice fun atmosphere. 
For dessert I had the green tea cheesecake and the texture and flavor was on point. If I had more room in my stomach, I would have also got the yuzu cheesecake. That will have to be for my next visit to London. 
Amazing food with quality, friendly inviting staff, fun atmosphere

1839.review: Great broth, noodles, and overall excellent variation on this Japanese dish. Loved the piri piri and fresh jalapeños for heat. Definitely would come again.

1840.review:
I just tried Ippudo in NYC few days ago where Hirata Buns and Ramen are PERFECT. So basically when you come to Shoryu Ramen in London, the deception is normal.
The Waguy Beef Hirata is BAD, very fatty, the bun doesn't hold and it is drenched in mayonnaise !! (£7.5)
The fried chichen Ramen, is a large portion with several big pieces of Fried chicken (bland) that lost their crispness because of the broth.
The broth is flavourful but nothing compared to Ippudo.
The 1 star is for the location.
The minus 4 stars are basically more for the lack of service i got from the staff.  They are not motivated and not welcoming. I really was about to leave cause i felt i disturbed them. They were several empty seats/table but they offered the one very mext to the main door (bear in mind it is freezing outside and the clients are entering and flgoing out from this door)
When i insisted to get the seat inside that i knew was free they told me no. I was abot to give up but eventually they gave me that seat after mumbling about me.
That is how my experience started at shoryu and believe me l, i was still expecting the food to be good despite the attitude of some staff.
It is very expensive for nothing and no need to say that i won't recommend it.

1841.review:
I bloody love Shoryu! I haven't eaten a lot of ramen but from what I know this is really good stuff! The portions are huge and for the price totally worth it! I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu and it was amazing! Delicious thick broth, succulent pork and perfect soft boiled eggs.
Sure this ramen thing is a bit of a London fad at the moment but who cares?! It tastes great and it fills the hole!
Oh, and they also do FROZEN BEER!!

1842.review:
Believe the hype. It's REAL. 
Just a few steps from touristy Piccadilly Circus, this gem is legit. Complex flavor, amazing service, solid recommendations. 
Do yourself a favor and make it here. It'll be worth every slurp of your soup.

1843.review:
I was walking and on my way to a different restaurant when I passed by this place. The place had this warm and inviting vibe to it. Or maybe it was the rain that made me want to just grab a bowl of ramen.  So I decided to forgo the steak I was about to go enjoy and walked into this place. The staff was friendly and attentive and seated me right away.  Took a look at the menu and decided on the Kimchi seafood ramen along with the pork and prawn tempura buns along with a sake flight.
Long story short everything was amazing. The buns were perfect and amazing. I wanted more but I had a whole bowl of ramen I needed to eat. So I start the ramen and the broth is just die to for. Perfect amount of heat along with perfectly cooked seafood. The noodles were not overcooked and had the right amount of chewiness. So good that I am promising myself that I will go back on every trip I make to London.

1844.review:
A-OK..... that sums it up.
I had the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu for 11.90gbp/18usd, 3pc gyoza for 4gbp/6usd, and a drink.
My bowl was small, so small I finished it even though my mouth was on fire because it was SPICY.  I'm not complaining about its spiciness, but its size...
gyoza. ehh.
US$33.75 for eating alone and leaving a little hungry... no thanks

1845.review: Amazing ramen noodles I ever have, tried Piri Piri tonkotsu was delicious and their buns are just so good. Definitely would come back and recommend it to everyone

1846.review: Having my fair share of tasty ramen from California, this place is solid. Broth is very authentic and flavorful, noodles are perfect. If you are in the area and in the mood for some ramen, this is the place to go. Keep up and improve further and some day you'll earn that Michelin Star.

1847.review:
I've been to many ramen places in southern California, which is crawling with Asian food places including ramen. While studying abroad I was really missing a dose of Asian food and had heard such good things and was so impressed with Shoryu! I think it's the best ramen I've had yet. Now that I'm back in the States, I find myself craving Shoryu all the time. 
I've had the original once in Carnaby, the signature ramen twice and the Dracula once on Regent St. All were so good! The broth is amazing and the egg. Ugh, the egg. Perfect. Just how it should be done! 
Having gone a few times, I found it not filling enough, so I recommend rationing your broth so you can get extra noodles if you're still hungry!
The plum wine is also great. A really nice complement to the savoury noodles. I didn't liked Asian steamed buns growing up but the pork belly hirata buns changed my mind. So good!
Next time I'm in London, definitely making a stop at one of my favorite trendy restaurants!!

1848.review: Really fast service and delicious sashimi. My family enjoyed their ramen as well! It was a cool atmosphere with different kinds of seasonings available at your table for customization.

1849.review:
What can I say, it's good ramen. Is it the best though? I personally think I've had better...
Shoryru seems to be popping up everywhere and I've had the chance to try both their sit down and takeaway.
It, just like all the others, is first come first served and you need to get there on time if you want to get a place to eat.
As I do, I ordered the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu ramen, and make no mistake, these noodles are good, the broth flavourful and fatty as it should be. You won't be disappointed going here that's for sure.
For me though, the price is a little high and the noodles just missing a little something something to make it my favourite. I'm a big advocate for making the effort to getting something good and going the distance. In this case, I think I'm going to walk a little further and get something just a bit better...

1850.review: Horrible wait and low table turn despite the supposed fast appeal. Indecipherable menu. Slow labor all around.

1851.review: I came back in two years and it hasn't changed much. Food was good. Prawn tempura was perfectly cooked and ramen had good flavors. I would give it a solid 4 stars but the service. There were too many of them but not well coordinated. They seemed to trip over each other.

1852.review: I am writing the review for the first time for those who consider to visit here... The guy who served us very unkind... i would never come here again...we asked some questions and he seemed to be annoyed by our questions and gave scornful look..

1853.review: All in all the experience was alright. Had heard good things about this chain, so had high expectations for an authentic banging ramen. Was pleasant, though they forgot about our sides.... Also didn't see one Japanese staff.... Was a little odd but I guess they pulled it off ok. In summary, it was ok. The space was pleasant, the service was ok... Erm... Prob a little like an upper end fast food joint though? I dunno.. Maybe I'm too picky? I'll still rate it a 3.5 out of 5.

1854.review:
Delicious ramen!!! And, the Chef (Aris), as well as all the staff, were really nice and friendly.
Ordered a bottle of sake to share for two, and did not expect such a large bottle! Definitely worthwhile :)

1855.review: Delicious, delicious ramen and buns. I got the Ganso Tonkotsu, their signature dish and Shoryu and Chicken Karage Buns. Shoryu buns because it had a lot of great reviews and Chicken Karage because they were having a BOGO special and that was what my waiter recommended. For a Michelin recommended restaurant, they surprising didn't have great presentation or at least presentation that matches their website. The ramen itself is constructed with quality ingredients. I think they use mayo as part of the sauce base which I half enjoyed, because mayo + special sauce is usually going to be pretty good, but also didn't care for since it's mayo...

1856.review: My go-to ramen place. Great service, great food, all in fantastic locations, what's not to love.

1857.review:
Stopped at Shoryu Ramen for a late after show snack. It was a great choice. Had their signature dish Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which is ramen noodles served in a thick rich pork broth and garnished with deep fried shallot, pickled ginger, soft boiled egg, julienned mushroom, and seaweed paper.  We also tried gyoza, salmon sashimi, and tempura tiger prawns. The service was friendly and prompt and the atmosphere is very comfortable. 
Our server suggested two cold sake options that were excellent and provided a new experience for myself. The first was Tarusake which had a black pepper finish but still subtle and flavorful.  The second selection was Nigori cloudy sake which was creamy with real texture.

1858.review:
Shoryu Ramen honestly exceeded my expectations. Whoever said that food at London sucks should go check this place out.
I ordered the pira pira ramen and my friend ordered the kimchi seafood ramen. The broth for both ramen tasted similiar: both spicy, thick and DELICIOUS. The egg was perfectly cooked and the pork was soft and tender. I've tried many japanese ramen places in southern california, shanghai, and seoul, and this place was hands down one of the best.
The price was pretty expensive for a bowl of ramen, around 12 pounds. However, in my opinion, the ramen was worth the price and i would definitely come back again.

1859.review: Great atmosphere and menu, and fantastic service. A positive, cool vibe.  Food was excellent. The Curry Ramen was delicious accompanied with a side of kimchi. Perfect lunch.

1860.review: I thought we had happened upon this place by happenstance but it turns out it was part of my wife's masterful plan (she had researched Shoryu Ramen before we got to London). The ramen we both had was some of the richest, most flavorful and aromatic ramen broth we'd ever had. What really got me was the texture of the noodles. They were firm and had a hearty and pleasant chewiness to them. They held up to the powerful broth and abundance of stellar ingredients. It all paired wonderfully with a cold Sapporo.

1861.review: Don't let Eve serve you!! She was rude: not only did she take the order of the couple next to me AFTER she had just seated me first, when I asked her why I had to wait, her response was that I hadn't waved my hand in the air to get her attention. Apparently everyone else in the restaurant could sit respectively, but I was expected to look like an idiot and wave my arms around. Right... Who says that to a customer?!?! She put up a little argument about taking off the service fee also. As if arguing with a customer is common practice. RUDE AND UNPROFESSIONAL.

1862.review:
Oh ramen, truly some of the ultimate comfort food. I feel as though I was a little too spoiled with my first ramen restaurant experience because I went to one of the top spots in Los Angeles and it was truly incredible. I haven't been able to get the same quality of ramen since but that isn't to say I've been dissatisfied. 
For a chain, Shoryu is quite good and I went twice during my week in London because I love ramen that much. The ramen is definitely better than some that Ive had before which is a good thing. I tried multiple types and they all had unique tastes to them that made them worthwhile. 
Some appetizers were tried as well and they had varying degrees of success. The pork belly buns are good but certainly there are better. The brussel spout tempura...uhhhhh not good. Like wow those were pretty bad.
The restaurant is also quite small, surprise surprise for a London restaurant and the tables are scrunched together like you can't believe. Surely that made things a little uncomfortable but not until a group of stereotypical 16 year old asian girls with jansport backpacks as if they came straight from a Japanese anime sat right next to us. But until I can afford to rent out every restaurant I go to for the night I will have to cope with my middle class problems.

1863.review:
Really liked this place. This was the first ramen place to I have been in London and it didn't disappoint! I was here with a girlfriend on a Friday evening and while they don't take reservations - we came here around 7:30pm and waited for under 5 mins. 
The ambience is casual and the service was a bit slow, but the food was delicious. To start we ordered the edamame which was salted and lightly dusted with pepper. And for main course, I ordered the "white natural" with gluten free noodles which is served in a soy milk/mushroom  soup with mushrooms and fried tofu among other things. My ramen was quite delicious especially given that it was vegan and gluten free (a rare find!). My friend ordered the original tonkotsu which is a simple dish with pork belly, mushrooms and spring onions in a pork broth. Of course you can always add extra toppings if your heart desires. 
Both of us enjoyed our food and I will definitely return to try their buns which they can substitute with gluten free buns!
PS: The ramen portion sizes are quite adequate. While this time, I didn't try the desserts - they do offer some cool green tea flavoured desserts.

1864.review:
I think this was better then Bone Daddies in the soup to noodle ratio.
I dug. The house classic tonkotsu was pretty damn good.
Nice service. 
Would bring friends back here agin.

1865.review:
I recently visited a little gem I frequent on Regent Street, London named Shoryu Ramen. Since its opening in November 2012 they have been offering their Hakata Tonkotsu ramen, a recipe which was specially designed by executive chef, Kanji Furukawa. 
Shoryu translates to mean 'to bring good fortune'.
I find Shoryu to be an understated, modest establishment, however its popularity speaks for itself. You cannot reserve a table ahead of time and frequently I spot a line that reaches way outside into the busy streets of Soho. A ringing endorsement in itself and an indication of quality before you even enter the front door!
Their menu is refreshingly simple - as their name suggests, they mainly offer steaming bowls of ramen, amongst other small plates and of course, steamed buns!
I HAD to try their steamed buns as this delicious creation is one of my latest favourites. For those yet to discover these beauties, a steamed bun - as the name suggests, consists of a variety of fillings, encased in a pillowy, fluffy steamed-dough bun
I opted to try two different variations, the Char Sui barbecue pork belly (left) and the soy marinated chicken Karaage (right). Now I'm never short of an opinion, but I REFUSE to pick a favourite, they are both unbelievably spot-on. The pork belly was packed with flavour and smothered in charred-sweet sauce, which married well with the crunch of the salad and the softness of the bun, whilst the contrast of the crispiness of the chicken against the cloud-soft bun was to die for!
You just simply have to try these, plus they offer more variations on their menu, namely; their ginger salmon Tatsutage, their tiger prawn Tempura, and their vegetarian-friendly, grilled Halloumi & Shimeji mushrooms.
Quite honestly, after those two delicious helpings of steamed buns - I really couldn't imagine tackling their rich, generous serving of Ramen - I had to give myself a break! 
But I finally opted for their Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu - their signature 12-hour ramen, but with a richer, meatier broth. 
I loved this dish, it has variety, balance and is the exact antidote to a hectic day, rushing around London. This steaming bowl of warmth allows you to take a much-needed pause.
Ok, I will admit that I had to take half of this serving home to enjoy, however I'd argue that after the flavours were able to muddle for even longer it made for an even more delicious serving. Don't be ashamed to take your ramen on the tube home!
Shoryu Ramen isn't the least expensive establishment you can visit, but its comforting simplicity, packed with flavour keeps me coming back. A would definitely recommend this to anyone who is an Asian-food lover. Or to anyone who has yet to try their first bowl of Ramen or steamed-bun - this is a great place to start!
...And a tip to any Ramen-lover on a budget - you can take a ramen, steamed-bun and a drink to go for just £12 with their go PACKAGE. 
I've only ever visited their Regent St. location, but why not visit their other restaurants located in Soho, Carnaby and Liverpool Street? Does anyone have a preference? Let me know!
Happy Slurping!
See the original blog here: 
laurajreeves.com/2015/05…

1866.review:
Chose to eat an early dinner at Shoryu as it was a short walk from my hotel. 
Their menu seems extensive given the number of pages. 
I chose to start with a Pork Char Siu Bun to start. The Pork Char Siu came in a fluffy bun with sliced cucumber, lettuce and mayo. I liked it, but wish it had a couple of slices of pork. 
They have several versions of Tonkotsu Ramen. I chose the Piri Piri which is their spicy version. All the ramen come with the sliced pork, half a soft boiled egg, mushrooms, seaweed, roasted garlic and thin noodle egg ramen. The broth was rich and thick, but to my surprise not very spicy at all. I kind of wanted more heat, so a little disappointed. I didn't see the red pepper anywhere either. But they do have the fresh garlic in a bucket with the crusher, if you choose to want to squeeze some into your ramen, which I did. I did like their noodles as it was thin and chewy. 
The service was good. And they leave a whole bottle of tap water for you which I thought was convenient. 
For my ramen and pork bun, it was £18.45 which included what they called a "12.5 optional service charge". That's strange to me as its already in the total.  Does that mean that I could have left £16.40 and they would have been ok with it?

1867.review: This is the place to have a authentic Japanese ramen! The menu variety is not that big. Service is quite fast. Bathroom was dirty - I would expect a cleaner environment for these prices. Thank you for delicious ramen!

1868.review:
Oooh shoryu ramen is another good place to stop for a bowl of noodles, although like Vicky, I liked it, but didn't LOVE it. Maybe all the other new-ish (excellent) ramen places have made it harder to impress me in London?
I was really impressed by the variety of soups here! The menu was massive and it seemed like you can order almost all kinds of noodle-joy. I tried the Sapporo Miso, and my other half tried the wasabi tonkotsu. They were both pretty good...so I'll have to come back and try some other flavours to see if I can bump this place up to 5 stars.

1869.review:
I would eat here every day!
Excellent service, excellent food.
Set menu or a la cart. Really nice place, crowded location, but good service and a manager who cares enough to stop and talk with you and ensure all is well.
Good prices and fast. 
Atmosphere is acceptable, although nothing special.
Go for the food (i.e., Ramen, buns, etc.), it's really tasty.

1870.review:
I don't eat pork and presume their tonkatsu is their signature ramen, but their wafu chicken ramen isn't great.  The stock is ok, albeit a bit unappetizing in hue, and the chicken karaage is passable at best.  Kaarage is meant to be marinated, typically chicken thigh and coated in a thin dusting of potato starch or flour; theirs is chicken breast and in a tempura type batter which does not suit being submerged in soup whatsoever.  
Overall a dish not worth spending money on - if they're going to offer a chicken ramen they should at least make a chicken bone broth like Bone Daddies; regurgitating the vegetarian soup and adding chicken seems like a cop-out.

1871.review:
Wow, I love their ramen!  "Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu Ramen" was super delicious and authentic!!  I chose "katame (hard)" for noodles, and it was just right.  Karashi Takana (mustard greens) as an extra topping was also very good but potion was huge! 
I would NOT RECOMMEND "gyoza".  It was totally not gyoza.
I went there around 4 pm on a Wednesday. They don't close after lunch hours, which was very helpful for a tourist like me who eat lunch when it's convenient for sightseeing.

1872.review:
Other Yelpers are right, the egg is pretty amazing. Rare but not too rare, just perfect. 
I liked the broth, and even though it's kind of odd to have bean sprouts as a topping, it was a nice addition for me (haven't been eating my veggies since I came to London... or wait since I moved out of my parent's house). The noodle is a bit hard, but still pretty good. Green tea was served with a cute little tea pot, nice containers can always make things taste better ;).
Didn't like the mini salad too much. It's a bit too salty, I wish I got gyoza as a side instead. 
What I love the most about this place is that it's not awkward to eat alone at all. I sat  on a communal table and there were 5 or 6 people eating by themselves (most are Japanese). It makes my aloneness doesn't seem as sad.  The staff were friendly and efficient, even though none of them are Japanese they tried to greet everyone with Japanese. 
Besides food and service, the location is great (super close to Piccadily circus) , and the decor is minimal/clean, just the way I like it.  For someone who isn't a ramen geek, I totally enjoyed the experience.

1873.review: Went there at 10pm for a quick feed up. Taste almost the same as the ramen I had in US. Nothing special except being a bit too oily for me though but still not bad.

1874.review:
Love how they offer gluten free ramen! But overall, their signature ramen I ordered definately does not beat popular ones back home in SoCal. The broth was very bland, pork tasted a few days old, the boiled eggs were delish! We also ordered the chicken steamed buns and that is a must! Chicken was crispy, sauce was sweet, bun was very soft, veggies stuffed inside were fresh and crisp. So tasty!
Waitresses were very attentive and sweet.

1875.review:
Fantastic food in a great space. The place is a great value - easily 5 stars. 
I had the pork ramen and a prawn steam bun. Both were perfectly prepared and presented beautifully. The price was fantastic as well - my fiancé and I were out for less than £30 for the 2 of us - including service.

1876.review:
Went recently for a very quick lunch. I loved the starters which were served promptly but I came here for the main event of ramen. It was cold and I needed arming up.
Compared to say Bone Daddies or Kanada-Ya all not far from here, I was quite disappointed. Did I come on an off day? I got the original Ramen Tonkotsu, which I didn't think had any depth of flavour. Pork belly also far too fatty for my liking.
I'm willing to come back one day but it did put me off considering I could easily compare it to it's rivals in Soho.

1877.review:
Japanese remen ( noodle ) great located , staffs really warm welcome! And noolde is so great! But sushi is soso ( dragon roll ) 
But overall its really great restaurant

1878.review:
This is the best ramen I've had in London and the best I've had in NYC as well. 
Its potentially true that the bao is not 100% perfect. I want to say maybe 98%? Some times there is a tiny bit more bun than filling and they can put a .5 gram of too much mayo on it - that's all I'll concede.
Add to that its reasonably priced and the service is fantastic and I will come back here again and again. The only downside is that the quality is quite good so one can then eat a lot - one time I both ate a lot and took down some beer. Its hard to go back to work after that - you kind of want to go have an afternoon nap.
Really cannot over recommend this place.

1879.review:
Best ramen I have had in London. 
I can't wait for them to expand in NYC and Or LA. My waitress Noelle was exceptionally amazing are her service. I wish for her to serve me my next visit. I had the Fish cakes that were to Die for, the Kotteri ramen and the TAN TAN Ramen are highly recommended. Thank You

1880.review: That is a decent Ramen like the one I'm used to find in California. I had the classic one with Pork, mushrooms and the half cooked egg. Ordered and Served promptly, Finished the bowl in a couple of minutes. Even Forgot to take a picture! I will go back there anytime!

1881.review:
I am a big fan of ramen and am always up for discovering the best shop around town. There are two Shoryu around Piccadilly Circus, which is a highly touristy area, so I am already a bit suspicious. 
Though a gong is rung every time a customer comes in or goes out of the shop, it doesn't make the place more Japanese. Maybe most of the servers are not Japanese or the restaurant just doesn't have the coziness which is typical of Japanese ramen places. 
I went there for lunch, so I just ordered Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu which is their signature ramen. Anybody who is into ramen knows that the broth is what makes or breaks ramen. Their broth is ok flavor-wise, but nothing really jumped out at me. The toppings include pickled ginger, fried shallots and black wood ear in addition to the usual roasted pork and egg. Overall, it was a good bowl of ramen but that's it. 
Shoryu offers a lot of side dishes ranging from sashimi, pork buns to chicken wings, which are not food you would see served at an authentic ramen shop. Call me all fashioned, a good ramen place to me should have just a few options of ramen and limited number of side dishes. Shoryu seems to be a Japanese restaurant that caters mostly to tourists and serves all sorts of Japanese dishes, one of which happens to be  Ramen. If you are looking for great ramen place, I wouldn't recommend it, but if you want some decent Japanese food in the area, this is not a bad choice.

1882.review: Stopped by on a cold London afternoon to some comfort food. The wait staff was very welcoming, walking me through the menu and different options. I ordered their Tonkotsu ramen, gyoza and pork bun. I thought all of the food was very average, but not bad. The tonkotsu broth lacked something, but it was not flavorful enough while the noodles were a bit soft for my taste. Not a bad bowl of ramen but not one that is memorable. The gyoza was presented on a sizzling skillet, very cool. However, the flavor of the gyoza stuffing was also lacking something, perhaps sesame oil? The pork bun used a miso paste of some sort and was my least favorite thing I ordered that day. Okay for a quick bowl if you're craving one but probably not one I would recommend people to go out of their way to get. They do have free wifi.

1883.review:
Why is everything in london so expensive... Came to london for a vacation, mid week through our trip of course I start to crave asian food and whats better than a hot bowl of ramen?
Shoryu specializes in tonkotsu soup base which is my favorite.  They have different option for the thickness of the broth.  If you are used to eating ramen def go with the rich broth option as their regular broth was a little on the bland side.  I love the egg as its the perfect yolk consistency.  Service was pretty good also, very fast and attentive.  
While the noodles are pretty good here, it is hard to stomach the fact that I spent almost $100 US dollars here for 2 bowls of ramen, 6pc gyoza and an icecream dessert.  It cost like $30 for a bowl of ramen and $5 to add just an egg...if you are a local then definitely check out this place as their ramen is pretty good but if you are travelling from NY i would say to skip it and save the $.

1884.review: A few days ago, I came across this busy and surprisingly delicious Japanese cafe. What makes it surprising is that I was expecting a traditional bao, but in fact it was a mixture of 3 of my favorite infused ethic flavores combined in one bao bun.  Japanese karaage chicken, topped with Korean gochujang sauce and placed between a Chinese style bun. Wowee Bao-ee!! So much flavor bursts exciting my taste buds! Definitely glad I tried that. My Japanese fruit infused mojito and green tea cheesecake for dessert topped it all of to perfection!

1885.review:
I rarely give five stars for ramen because I enjoy a particular style and that is tonkotsu broth and not many places do it well.
I walked into Shoryu for lunch solo on a weekday afternoon and didn't have to wait for a seat. The place was pretty packed for lunch.
I got a Dracula ramen which is tonkotsu with garlic. Garlic oil, garlic chips, fresh minced garlic, which as one can imagine, gets a pretty strong flavor. Let's just say I wasn't kissing anyone for the whole day or even opening my mouth because I could've killed someone with my breath. Was it worth it? You bet.
The broth was rich and flavorful and the flavors melded together for a heavenly experience. The ramen came with half an egg perfectly done and three slices of fatty chashu. What I REALLY enjoyed was that there was some ginger in the broth, which really contrasted well with the garlic. Anyone can throw garlic inside tonkotsu but not everyone can layer flavors like a Korean girl layers clothes. My only grouse is that there was half an egg. Just give me the whole damned egg already. Thank you.
I haven't written my Bone Daddies review yet but tldr;
I would choose Shoryu over Bone Daddies. 
I have noticed a distinct difference in the crowds at both places. Shoryu has a more Asian crowd and Bone Daddies seems to have a hipster crowd. Different strokes for different folks.

1886.review:
Just as good as the other Shoryu chains. Key advantage of this one is that it's less busy and hectic than the other locations that are in higher footfall areas.
Food is extremely consistent and I have difficulty spotting any differences between this place and the Soho branches.
Most of the tables here are for 2 people so if you're an odd group you'll probably be seated on a group table, by the single seaters at the window or I guess they can merge some tables together.
Check out my other reviews if you want to know what the food is like.
Shoryu Carnaby - 
yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-ca…
Shoryu Soho - 
yelp.co.uk/biz/shoryu-lo…

1887.review: We looking for a a quick noodle fix before our train back to Birmingham. This looked liked the go to place for ramen and it didn't disappoint. Up on arrival into the small restaurant a bong sounded and all the staff greeted us in unison. A unique if not strange touch. The two of us had traveling bags, so chose a 4 seater table. Even this was a squeeze. I went for the shoryu pork ramen and my partner went for the curry flavoured chicken ramen. we had pork buns on the side to share. The dishes came quickly and were well presented. I really enjoyed the pork broth and the slowed cooked egg was perfect. The pork buns though seemed a little unloved and a bit thrown together. Overall a decent quick cheap eat.

1888.review: Great Natural Miso Ramen, great flavours. It was the only ramen suitable for vegetarians. Besides the Ramen the Harata buns Tempura shrimp and halloumi were great. It would be great if they had more vegetarian selections.

1889.review: This is not a Japanese ramen. I ordered chicken ramen and the taste was bland and my friend ordered pork based ramen but he said it tastes so bland. The price is expensive, there is no Japanese thing in this resto and the matcha taste bitter, it is like cheapest matcha which you can find in supermarket. I used to stay in Osaka Japan, and my descendant is Japanese, I know exactly this is not made by Japanese hand. They also asked for tips which makes it worst.

1890.review:
Although I personally prefer a simple tonkotsu ramen, they have quite the variety for those that are more adventurous. I found the overall experience and food better here than Bone Daddies. The fried chicken at Bone Daddies is better though!
The Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu broth was rich and flavorful. The pork belly buns were.delish!!! Soft and tender pork bursting with flavor with a mild spicy kick on some fluffy buns. The fried chicken could have been crispier but had good flavor.
Pork belly Hirata bunsChicken Kara Age Fried Chicken- crispy deep fried soy, garlic, and ginger marinated chickenShoryu Ganso Tonkotsu- signature ramen, a tonkotsu and miso broth with added spinach and garlicHokkaido Curry Ramen- rich curry-soy pork broth with crispy kara age chicken, nitamago, nori, menma, naruto fish cake, and spring onion

1891.review: Really not that great. I was pretty disappointed in the overall experience. Ramen broth was ok but the meat wasn't seasoned well. Over crowded an bathroom smell was noticeable. This is tourist ramen.

1892.review: The ramen here is delicious, nice filling portions and quick service if you are in a hurry. They also serve "frozen beer" where the froth is this strange frozen swirl if you are curious

1893.review:
An absolute favorite Ramen restaurant of mine. This was the first time I'd been to the Carnaby Street branch, tucked away inside Kingly Court. From all the Shroyus it has the best atmosphere by far! It's not as crowded/ small as the others, the wood-paneled walls give it a warm feel and the lighting and decor is just right. 
The food of course is amazing. We shared the pimentos and the Chicken Karaage (a definite MUST at Shoryu), and for our mains I had the Curry Ramen- bursting with flavor and totally filling, while my friend, who likes her dishes a little more spicy, chose the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu.
Service was attentive and speedy, place was buzzing with people. You can't go wrong with this place to fulfill your Ramen Needs!

1894.review: Yes, it's as good as advertised. Line is not that long. And it's nice that they have a nice heat lamp for those waiting outside.

1895.review:
Let me say that I'm a big ramen fan, but I think I've been spoiled by ramen I've had in San Francisco and Las Vegas.  
On a cold rainy day in London ramen is a nice antidote to blah weather.  This place does a decent job, although the noodles were pretty thin and didn't seem to be freshly made.  
Overall a decent place that I'd probably go back to.

1896.review:
Came here after seeing it on yelp. I was having a crazy ramen craving and this seemed like a legit spot, so I gave it a try. I'm sure glad I did!
I came at about 5 PM on a weekday and the place was about half full. I was immediately greeted by the waitstaff and seated at the tables facing the window (one of the perks of dining alone- you can people watch!). Its on Regent Street, smack dab in between Piccadilly Circus and Trafalgar Square so there's plenty of foot traffic going by. 
The restaurant is somewhat small but has a very modern-style Japanese decor theme. The menu is short and sweet, but they have plenty of varieties of ramen for every taste. I originally leaned towards the curry ramen but ultimately went with the piri-piri ramen after reading peoples' rave reviews. 
I put in my order for a cocktail (only £6 during happy hour!) and ramen, and both were out within 10 minutes. My cocktail -whose name I cannot remember- tasted like a mai tai and was definitely strong... but enjoyable. The ramen came out piping hot with lots of goodies on top of the bed of noodles. The noodles were cooked to the perfect al-dente consistency but I was a little disappointed in the lack of spiciness. Since this is their spicy option, I expected a little more of a kick. There was also a little bit too much lemongrass for my own personal tastes but not so much that it kept me from enjoying my meal. I noticed some reviews remarked on the small serving size but I felt it was the perfect size. I hadn't eaten all day and finished off most of my noodles, and felt more than satisfied. 
Overall, this is a great ramen place if you're in central London. The service was super friendly and attentive. The ramen itself was really tasty and they have all kinds of varieties to try. I definitely think its worth checking out if you get the chance!

1897.review:
As a ramen junkie from NYC, I've been traveling around London's ramen scene to try and find the best bowl here. Shoryu piqued my interest due to the fact that they tout their Hakata roots, which is the region of Japan that tonkotsu ramen is specialized. So I had to come by and try the tonkotsu broth!
I stopped in around noon and was seated immediately. I ordered the Kotteri Tonkotsu Ramen, a chashu pork bun, and a grilled halloumi and shimeji mushroom bun.
The ramen came out first, which was a bit strange, but I started eating. The broth was not as rich as I like my tonkotsu ramen to be. It has what I've complained about most NYC ramen - I call it the "Ippudo Problem," where the tonkotsu broth is the specialty but is not super rich. Tonkotsu broth should be thick, bony, and hearty, but the broth here (which was said to be extra rich) is pretty thin. Also, it was a bit under seasoned, a bit bland. I don't like my broths salty but I do like some flavor in the soup.
The noodles here are missing that signature bite that ramen noodles have (even when I ordered it hard), almost just like regular egg noodles.
You can thank Momofuku and David Chang for the steamed buns with ramen trend around the world, and the buns here have the same problem that the ones at Momofuku Noodle Bar in NYC does - they are overly sauced with a very strong sauce that masks the flavor of the main ingredient and you basically are eating a bao with sauce and some meat/protein rather than getting a nice complex bite of flavors and textures. It's a shame, because I only really tasted the cucumber because it was not as salty as the rest of it. I actually had to wash it down with the broth (really shows you how bland it was).
I ordered kaedama and it came out quickly, but they didn't put any tare or sauce on the noodles, so when I put it into the bowl, it watered it down a bit and made it blander.
Overall, this was a pretty average bowl of ramen. There are many better bowls of ramen in London.

1898.review:
I'll go here again.  Small place but packed with lots of flavor and great Japanese ramen.  I got their set (shoryu bun, ramen, and cheesecake for 11.90) and Kirin Frozen. 
Great meal for dinner.

1899.review: I would give it six stars if I could. This place surpasses any ramen shop I visited in Boston or NewYork (yes, more impressive than Totto or Sapora etc.) I ordered the Tan Tan Ramen, whose soup base is AMAZING - with a touch of spiciness but not too heavy; make sure to choose to have noodle cooked the hardest way. My fiancé had another ramen (sry forgot the name lol) which was equally fantastic, and his soup base tastes totally different from mine - unlike a lot of other ramen places where dishes share similar base. Service is decent. We arrived ~9pm Sunday night and there was no queue.

1900.review: I like this Ramen place lot. Great service and great food. the Bun is so-so, I will only recommend the Ramen here. I will going back if I have a chance.

1901.review:
I almost always try the most basic ramen when I visit a new place, but this time I made an exception and went for one of my favorites, cold sesame ramen (Hiyashi Chuka). If you've never had this before, and it's a hot summer day, you should definitely give it a chance. Save the hot soup for colder weather.
Noodles: Very good. Firm and cooked just right. Better than Bone Daddies IMO.
Hiyashi Chuka sauce/tare: A bit to much sweetness, but overall very good.
Tokyo egg: Perfectly cooked. However Bone Daddies tea smoked marinated egg is still one of the best I've ever had anywhere. 
Toppings: Menma (bamboo) not bad, needed  more crunch. Tomatoes were not the best - since they're in season now they could have been better. Charsu was a bit to dry, that's why most places use cooked ham typically (there  is no hot soup to soften the chasu). 
Nit picking now: Needed a small dab of mustard on the side (pretty standard). And cucumbers should be added too - especially since you're making it in England where they love cucumber too.
Overall: A great bowl. In Tokyo I'd give it a 3, but for London it's top notch.
Other stuff: Service was decent, but I find it really weird in London how so many servers don't seem to know squat about the food they're serving. Gyoza were good - and may have been made in house possibly (impressive).
I will return to try the basic tonkatsu ramen when the weather changes.

1902.review: Very tasty and mouthful. Stick with the raman, everything else is ordinary. Staff are pleasant ans the decor is nice.

1903.review: Ramen in london.  After visiting japan, the ramen was average.   Nothing bad about it although it it took an awful long time to arrive to the table.  The servers were really nice.   The price i felt was too high compared to other competitors.

1904.review:
Try to get here before 6pm if you are dining on a Saturday evening or you'll have to wait in line outside!
I too think their tonkotsu ramen is better than Bone Daddy's.  I had a bite of the ramen with matcha noodle, but I personally like the regular noodle better taste-wise, less distraction from the rest of the dish.  And matcha noodle seems to get soft quickly in hot soup while the regular noodle stayed firm for long.
I was very impressed with their salmon Hirata Buns.  The salmon karaage goes really with the soft bun with lettuce and cucumber, really enjoyed it :)
If you are looking for a Ume-shou type of salty tea, their Ume Kombu Cha is recommended.

1905.review:
I don't want to sound like a food snob, but I wasn't expecting much from an English ramen place. However, I'm happy to say that Shoryu was a pleasant surprise! I saw a bunch of people waiting on line to get in but they were in parties of 3+ so I decided to go in and put myself on a list in case there was one. Turns out there is no list, the line is 'first come first served' but because I told them that I was just two people, we got to skip the line. Lesson: don't just follow the crowd. 
As per usual in London, it took a million years for them to take our order of a beer, cocktail, the tan tan ramen and the Dracula ramen. The cocktail, which was just soda and plum wine, wasn't very good. But, the ramens weren't all that bad. The minced pork ramen (£10) was pretty much liquid fire for me, but my boyfriend managed fine. The Dracula ramen (£11.90) had a richer broth that wasn't spicy and was really good when I added some rice vinegar to it. Good spot if you're looking for a change from the fish and chips, but I don't need to go back.

1906.review: My next favorite place for ramen in London, 2nd to kanada-ya. The ramen is great, and the side dishes are also delicious. Only downside is that the ramen sometimes feels abit greasy imo. Btw, the curry ramen is really good actually but it's not a popular choice so I'm recommending it here.

1907.review:
I found Shoryu Ramen to be much better than bone daddies!  However, I never found bone daddies to be traditional style ramen in the first place...
We arrived Sunday afternoon and we were seated immediately.  I got their classic Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and the wife got the Piri Piri Tonkotsu which is their spiciest ramen.  Both looked great and tasted even better!
They even give you the option for 4 different sizes noodles, however, we stuck with the classic thin hosomen noodles (original) ...not sure if they were homemade but they tasted very good.
Am looking forward to going back to try some of their more creative ramen like the 'Dracula Tonkotsu'?!

1908.review:
This place definitely hit the spot on a rainy and cold day in London! My friend and I were lucky to make it to the shop before the kitchen closes (they close 30 min before their posted closing time). We didn't have that much time left to order but we were definitely satisfied with what we got!
We both ordered the Piri Piri Shoryu Ramen, it's the spicy version of the Shoryu Ramen. We both loved our ramen! The noodles tasted very fresh and the broth was very flavorful and had the right amount of spice! I wouldn't recommend getting the Piri Piri if you are just looking for a little bit of heat. The green tea and raspberry mochi were the perfect treat to end our dinner.
I forgot to mention that service was really friendly too. 
I've had good ramen back in the a States before and I think this place is very good. The only downside about it is that everything is so expensive in London. Back in the States, you can get a lot of extra toppings and customize your own ramen for much cheaper at very well known ramen shops. However, it is what it is and I definitely enjoyed Shoryu Ramen! I would definitely recommend this place to anyone! :)

1909.review:
Had the kotteri tonkotsu ramen and a beer. 
Noodles were decent, roasted pork a bit small, boiled egg was good. Soup tasted like it had noodle flour in it and also the kitchen had dumped a massive pile of pickled ginger on top which made the soup taste oddly fishy. 
The draft beer was Kirin, decent but not spectacular- on the menu it said that it would be served very cold but it was several degrees above that. 
Price for a bowl of ramen 12 quid, with today's exchange rate making the ramen at least 3 times what one would pay for the same food in Japan. Service was friendly if a bit disorganized on a crowded Saturday afternoon, but the buy 1 ramen get the second half-off coupon that I used made up for any slowness and probably saved Shoryu from a trip to 2-starland, for now three is the number of the stars thou shalt count, and the number of the counting shall be three.

1910.review:
Was not happy with the service.  The lady did not comprehend what I was asking. I ordered the regular ramen w the fried shallots and I had asked her if it was simply the basic ramen w the Pork and egg plus the added ingredient of fried shallots. Took me about Three minutes to ask what I needed to ask until I gave up and went with it. And she still didn't understand. Service was terrible overall 
The ramen was ok. A bit oily. I prefer kanada-ya ramen over shoryu

1911.review:
Great place last minute when a more popular ramen place had a line out the door.
Service was a bit slow but they were just finishing up their night so it is to be expected when closing up other areas of the shop. 
Will def return.

1912.review: My wife and I loved this place.  There was a short wait to get a table as the place was packed but certainly worth the wait.  The broth was savory, the noodles were cooked perfectly, and the portion was just the right size.  I don't really associate London with ramen but my wife and I will certainly be back!

1913.review: Shoryu think you can cook Ramen! Honestly this restaurant was AMAZING. Great service that was friendly and quick and the best food I've had in awhile. I highly recommend the pork belly bun, edamame beans, and ramen! I would go again!

1914.review: Visiting London and was trying to find a delicious Ramen place. Checked out Yelp and this was the top rated one nearby our hotel. I see how it was top rated. The service was very attentive and quick. The Ramen man it was delish the broth was super tasty. I ordered the spicy mince pork one while my bf ordered the most popular ramen dish. I prefered my broth for it was less richer. Overall if ever back in London would definitely come back!

1915.review:
Now I see what all the hype is surrounding Ramen.  With a sore throat and the desire for some fresh vegetables, we happily chose to eat here for some ramen. 
I ordered the vegetarian bowl with extra mushrooms and my friend ordered the traditional pork Ramen bowl. 
Although it took some getting use to using the spoon and chopsticks, we really enjoyed our fresh soup and I'm wishing there was a great ramen place in Tampa bay.

1916.review:
I've been to a lot of ramen places in the US (mostly in California), but Shoryu Ramen in London is hands down the best I've had. We were in town for less than a week, and naturally we wanted to try out as many restaurants as possible, but we ended up eating here twice because it was so good.
The wait was quite long for dinner, but we were able to be seated immediately for lunch. It's a small, packed space and you will most likely be seated at a table connected to another party.
I got the curry ramen both times. It was unique, flavorful, and the perfect portion. The only suggestion I have is to put the karaage chicken on the side, so as not to have them turn soggy.  Additionally, the lychee strawberry drink was amazing, but maybe not worth £6.

1917.review:
Delicious! 
I went to London for a weekend and I absolutely wanted to try Shoryu after all the excellent reviews I read. 
I waited for 30 min on a cold night but it was definitely worth the wait. 
I ordered a Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu ramen and loved it ! The noodles were perfectly cooked and broth was yummy & spicy.

1918.review: very nice. we got two spicy vegans and one tonkatsu. the aesthetic and atmosphere itself is very cozy. service is prompt and answer all and any questions you have. food is delicous and huge-as ramen always is. and it's open late!

1919.review: The Donkatsu ramen was very good.  Rich and brothy.  Much better than what I tasted in Paris.  However, not as good as in SF or Japan but well worth the 1.5 miles walk from my hotel.  Also had the tempura and sesame tofu.  The tempura was good but not too much batter.  Not as crunchy as it could have been.  The black sesame toy was new and good.  I would definitely come back!

1920.review:
It's very hard for me to go and change a venue for something new especially when it comes to Ramen. Although this was a good choice. Food was very tasty. Service was cool too. I will definitely come back when I am back in London. 
Thanks

1921.review:
Quite disappointed with the pork belly bun, the pork was great but while the bun looked well made, it seemed to have been "restored" in the microwave. Even with a full set of teeth there was no tearing through that bun. 
   But alas, then the ramen arrived, I had the Karaha Tantan Tonkosu Ramen.  I was totally blown away. I was just in Tokyo in January and this bowl rivaled my favorites there. Perfect texture and wonderful warming heat! I could not get this dish out of my mind and returned to their other Soho location two days later! Even with the bulletproof bun, I am still giving 5 stars!

1922.review:
Really good ramen! Okra appetizer looks deceptively simple but really yummy.  The broth is less pork-y, if you know what I mean.  This really hits the spot when you're looking for ramen and thankfully now there are a few locations so less chance that you'll have to queue.
I would have given five stars but it's a little while since I've been so I'm going to have to visit again and update my review.  A good excuse to have ramen at Shoryu again!

1923.review:
Yum yum yum!
