Was looking for authentic Japanese ramen and definitely found it here! Even my parents approved/they loved it!
Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu: Perfect ramen if you're looking for a savory hearty ramen. 
Hirata Buns: ****OH MY GOODNESS. Must try. delicious.
Chicken Kara Age: Can never go wrong with fried chicken :)
It gets pretty busy so I'll definitely be back on a slow day/night.

1924.review: The shoryu ban with pork and chicken is very delicious. The Piri Piri Tonkotsu is kind of spicy but it tastes good.

1925.review:
Not that good as I had too much good experience in HK. The food did not meet my expectation. The pork belly bun is too fatty for me and the steamed bun is not that soft, the sauce is not strong. The dumpling is nothing special. Will not go again 
But the staff is very helpful there

1926.review:
I can't believe it has taken me so long to write this review.
THIS PLACE IS AMAZING!
I remember the first time I discovered this place: I was on bus 23 towards Picadilly Circus when I saw the huge line of Japanese outside this little place. Intrigued, I went back the next day, stood in line in the cold for half an hour having no idea what was expecting me. Basically, I didn't know what ramen was until I stepped foot here.
Obviously, I've seen the light and consider myself a convert. My new religion is ramen. 
Ramen is a bowl of soup, mostly on pork stock, with noodles, half an egg, some veggies - but the description doesn't do it justice, as ramen is a state of mind. The absolutely sensational feeling of well being when you sip on the soup, chew on the noodles. Then the wonderful feeling hours after you've had your ramen.. Ahh.. 
I usually go for the Tokyo Ramen, but last time Ulrik tried the cold ramen and it was soooo good! A new favourite for sure.
Go, wait in line, eat, be happy!

1927.review: Great ramen place, though not the most authentic (pickled ginger strips, what are you doing in my ramen soup??) and a bit pricey. Close to Piccadilly Circus. Make sure to go early if you have a large party, especially for dinner because this place fills up fast.

1928.review:
After going to Japan recently, my husband and I are now massive ramen snobs.  We've been to Shoryu in Soho before and loved it, so we gave this one a try on a Sunday night (no booking) to see if it was as good as we remembered.
It's a packed and busy place, with no room to wait inside, but it was only about 10 minutes before we made it in the door with my parents and grandmother.  I had the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu - their signature ramen with meatier broth and two eggs, as well as barbecued pork belly, mushrooms, spring onion, sesame, ginger, and seaweed.  Drool.  You can choose how firm you want the noodles too (firm all the way!) and we passed around a few sides of lovely Chicken Karaage - Japanese fried chicken.  It was, as expected, lush, although not the completely glorious closed-eyes experience I remembered from the other Shoryu (I think Japan has ruined me forever).  The broth is just lacking that particular je ne sais quoi that we ate in Asia, but everything else about the dish - noodles, pork, accoutrements, were lovely and craveable.  The fried chicken was very good, with a more delicate batter than you usually get with fried chicken, no bones, and a very hot temperature so watch your tongue!
A very affordable and delicious place to go for dinner.  Not a bad substitute if you can't make it to Tokyo!

1929.review:
The pork belly buns were flavourfull and yummy; the gyoza had a fresh pork filling that reminded me of homemade (although the skins were not).  I had the original ramen which was a big bowl of miso pork broth with two fatty slices of pork, some seaweed and scallions.  This was good although I did have food envy for my friend's signature ramen (there was half an egg!)  One drawback on the broth was that it was quite greasy.  Defat the broth!  It's not hard to do and really makes for a better, non-greasy experience.  It's not fun having to wipe your lips because it feels like you've put on too much lip balm.
While I liked Shoryu and would go back, the main drawback is the seating.  I think they are trying to provide an authentic, Tokyo experience by making the tables as crowded together as possible.  It is not a place to have any sort of intimate conversation with anyone because you are literally right up against the person sitting next to you.  I get turning tables but Shoryu borders on the ridiculous.  No wonder there were so many solo diners.  You wouldn't want to go here for a friendly chat or first date!

1930.review: Ramen and buns are okay. Service was prompt. The price is reasonable compared to london standards. They add a service charge to your bill. Come here early as the place gets packed after 6pm.

1931.review: I had their signature ramen dish. It's ok but I've had better. Broth was a bit bland for my taste, noodles were decent but could be better. Pork was very good. I'd eat here again if I was in the area but wouldn't come specially for this.

1932.review:
I've now had the chance to return to Shoryu to try more of their menu. In fact, their ever burgeoning menu. I'm impressed quickly they've added dishes to their menu, both in the ramen and the starter/side dishes categories
They've also tweaked service slightly. You still get the cheerful Japanese greeting but they've done away with the drum they hit with each new customer
They've expanded their ramen menu with both traditional and innovative combinations. I want to love their ramen but can only bring myself to like it. At the risk of sounding ungrateful, I think they put too much in their bowl. I like ramen because I like to taste the ramen noodles but the noodles get lost with all the other parapernalia they put into the bowl
They've also greatly expanded their starter/side dish menu. I have to give a shout out to their belly pork hirata buns. These are made up with 2 steamed buns which are quite dense but the perfect foil to the sweet soft pork which they sandwich. I had discovered these at Ippudo in New York and am so glad that I've found somewhere in London which does them
If you want a range of dishes, go to Shoryu for their range. However, if you want the best bowl ramen, I'd still recommend Bone Daddies

1933.review:
Delicious and fresh of the salmon 
I recommend the spicy reman.
My friend and I love this place. 
The service here is great. The waiters are friendly
When you pay the bill,it contain the tip ,10% of the cost.

1934.review:
Me and some friends took advantage of the massive discounts Shoryu was offering and payed the new shop in Piccadilly a visit.   I gotta say in advance that my opinion about the place was not very positive for a good part of the evening but then built up and ended on a good note.  
When we first arrived, we were left outside on a queue waiting to get in with no indication of whether it would take 10 minutes or 1 hour. Not a big deal, but doesn't get anyone any points either. When we finally got a table, we had to wait quite a while to get a menu (which only arrived after us chasing the waiter). 10 minutes later, 2 more people were squeezed in into our table - clearly a management attempt to fit in as many people as possible.  It is fair to say that there wasn't much space left in the table, but that didn't matter as far as the drinks were concerned: 3£ for the smallest orange juice I've ever seen in my life.  
Those were the not so good points... but then a storm of flavor arrived and washed that all away.  
The starters are really really good, specially the Hirata Buns - the pork ones are spicy but terrific. We also had Soft Shell Crab Tempura which were more than enough for 4 people.  
The main Ramen dishes completely met our expectations: flavorful, big portions, good balance between the ingredients. We struggled to finish them after all those starters so it's worth building up your appetite before visiting the place! I had the Tori Kara-Age Men and was quite happy with it - only negative was the size of the fish cake portion: way too small.   We also ordered an extra cold Ramen to try it out. Unfortunately, the waiter brought us the wrong one, so not sure which one it was. 
Overall the service was a bit all over the place and not that well organized, but the staff was friendly and approachable. Can't really give this one a 5 but the food was good enough to stir away from a 3.

1935.review:
3.5 stars
Decent ramen in London??? Not sure I even recognise this city anymore. I swear every place has only popped up in the year I was away. (Which is incredible!)
Ramen:
Any place with tonkotsu broth, I'm going to invariably compare to ippudo. The broth was good to be sure but just not as flavourful as I'd like. It lacks a certain intensity you find in other places.
Noodles here are pretty nice. Again, not big on flavour but they have a wonderful texture. Definitely Shoryu's USP.
Sides:
Had gyozas, chicken karaage, and pork buns. All were extremely enjoyable. Pork buns are a must order. 
Overall:
I'd give the ramen 3.5 stars objectively. In Singapore or New York, I'd say this is an average ramen place. It's a safe choice, enjoyable, but really nothing special. In London though, those same factors mean it's effectively 5 stars. If you're craving ramen, you'll be satisfied.

1936.review:
I queued in the snow for nearly an hour... just to eat this ramen.
(And gyoza and onigiri)
AND IT RULED.
After we finally got in, we got lucky and secured the only 2 seater table in the place. We were right against the window and had to turn our knees outward as they didn't fit under the table, and I had a fire extinguisher sticking out from the wall behind me. It's definitely a squash in here when it's full so be warned. But unlike Bone Daddies your lack of space doesn't come with uncomfortably loud music and petty portion sizes. So it's even more worth it.
We ordered some drinks and a portion of gyoza. They came pretty quickly and were awesome. The gyoza skins were nicely crispy and the perfect thickness.
Then our ramens arrived. I had the Charsui Tonkotsu for £10 a bowl - which is kind of expensive, but the portion is really generous and it's so good - again this beat Bone Daddies offering. There was lots of broth (GOOD) and the perfect amount of noodles and meat and lots of toppings. The broth was the perfect texture, it had that tonkotsu thickness but wasn't too fatty and greasy. My husband went for the Dracula Tonkotsu, which he loved. It was essentially the richer, garlicy-er version of the normal Tonkotsu and was a dream come true. We asked for vinegar and shichimi powder. They brought a huge metal jug of vinegar and a cute wooden container of shichimi, the waiter was quite funny about the size of the vinegar and the vinegar was really, really good. I love vinegar in my ramen so finding a place that offers it on-menu is a huge plus.
When we saw the specials board we couldn't help ordering a couple of onigiri. They were meant to come with brown rice but as they were running out they asked if we'd mind one with white rice. They were so apologetic and said if we didn't like it with white rice we could have one with brown for free! But for me this was even better as I prefer white rice. They were filled with pickles and really delicious.
The onigiri filled us up quite a lot and when we couldn't finish the ramen, we were so happy to find they'd bag everything up in a takeaway bag for us to take home.
The service was good, with one minor slip up when a different waiter tried to deliver a second plate of dumplings to us and didn't apologise for the mistake, aside from that it was pretty perfect.
I love the food here. If it wasn't for the cramped space (sorry, I know it's ramen bar style but I'm still getting used to these packed-in restaurants!) and the fact we had to queue for so long it'd be a 5 star straight away!

1937.review: Great value for money in London- very enjoyable food - company and service- sure there is better about but this is a great sushi - Japanese Restrauant in a nice quite location- you will enjoy it without fuss- walked in freestyle for a Restrauant and found this gem. Was very close t giving it a 4 star rating - but is just isn't there yet

1938.review:
So yummy. Much Umami. Goooood!
Quick lunch in trafalgar square and around? planning for some ramen but you already tried sasuke (which is better!)? Definitely come here. Especially if you are alone.
The place is not that big with many small tables and a counter running all over the window. No-nonsense chart, solid ramens, some buns and just a couple of other dishes. But you definitely wanna get the ramen.
Take the one you prefer, I usually go for the standard one when I want to try a new place (first you show me you can cook a steak, then you can make a filetto alla rossini!), and just stare at the broth: Brown, thick, if I didn't knew it was liquid I'd have said it was a cream! Definitely something special, you can feel that it will be delicious just by looking at it! That my friends is probably the best broth I ever had in my ramen. The egg follows the same description, just absolutely amazing, cooked at the perfection, and overall a real pleasure.
The only thing missing, and the reason why it stands below Sasuke in my personal RAMENED competition (Ramen Axelrod May Eat Night & Day) is regarding the thickness of the noodles, which I found a bit too thin for my personal palate. But that's just me being an annoying stickler.
Just come here and enjoy the delicious broth!

1939.review:
I tried the Karaka TanTan Tonkotsu Ramen which were garlicky spicy noodles with minced pork on top.  My egg was a bit overcooked, I do like the yolk soft and runny.  My Tantan noodles were on the saltier side.  The only thing that annoyed me was that all the minced pork sunk to the bottom of the bowl, and I spent most of my time trying to fish it out. 
I think I'm gonna stick with basic Tonkotsu noodles, where I actually get slices of pork.  
To share, we had the Chicken Karaage - same as last time, nicely fried!  We also ordered Gyoza, but for 5, I felt it was quite understuffed and small.  The wrapping was a bit on the hard side.  The pork filling was good, nothing wrong with that.  But I think for the value, I'll stick with just the karaage. 
My friend ordered the Charsiu Tonkotsu - which is pretty much your classic noodles but with extra pork.  I tasted the broth, and strangely enough, it was... on the sweeter side.  I thought it was just me, but he tasted it too and thought it was definitely sweet.  Anyway, still a nice place to go to, but I think my go-to place is Bone Daddies for now.

1940.review: This place is amazing.  Original and vegetarian were both delicious.  I've been dreaming about the broth and the noodles ever since.  Very warming on a cold winter night.

1941.review:
I got a very good Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. The broth was very tasty and there was quite a lot of meat and vegetables inside.
The only problem is that the standard noodles are very thin. If you prefer the bigger noodles you must tell it when you order.
Every day they also have a day offer: when I went there it was 2 buns at the price of 1. Which is a pretty good offer since it means that you'll pay just 2.25£ per each.

1942.review: I only had one vegetarian choice here...and I loved it! I also had the sake flight of the day and it was a great discovery. The non-Japanese staff kept yelling random-sounding phrases in Japanese. Not too sure what that means but whatever! It's a small place so be ready to wait, it's worth it.

1943.review: This is a solid 3 stars, if you only order the ramen. The buns were a huge disappointment, lovely soft and fluffy, ruined by iceberg lettuce, piece of cucumber and pretty rank Mayo. Not worth queuing for, pricey, but I can forgive a little of that given it is in tourist central. Broth is made centrally and shipped in, if that matters to you. I feel kind of bad about the two stars, but don't big up the buns and leave me feeling like I've been conned out of seven and a half quid ! Will I be back, probably not.

1944.review:
Really solid ramen chain. Go for the Dracula garlic flavor or something more than just the plain option. We tried the third "hardest" noodle type and it was good, nothing too crazy. I'd try the hardest one next time. The noodles are thin and not too starchy, so the consistency worked well. The garlic broth was intense in a great way. I do wish they included corn as a topping. My husband ordered a "frozen beer" which was a fun gimmick. 
The place should write down orders though because they initially brought us the entirely wrong flavor for one of our bowls and had to go remake it. Then they just never delivered the appetizer we ordered. Kinda amateur service issues.

1945.review:
I only was told about this ramen place two weeks ago while trying out another Ramen bar ... since then I have been three time. Yes, it is that good. I like most of the broths, also some were too salty. I also tried the different sides and they are all delicious. I'm a fan. ... but I think I will stop going now, as I need to give other places a try as well.
One word of warning: on the weekend we had to queue for a place, but on a normal weekday ... if you go straight after work ... you will find a spare seat.

1946.review:
I've been to Shoryu now twice, once during their soft opening and once afterwards. 
This place specializes in a a different sort of white soup ramen from a particular region in Japan. Compared to places like Bone Daddies, this is more of an authentic Japanese-style ramen place (but that's not to say that authenticity=better). 
Service: When I went during the soft opening, they were definitely still working out the kinks. They have one waitress in particular who we've named 'waitress happy pants' because of her... rather surly demeanor. Quite frankly, I don't know if she was just having a horrible day or what, but I am very forgiving when it comes to bad service, but less so when they are snappy and eye-rolly and seem like they hate their job and everything is the customer's fault (even when it isn't). At any rate, she was actually more hilarious than frustrating, so whatever. 
Food: High soup to noodle content, the soup is flavorful but not quite rich enough for my personal tastes, some nice goodies in the bowl, but not quite enough of them. The ramen noodles themselves were the best thing about this bowl, really good. The first time I got the Shoryu Ramen, which was nice. The second time I had the Tokyo Ramen, which was soy sauce based broth with fish cake and bamboo. I think I prefer the Shoryu because it was one of the specialty white broths. Do order the egg, as they are well seasoned and quite nice (though it is a shame they don't come automatically with a bowl like they do at Tonkotsu and Bone Daddies). My dining partner had the yuzu ramen, which was really tasty. 
When I come back, I want to try to spicy miso and the yuzu ones. That said, and this is just personal preference, I found the overall dining experience and food at Bone Daddies to be more satisfying, but it is actually quite hard to compare the two as they are totally different ramen beasts. I'll certainly be back to Shoryu as well, when I want a soupier/less heavy noodle experience.

1947.review: To be honest, one of the best meals we had in London. Despite the poor service (bad attitude) the food was very good. The soup was thick and the noodles was perfect too. Great reman!

1948.review:
Went today to take advantage of their soft launch special where ramen is all 50% off. The place was packed!! I've never seen so many Japanese people in one place in London :P
I had the spicy miso ramen which was awesome. Broth and noodles were legit. Loved it and you can't beat the price at 4 quid for the special price. Service was fast and friendly.  
Soft launch special prices are until Nov 24.

1949.review: Best ramen I have ever had! I ordered the kimchi seafood ramen ! Spicy with fresh squid, scallops and  prawns!

1950.review:
Authentic and Nice atmosphere. Friendly service :)
Had the signature dish ( tonkotsu ramen) and hirata bun as side. Great value, and large portions!

1951.review: Best ramen I've had!! Visiting from the US and I will have serious cravings for this place later. Cute little restaurant and friendly staff. The broth they use is seriously amazing! I got the standard ramen bowl they had with the fried shallots, no nori (just cause I'm not a fan of seaweed), and it was seriously so delicious! Would definitely recommend!

1952.review:
Tried the Shoryu Ganso Tonkotsu and though it was alright. The broth has flavor, but felt like it was watery. I am comparing it to the ramen I had in California which was pretty flavorful. The ramen noodle itself wasn't anything to right about.
However, I also tried their Shoryu buns and I would recommend it to anyone who goes there. The meat is pretty tender and flavorful. 
Having only been there once, I would give this place another try. Maybe the chef was having a bad day.

1953.review: Winter ramen.  Soup is good, prices anywhere from 10 to 20 pounds. Not so busy, so service alright.  No cockroaches on my food.  I'm not crazy about ramen but enjoy them from time to time.

1954.review:
Overall a good meal.  But the whitebait just wasn't good.
The wagyu buns were large and fluffy compared to others, but were filled with tasty beef and melted in your mouth.  
The Piri piri Tonkotsu ramen was good.  Lots of flavor with a beautiful egg and a nice kick.  
The gyoza was nicely done with a crunchy lace in the bottom of the skillet.
The whitebait was fishy though.  Didn't taste very fresh.  Didn't finish these.

1955.review: Pretty good ramen by London standards, can be a little salty, but if you're in the area, is always a good choice for a bite of Japanese. Take note that queues can be long, so be prepared for a wait. I tried the black garlic ramen, which was unique and left me warm and happy. The space can be a little cramped due to the huge number of people they have, so the point is - eat fast and get the hell out of there, and reflect on how tasty it was after you leave. Worth a try for sure.

1956.review: If you like spicy food, don't listen to the waitress warnings. Specialty cocktails were good but the ramen stole the show

1957.review:
I enjoyed my Shoryu Tonkatsu ramen but personally I prefer the Bone Daddie Tonkatsu ramen more. I found the ramen here to be very good, with generous serving portion, more toppings and equally satisfying, however, I still pick BD tonkatsu over it. My reasoning behind it is that I felt that the broths (both pork and chicken) there were much tastier and with more intense flavour.
As for the service here, my experience with Shoryu was as good as our service in BD. I had no complaints. Overall, Shoryu was good but my taste buds seek the BD flavour.

1958.review:
This ramen is clearly geared towards the western palate.  If you're looking for authentic Japanese ramen, this isn't really it.  It is still good though.  
We did have an unfortunate thing happen when we went; my friend's phone was stolen while we were eating there.  Keep an eye on your things while you're there!

1959.review:
Very good ramen place. 
We had the spicy ramen (#4) and normal (#1). Topped off with frozen Kirin (draft beer topped with frozen foam made from beer -- so it keeps it colder longer without diluting the beer when it melts). 
I added fresh pressed garlic (sorry to my darling wife). 
Although the ramen was very tasty, the presentation isn't to be overlooked. From the bowl and wooden ladle to the layout of the ingredients on top (half an egg, thin slices of pork, chopped onions, etc). 
Perfect after freezing our fingers and toes off for an hour+ watching the changing of the guards at Buckingham Palace.

1960.review: This place has the best buns I've ever tasted and Monday 2-4-1 is a steal. The ramen is top too. If you're in town you just visit

1961.review: The ramen was wonderful. Ordered a signature ramen. Besides the ramen, I ordered a pork bun too. However, it came out a little disappointing, as the bun is cut into halves instead of folded, like how it was supposed to be. There was also some mayonnaise used in the pork bun, which to me, was a bad idea to a cuisine like this. When it was served, the bun was a little cold, indicating that it was not freshly steamed. On the other hand, the broth to the ramen was just nice! Perfect! And I like how we get to choose the tenderness of the noodle. Overall, the ramen is good, and the ambience is perfect since the server tries to use Japanese but I would avoid the pork bun.

1962.review:
This is just a review of the veggie ramen - I've heard excellent things about the non-veg but haven't tried it.
The veggie ramen is wholesome and satisfying - exactly what you want on a cold day. It's a little bit bland, which is why I recommend getting it with the chilli sauce, but with that addition it's delicious.

1963.review:
A comedy of bad service. Don't buy the wine. They served probably the worst expensive Chablis I have ever had. They also failed to have almost any of the gluten free items on the menu. 
Finally they did not deliver one main. It was my main and I can't review the food because after a long wait I didn't eat. 
Dead loss.

1964.review: Surprisingly, I enjoyed their ramen much more than the ones I've had back home in Las Vegas. The broth, noodles, and toppings...delicious from the beginning to the end. The only negative thing I have to say about this place is their price. £11 or around $17 for a bowl of ramen when I'm used to paying $7 in Vegas.

1965.review: Excellent service from start to finish -fantastic Ramen and to top it off a frosty draft beer...couldn't of asked for better! whenever I'm in London I will be back.

1966.review: Very good place! We got the prawn tempura and it was great! And we got the mushroom appetizer and it was good too! The ramen was also very nice- the broth was not as rice as my ramen place in santa clara buutt it was good. I thought it was a little weird that they didnt have corn as an option to add to the ramen but oh well.. come for the music, stay for the ramen!

1967.review:
We were extremely impressed with the Tonketsu ramen.We added some Japanese chili powder to our noodle.Wow.we thought the Ramen scene in London has come of age.
Then the MSG induced dry mouth came.OH OH.
Tonketsu with MSG!!!!!!

1968.review:
Good Ramen, and the buns are great too
Gyoza was amazing, didn't think gyoza can be that good

1969.review: It's a chain restaurant that can be found mostly in central London. The ramen here is consistently good. The bao, though, not so much - a tad bit too pricey for the lacklustre flavour and ingredients in the bao itself. Stick with the ramen, and go for the dessert after if you're still hungry (warning: you'll probably be ultra full after their generous servings of ramen!).

1970.review:
Well.. was ok, I guess. In theory Ramen are just a fast food, but nvertheless it's quite difficult to get it right. This place is a quite a gimmick: A blonde greets you at the door with a forced and awkward "irah..shai..ma..sei?", hits an embarrassing Japanese drum, and shows you to your table.. the broth is quite boring.. neither memorable, nor worth writing much more about.. ok overall. 
(oh, on the way out they hit the drum again.. I have probably eaten at 500 different restaurants in Japan, and never seen this before)

1971.review: Good ramen. I had the dracula ramen (with lots of garlic). Really good for a cold night.

1972.review: Delicious broth, especially On a grey, drizzly day. The noodle texture is not my fave- too thin, but overall a delicious bowl of ramen. Wonderful service- very friendly and attentive

1973.review: Nice food, good costumer service. The ramen was well served, well condiment. The spice plate was hot but not excessive

1974.review:
Will this Ramen blow your mind... not quite. 
Shoryu, either this one, or the one on the other side of Picadilly Circus, is nice for a quick stop. It's always busy -  in my option this may have more to do with the lack of alternative choices in the area vs. the quality of the food.. 
I've not found better contenders in London, but compared to other cities, the ramen leaves something to be desired. 
Avoid the green tea mochi! 4.50 for one small piece that we didn't finish because it tasted bad :/

1975.review: One of the best ramens I've tasted outside of Japan. Great selections and the broth is divine. Very friendly, quick staff. There are sharing tables so if you come alone or even with just a few friends, you may be sharing a big table. I went by myself and sat next to an interesting group. I haven't tried the sushi here, but when the ramen is so good, you don't really need not. Price is pretty decent.

1976.review: Solid flavor, but not enough noodles. (I got thick; those with thin noodles seemed to have larger portions). I also ordered a beer that didn't come until I was halfway through my meal and water that never came. Really expensive, but that's probably because I'm an American who isn't used to the pound.

1977.review:
31/3/14
Okay.......... Was thinking to change this to 4 stars or not after finish eating my bowl of noodle while waiting for my add on side order hakata roll to come.
Reason to add a star:
1. Ramen still as yummy. I ordered hakata tantan ramen. Nice n spicy. Still loving their chicken kara age.
2. They change their table n chair to proper table!!
Reason on holding back:
1. Table was quite oily and sticky. the stuff that I taking up from the table keep sticking on table which make me think about the hygiene of this consider still new ramen shop.
2. Our sushi didn't come after 20min...... Ask for a waiter to check if they did place the order if they didn't then is ok we ready to pay. He went to check n come back telling us ok Cancelled now!! -_-!!
Okay....... 
2013
Have been looking for an authentic japanese ramen shop for quite some time. Heard bout this restaurant for quite some time and finally we get to try it.
When there around 8pm on a weekday with my friend. No queue. Got seated once we were there. Their table and chair seems to be slightly lower. The chair is like those low bar chair kind.......Not comfortable type. Clearly they do not want their customer to be too comfortable and stay too long in their restaurant.
The day we went we they were giving out free sake for customer. I ordered their house special bone soup roast pork ramen (I think it call tongkotsu). It was yummy. I like it.  We also order 2 sides fried chicken and the green bean edamame. They serve the bean with brown colour rock salt which make it look special. They do give a free side which is vinegar cabbage.
Would give a 4 stars if they have more spacious space and comfy seating for  what the price they are charging their customer.

1978.review: Very bad ramen. Very disapointing. The burger was beautifuk but it felt like eating a small burger at mcdonald. Pretty fade taste. wouldnt come back unless  it is for a quick lunch and there is nothing else open...

1979.review:
This has to be one of the best ramen that I've tasted in London.  I actually took a friend here that lived in Japan for 3 years and they gave it their stamp of approval, being the best ramen that they'd tasted outside of Japan and that it was very authentic.
The portions are a good size and you can ask for an extra serving of noodles if needed.  I've never needed to have extra noodles as the portions are pretty filling and the prices are reasonable for what you get.

1980.review: This lovely Japanese style place is perfect for a dinner for two or more. The ramen is very tasty and the portion is very big. We also took a "bun", something like a steamed bread sandwich stuffed with fried chicken, lettuce and two different sauces. The staff is very friendly and able to give you a lot of tips about the dishes. I'll be back soon.

1981.review: Love this place! Ordered their ramen special with pork belly, and steamed bbq pork buns. Absolutely DELISH, and made to feel very welcome!

1982.review: I had the best ramen experience in London. Small cozy place with nice friendly atmosphere. I ordered hirata bun with pork (which is absolutely amazing, must try) and spicy noodle (which was absolutely amazing as well). Highly recommended

1983.review: Best ramen I've had in London. It gets busy though, so be prepared to queue. The steam buns are ok, but not the best I've had. My friend was disappointed they took off the salmon buns from the menu. She loved them.

1984.review:
This place is always busy and I definitely wasn't dissapointed once I had jostled for the last reminaing seat!
I had the natural tonkotsu and my boyfriend had the iced chicken wings and pork buns, which he loved.
The dumplings were a little on the dry side unfortunately but everything else was great.

1985.review: Not bad for local standard, but lacks authenticity.  Soup base should be richer, the noodle is a bit too soggy for ramen gurus.

1986.review: Got to finally try this place out. Waited around 10mins to be seated during the lunch time hours. Ordered the Shoryu Ramen, and have to say I was impressed. Very good flavor broth and the veg was very good and the meat was cooked spot on. I pretty much gobbled up all of it and the egg was cooked perfectly. Obviously not as amazing as the Ramen I have in Los Angeles, but for London I was very happy with it. Definitely recommend this place for anyone craving Ramen around London.

1987.review: Perfect place to be when its cold and wet outside. Ended up getting a spicy ramen which was incredible. Broth wasn't overpowered by the spice. We also got some bao/buns to share. Chicken came with an amazing sauce, the pork was maybe a little too fatty for my liking. (Visit - 27/05/2014 Dinner)

1988.review: Easily my favorite meal I've had in London. I thought about going back and definitely would have, but I wanted to try other places. I had to Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu which was fantastic.

1989.review: Excellent ramen. The gyoza (potsticker) is very good as well. Service exceeds expectation for a lunch spot. We would return.

1990.review: lovely place. the waitress explains all the different types of ramen soup. the kotteri Hakkatan tonkotsu is to die for

1991.review: There are queues everywhere in London, but this one wasn't so bad when we arrived around 5:30pm on a Saturday (10 mins wait), and definitely worth it! This was my first real ramen house experience, so I got the tonkotsu regular - it was flavorful with an egg, veggies but only about three slices of pork. I had a taste of the spicy tonkotsu broth, and it's a little more flavorful only if you can handle the heat!! We also didn't have to wait very long for the soup to come, which was convenient. The ambiance is charming and modern, and the servers were attentive, but since this restaurant is quite small and pretty busy, we decided against overstaying our welcome. Recommended if you're near Piccadilly Circus.

1992.review: This place is in the heart of the shopping district in London. After walking around in the cold throughout the day, my gf and I wanted something warm and came across this place. The service and location are exceptional, albeit a very touristy location. Obviously, I gravitated towards this location because all tourists get sucked into the "tourist epicenter" of any city. The food is good but not great (meat quality in the buns is not good) and definitely not worth the price. I understand rent is very expensive in this area and the high costs definitely pass down to the food. However, I was still disappointed with the quality of food based on the price. After paying for the meal, I thought about selling my semen to a sperm bank to help offset the cost of this meal. I eventually decided not to do it because I didn't want my biological kids trying to find me 30 years later during their "finding myself stage" to figure out what genetic similarities we shared. At the end of the day, I thought about semen for money for ramen. End of story. End of review. I didn't do it. I'm out.

1993.review: I give this 5 stars because it was just amazing. The menu had so many options and was super nutritious (even had multiple gluten-free options!) I tried the Hirata Bun first which was a rice bun with pork, lettuce, and an amazing sauce. The bun was so soft and the pork was really great. The service for the food was perfect, nice and fast. The standard origin Ramen I got after the Hirata bun was delicious!

1994.review: Yummy! One star off because there was no healthy options. We got a bottle of rose and the buns with chicken karaage (deep fried). Then moved on to the chicken ramen which was better than the ramen I've had in the Bay Area even. Milky, flavourful and satisfying.  Again I wish they have grilled chicken so I could keep my diet but so yummy sometimes so worth it !

1995.review: All their gluten free options were delicious - I could even eat shoryu buns again! Great for tourists and residents alike. It does seem to get crowded around peak times though.

1996.review:
First sip was somewhat bland but after it felt a lot more creamy and flavourful for a tonkotsu ramen.
Disagree with the Hirata Buns. Meat one was sub par compared to the many different buns offered using a japanese fusion take on things. The veggie one was different and actually special which pleased my vegetarian date.
Overall not too bad. Probably rare to find this type of cuisine in Europe but plenty of better ones in California and Toronto.

1997.review: I came here on a rainy weekday at 5:30pm for linner and it was very empty. I guess everyone's off to the pubs at this time of the day. I decided to order the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu (minced pork) for a change and my friend ordered the Kotteri Hakata Tonkotsu. After tasting my Karaka Tan Tan, the Kotteri Hakata tasted rather bland. The sous vide egg was pretty good. But I'd have to give it to Shoryu for having the best broth compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. The broth was spicy, thick, and flavorful. Same goes for the noodles, the best compared to Bone Daddies and Kanada-Ya. I still much prefer thick ramen noodles though. It seems to me that thick ramen noodles are nonexistent in London. Overall great service and tasty ramen. A must try!

1998.review: Super delicious ramen, authentic, with some frills. Beautiful decor with the mirrored bar shelves. Close to the craziness of Piccadilly circus but a nice respite from crowds and loud children. Much better than ethnic restaurants in the surrounding area and better than any restaurant in Chinatown!

1999.review: Excellent ramen. If you are looking for a bit of flavor in London, this is the place. The service is slow, though. Also, beware that there are ABSOLUTELY no substitutions. We could not even get a plate of sliced plain cucumbers (cucumber salad was on the menu). That was fairly ridiculous.

2000.review: Shoryu was a top place to go on a chilly summer night. The ramen was pretty good. The noodles seemed a bit undercooked and the broth was so-so, but the egg was one of the best things I've ever tasted. Would come back next time I'm in London.

2001.review:
I went back on got over my ramen envy from last time and got a shoryu ramen. I will die a happy girl. 
The egg wasn't as good as last time, but I'm not sure if that whole raw food thing scared the shit out of London eateries. But egg aside, we also ordered some cocktails, initially ordered a lemongrass one, but they made the wrong one and gave me a shochu sours. But everything has a bright side. SHOCHU SOURS FOR LYF. 
Yes. It was that good.

2002.review: My first visited the one near canary street and the best Ramen I ever had, then went to the one in Soho couple week later..not really feel the same at all, may be different Ramen I ordered.

2003.review:
"Irasshaimase!". Immediately as you enter, you're greeted with a boisterous traditional Japanese welcome. It pretty much sets the tone that you're in for something authentic. Its run by the same people as the Japan Centre across the road. If the Japanese shop there, they'll probably be eating here, so you won't be disappointed.
We ordered the Shoryu Tonkotsu and the Piri Piri Tonkotsu (which had just the right spicy kick). Both had pickled white ginger in it ...great for sushi, but too over-powering for soup noodles. It was shoved out the bowl and piled high on the complementary pickled red cabbage starter dish. We accompanied our meal with a side order of soft shell crab instead of the more traditional gyoza.
On our waiter's recommendation, we finished the meal with the sponge cake (not on the menu). It was light and filled with fresh cream, and topped off with a macha sprinkling.
Overall, a great eating experience for pre-movies or pre-theatre dining. I'd give it 5-stars, but that's reserved for Daikokuya in LA's Japan Town.
yelp.co.uk/biz/daikokuya…

2004.review: The vegan white natural soup was amazing. I've tried many vegetarian ramens and this was by far the best tasting broth I have ever had. It's a pity I discovered it on my second to last day in London.

2005.review:
We didn't even try the food but the service was horrible. We walked in and it was packed. I stood in front of the door and I probably eyed every waitstaff there and didn't get an acknowledgment.  I didn't get asked for how many until a min later. The wait was about 10mins which was fine... I see it was busy. Then another table of 4 came in and they knew one of the workers there... And the guy started to look for a table for them. In short we were overlooked and our table was given to someone else. We weren't too happy about that, so we left. 
Doesn't matter who your customer know or not know you shouldn't be seating someone ahead of customers who came first when there is a table for them.

2006.review:
I have become a fairly regular customer at the Denman Street Shoryu and this was my first trip to the 'other' Shoryu Ramen. 
I can happily say that the food is just as good here. The ambience is the same as well. 
I had a cold ramen - the chef's special something, it was - and it came with the Ramen on a straw mat with ice below it. Very visually appealing and definitely worth the 12 pounds-ish that I paid for it. 
The seating is a bit close together and it can be uncomfortable if you are here to have some intimate conversation. Of course, its not a problem if you can talk in a few different languages (Hindi, Malayalam, English) according to the people sitting around you - making sure that your privacy is maintained. Haha.

2007.review: A short walk from Piccadilly Circus, you'll find a cozy little ramen shop that serves up hot noodles, broth and tea. As a first timer, I took the safe route and picked the popular Karaka Miso Buta Tonkatsu Ramen (9.90), and although there was a tiny mix up with our orders, it got to us eventually, and still in quick fashion. I must say I was quite pleased with my selection... the broth was tasty, not too heavy, and the portion size was just right. Another treat was the Genmai Tea, I couldn't stop drinking it, it was so good! Oh yeah, get the gyoza. There's nothing ever really special about gyoza, but it's always good. Service was quick and attentive and they even gave us coupons for next time. Need something hot to warm up on these cold winter days? Ramen might just hit the spot.

2008.review: Great service, amazing food...get the dumplings (guitar) and the shoryu buns and have fun beyond that...such a cool place

2009.review:
Having tried the other recent Ramen places that have popped up in London, I thought I'd give this place the chance.... Now I know it's all personal preference but this place wasn't for me. To be fair I went for the signature  tonkatsu (as I have in all the others) all the ingredients were there and the noodles were good, however the soup just was a little salty and bland. We accompanied the Ramen with steamed pork buns that were very good though!! 
The layout of the restaurant is a little bit awkward also, the entrance door inconveniences at least two tables and if you need to use the only toilet then you will again have to disturb people.
Overall, fairly good and slightly cheaper than the rest but defiantly trailing  the others in my opinion.

2010.review: I've become a regular here since I first came 2 years ago. It's one of our go to restaurants when we're in central London (which is almost daily). It's always busy but we rarely have to wait for a seat for more than 10mins - service is fast and food is always amazing. I'd say this is my favourite ramen place above others such as Bone Daddies, Koya or Tonkotsu. I think the broth and noodle have the best texture/consistency/flavour out of them all! We also go to the Shoryu in King Street but this is still my favourite one.

2011.review:
So much ramen, so little time. And you need time if you want to go to Shoryu as the line is quite often 10-15 people long on any given evening. We went on the soft-opening week which meant the line was even longer although props to the staff for shoving us in as fast as possible and having no qualms about asking random people to sit together.  However, I didn't quite understand why they split the group up when the table the first pair was given was more than enough for all of us. We swapped the randoms for our friends and everyone was happy (except for the waitress who looked like she was about to punch a hole in the wall).
The Ramen itself was good (I chose the Shoryu Special) with a rich creamy white broth that was an excellent argument on its own for taking the slow boil method for making tonkotsu stock. The pork itself wasn't that flavourful and I remember being a little disappointed in the low amount of veggies. Those that were there were excellent and so was the egg. The bowl is a massive serving and I happily slurped my way into fatty pork nirvana.
It's a bit cramped inside with the planners seemingly hell bent on working out how to maximise the number of people per square meter. Be prepared to get close to some strangers and even cosier with your friends. Then again, we all survive the tube in rush hour so by comparison this is downright luxurious! 
In the London Ramen rankings, the overall food is good but not enough to dethrone Bone Daddies as the London Ramen King!

2012.review: solid ramen place. Not the best ramen i have had but not the worst. the service is pretty good. solid place if you are in central and want ramen.

2013.review: A die hard fan of ramen, I can safely say that ShorYu's ramen will not disappoint. Eggs could have been done better, but the broth was delicious!

2014.review:
And so continues my ramen quest!  I just moved here, and I'm on a mission to find my favorite ramen restaurant in London.  So far nothing makes me want to strip naked and jump inside the hot vat of soupy goodness, ecstatically yelling YES as I beat two slices of pickled turnips together in excitement.
Shoryu was half full by the time I got there at 7 pm, but packed by the time I left at 8.  I was seated quickly, and ordered the £9.9 Takana Tonkotsu with a £3 side of menma and £1.5 of egg, as well as the £6 shishito peppers.  Nice but quite expensive additions.  5 minutes later (I do appreciate the fast service here, way faster than Bone Daddy's), I had a hot steaming bowl of ramen.  They're not stingy with the portion either.
The noodles were al dente and the broth was certainly flavorful, but missing the fattiness that I prefer.  In fact, it was a bit watery. I preferred the pork at BD as it was softer and fattier.  
Update: I came here again, and ordered the Wasabi Tonkotsu and Karaka Miso Buta Tonkotsu.  Loved the Buta Tonkotsu, there were tons of ground pork in it and the noodles were perfect!  Couldn't really taste much of the wasabi in the other tonkotsu, definitely preferred the Buta.

2015.review:
IMO, far and away the best ramen in London (after Shoryu, of the places I've been I'd rank them Tonkotsu, Ittenbari, Bone Daddies, Yugo, Mitsukoshi). Good noodles, egg is of the perfect doneness, and the tonkotsu broth is fantastic, very balanced.
My personal favorite (and supposedly the favorite of the staff) is the Karaka Tantan Tonkotsu, spicier and with garlic.
I'm from the San Francisco Bay Area and I'd say Shoryu is similar in quality to Ramen Dojo there, and also similar in that they both have spicy ramen. Personally, I don't think anywhere else in London comes close.

2016.review:
Had a great bowl of Ramen hear a couple days back. Was really craving some good quality ramen after all the cold and the rain this week in London. I came on a weekday afternoon around 4pm, it was pretty empty at that time and I was seated immediately.
I ordered the special Hakata Tonkotsu ramen with spicy ground pork. It was very rich and flavorful. I could really taste the good quality of each of the ingredients, and then broth had a very unique taste compared to other ramen broths I've had.
Service and ambiance were good, no complaints as I did come at an off peak time.
I would recommend this place for good quality, flavorful ramen!

2017.review:
The key to a great ramen is the broth. The broth here is great, therefore the ramen is great.
I had the char siu ramen - the original ramen plus extra pork, and my wife had the Dracula ramen, which had caramelised garlic. I got to try her broth at the end: it was garlicky indeed, but still very nice. Noodles were cooked just right and the pork slices were nice. As you would expect, mine had a lot of pork slices which were a treat. An unusual element was the pickled ginger. It's a surprise when you eat it, but makes for a good occasional contrast to the rest of the ramen.
We got our usual sides of karaage chicken and gyoza. The gyoza came with a nice ginger dipping sauce. The karaage chicken was made from chicken breast, which was ok but I have noticed that the thigh meat has more flavour and is juicier.
We got an Asahi each too. They came with a half pint glass of the sort you would find in an English pub, which I liked.
Our total bill came to £48 with service.  This is about average or just under for the ramen places that we have visited in London. I would come back here, but probably just for the ramen.
The place is an easy walk, just down the hill, from Picadilly tube station.  There was a small queue outside when we got there at around 6:30pm and this grew during the evening.  This is something to bear in mind - however, ramen appears to be one of the trendy things at the moment, so most good ramen places would be like this.

2018.review:
If you're wondering about that wasabi tonkotsu, I too was curious before finally coming here on Sunday.. I had checked out their ramen selection in advance to see what they had to offer compared to the other ramen joints..and wasabi ramen is definitely a new one for me.
 
So I will start with the con. They have a scoop of pasty wasabi shavings when your bowl is brought out untouched, along with the atypical bean sprouts, earwigs, pork, and two sheets of seaweed (sorry, gotta pay extra for an egg!). The pasty wasabi shaving was not very potent, especially when I mixed it in with my broth. The beauty of wasabi is that spicy zing shooting up one's nose with every bite, and I had imagined every bite of this ramen would do me the same justice; on the contrary, it was very subtle. I have seen broth prepared with wasabi oil to give it a strong kick but this broth is not wasabi flavored and the only thing giving it the wasabi love was the scoop of wasabi bits on top of the noodles. Don't get me wrong, the broth was excellent, very milky and not overtly salty.. but just wasn't what I was expecting when ordering wasabi tonkotsu. While there's no doubt you can make out the faint taste of wasabi, the taste was too repressed for me. Don't lie to yourself and say you've ever gone for wasabi wishing it were only a faint kick! In my opinion, if the depth of wasabi flavor is not there, it really is just another bowl of tonkotsu ramen, with a hint of wasabi. I told the waitress who said she'd convey it to the chef, so maybe there will be a slight change next time?
On the other hand, the ramen had veerry good noodles. I am a big fan of thin straight ramen noodles (as opposed to curly or flat ones). These were straight, firm, and a little chewy, which to me is an example of well-made ramen noodles. It's always easy to make it too soggy and I don't enjoy it when it's bordering that opaque look, but as I said, these were firm chewy tender noodles with great flavor. They were very yellow too, so these were probably made with a higher egg content, giving it that yellow hue and flavor that reminds me of Chinese egg noodles (but with nicer texture). Another pro was that the egg was pretty delicious as well. It's no "dayum..dayum..DAYUM" (see review on Bone Daddies on my usage of the Dayum scale) but still great execution. It was not as runny as I would like it but it wasn't overcooked and you can still see the soft, creamy, orangey glow in the middle. So the main difference was that it wasn't as beautifully runny like Bone Daddies' egg, but to me it was marinated to perfection and not overly salty as Bone Daddies' eggs. The same goes for the pork. They were not overwhelming large slices; in fact, I usually save the pork for the end and when I reached the end, in hindsight, I think I only got one slice total? It was either one slice or one and a half slices. Not the most protein one could wish for but it was tasty. And I was too busy wolfing down my noodles anyways. 
Lastly, Shoryu Ramen doesn't have a bar area for one-person parties (is it a party if there's only one person :( ?). I always think ramen joints should keep with tradition to have single seats, for those who want to sidle in for a quick eat. That's the true beauty of eating ramen like fast-food as they do in Japan! Instead, they have a couple of small tables, and a long booth seat along the wall with small tables to section parties off. Meh, guess I'll just have to find some friends to come with!

2019.review:
It did hit a spot! 
We are visiting London for the first time and found this place. We were so happy because our 4 year old daughter finished her bowl! She likes eating good ramen.

2020.review:
So I was with someone who's been here before and after a rather long debate, this place seemed to be one of the few places that are open late (up to London standards that is). The ambience was nice and the decor as per the usual ramen bar (no Bone Daddies rockability theme here).
The food seemed rather adventurous for a ramen place - an interesting mix of flavours with funky names. 
It did take some time for it to arrive at the table (especially given the fact that everyone was leaving by the time we got there).Anyway, pretty good food, matching that generally offered in London. I've ordered the Tokyo Shoryu.  The broth was fine, the noodles tasted rather good and he toppings were OK, just your typical japanese inspired out-of-the-tin vegetables with meat. Soft shell crab was rather soggy, but I wasn't expecting any miracles here.
What was excruciatingly horrible was the service. 
Yes, we turned up late and our food was late. However when I discovered a hair in my food I got extremely upset by the fact that no one had the courage to come to me and apologise/offer a refund as they usually do in such places. I hadn't touched more than half of my food and no response - extremely unprofessional and definitely not what one would expect from such a central London location. 
I saw the floor manager who was only able to offer an apology and had the service charge taken - something that I found rather disrespectful for both the staff and I as the service was generally good.
I don't know if I'd go back - possibly I'd try the other branch but this place needs to invest more on customer care.

2021.review: Pretty good food.  Looks nice and clean.  I wish there was a bit more variety in the ingredients and types of meats.  I'd probably go there again, primarily because there's a lack of good restaurants in this part of town.

2022.review: The best ramen shop in all of Europe! Proper-est!! The noodle and the soup are authentic and good. But my ramen was served rather lukewarm. :(

2023.review:
Hot bowl of ramen = Perfect remedy for a freezing cold London day! 
Had to queue outside for about a half hour to get a table for two, but that was expected and so worth it. Something that stood out to me and I just have to mention it, is that they have a heat lamp for all of us eager ramen-craving freezing patrons right outside of the entrance. How thoughtful :) 
We started with the pork belly hirata buns. The bread was fluffy and the meat was tender, delicious. A little bit of spiciness, which was unexpected but tolerable enough for a spice-wimp like me. Then came the main event. I had the Tokyo Shoyu and it was amazing. The broth was full of flavour and the pork, veggies & noodles were all delectable. The portion was enormous and I was fully stuffed and satisfied at the end of the meal. Great place!

2024.review:
Stopped in with my mom after reading other reviews.  We were seated quickly and were told about the menu and their specialties. We weren't planning on getting any buns, but it happened to be 2-for-1 bun night. We ordered two bowls of ramen and two pork belly buns. 
The ramen came out hot and flavorful, very large portions. The buns were a good size and very good. If we ever visit London again, I would definitely come back and I would order more buns and share a bowl of ramen.

2025.review:
The Takana was pretty amazing! Our Japanese entourage concurred the noodles were legit and the gyoza were pretty amazing as well. It's a small little shop in one of the busiest spots of London, which means you might hit a queue. I was pretty lucky at noon on a weekend and we only waited about 10 min but by the time we left, the wait looked considerably longer. 
There seems to be a lot of ramen popping up around town, if you're on the hunt to compare, put Shoryu on your shortlist.

2026.review:
Came up to London to fulfill some Japanese Ramen cravings with my friends. Totally worth the 1.5-2 hours for our trip. I asked what the most popular dish was and the waitress told me the Karaka Tan Tan Tonkotsu. I absolutely LOVED it! At first I was confused on why I didn't have any Chashyu, and then I realized that I had gotten "pan fried minced pork" this was so much more delicious than the chashyu (pork slices). The meat was very juicy, a little bit too salty, but I liked it that way. There was a good portion of noodles and the bowl was quite large. I also liked the spicyness of the ramen dish!
If I lived in London, I would eat here as often as I could! I think the price is very reasonable and there are a bunch of side dishes that you can get as well. The place was quite upscale looking and super clean!

2027.review:
Dinner
Went there with my cousin and her boy friend. In total it costed £40 for three of us. Therefore i shouldn't be so judge mental? However, ramen in Japan is a serious topic, can be the theme for life. 
I think it could earn four stars as the quality of food was great overall, but the bean sprout tasted old, kinda sourly almost people from FSA will question about its freshness. Shame.
Maybe it's one off.
Thus highly recommended for a casual dinner.

2028.review: Most amazing ramen! We eat ramen in New York often and this is even better. We went multiple times on our short trip. LOVE!

2029.review:
I am a ramen-freak. It's what I crave when I am happy, sad, stressed, or celebrating. Shoryu satisfies all my cravings and it amazing!
Coming from New York, I have a pretty high standard for ramen (at least I would like to think so), so once I moved here, I had to find here I could feast on delicious pork belly and noodles. After reading a bunch of reviews I tried a few places out, and so far Shoryu is my favorite. I've been back a few times since finding it too. Each time I come hungry because the bowls are massive! And of course I have to save room for the fantastic hirata pork buns!
The place is relatively small and cramped, but that's London for small restaurants. It is still very nice and the atmosphere is great. Servers greet you when you come in and the servers are always nice and efficient. 
If you need a dose of ramen in your life check this place out. I have gone with native Chinese and Japanese friends and they give their stamp of approval too! 
The broth is always salty and deliciously umami-like, the meet is tender, and the noodles don't lose their sogginess after ten minutes in the bowl, which is nice. 
Go, feast, enjoy, return.

2030.review:
I am a devoted Ramen fan who spent years in Japan actively seeking the perfect bowl of noodles.  I even took it so far as collecting business cards from all the shops and making a binder with notes on each.  Of course, you have to judge Ramen outside Japan with a slightly relaxed standard, because it's hard to replicate the full environment.
That said, Shoryu is a solid bowl of noodles.  Tonkotsu is my favorite variety of Ramen, and these guys get it right.  The soup is thick and fragrant and the noodles have the right amount of chewiness.  I only go to London a few times per year, but Shoryu is definitely on my must-go list from now on.

2031.review:
This is one of those places in London that satisfies my ramen craving. Love love loooove.
When I first entered the restaurant, gongs were sounded based by the number of people you have in your party. *so honoured* Then we were sat, and a complimentary small saucer filled with cold yet crunchy cabbage(?) is served. 
For my first time here I ordered the Dracula ramen. It is one of the newer food options and it's delicious! Definitely gives you garlic breath after to ward off the vampires later on, but who cares? Great food requires great sacrifices. 
Second time was Yuzu ramen for me. Might feel weird at first glance because yuzu is a citrus fruit, but when mixed with the salty tonkotsu base, it is actually something quite sensational. Not one of my favourites, but my impression of Shoryu is still higher than ever. 
Love the ambience here as well - although everyone is sat pretty close, it's not too noisy and the lighting and overall decoration and furniture makes it a good mix of classy and cosy. 
The service here is amazing - I can tell that they try to emulate the Japanese service here, and that makes it so welcoming to me. 
Price-wise is reasonable in comparison to other ramen restaurants in London. Shoryu definitely wins in the value-for-money department. 
Will come back again and again and again. I'll never be bored of ramen.

2032.review: This is a fantastic, traditional ramen place with reasonable pieces and good drinks. I've been to Japan 40 times and j would come back here in a heartbeat.

2033.review: Ordered two ramen n a black sesame tofu. I'm in love with the tofu but not a ramen fan sorry. The dining place is a bit small. We feel lucky to have a friendly n fast service thank you

2034.review: Well isn't this place an absolute delight! Ramen is pretty much tailor made for miserable London winters and as the days get progressively greyer and grimmer, I'll be making a beeline for Shoryu. You should too. The noodles are fresh and bountiful (perhaps a little too bountiful but there are worse problems to have, hey), the broth rich and flavoursome and the meat and veggies seasoned to perfection. The gyoza is also pretty great, but there's no way you'll have space for it after the ramen. Honestly, if I didn't you won't. On top of this, the setup is really nice and cosy and does away with the canteen style feel that often comes with ramen spots. I'll be back.

2035.review: Im still looking for any sort of flavor in the vegetarian ramen (am i asking for the moon?!)

2036.review: Love my asian soups and especially Ramen.  Wow did this place impress and surpass my favorite NYC ramen places.   Aside from the impeccably authentic ramen with velvet noodles and broth, the side orders were also exceptional (pork belly buns were unbelievably fluffy, the gyoza was rediculously crisp, shrimp tempura was light and crispy and my kids devoured the tempura Brussels sprouts).   This place is the real deal and a must stop for Ramen lovers.

2037.review: Amazing Ramen place! A bit crowded but service was reasonable. We had two different kinds of ramen and buns. Buns were a great surprise. The ramen was served at perfect temperature and was really tasty. The wife had never had ramen and doesn't eat much soup but was really excited afterwards and ready to go back on our next trip!

2038.review: This is a chain in the city but the ramen is great. We were glad we got their early as by 6:30 there was a line outside. Great place for a casual and quick meal. So good we are here twice on our trip!

2039.review: Excellent ramen.  Good service.  Kirin Ichiban on tap.  A little pricey and a little cramped.

2040.review: The broth was rich and tasty! The noodles were cooked perfectly - not too soft, not too hard! We only waited for about 20 mins or so on a Saturday night so that wasn't too bad. Service was alright and we can't wait to go back again~!

2041.review:
I'm really disappointed at the quality of this restaurant. I ordered a Karaage and Shoryu Ramen .Karaage was good but the Ramen did not have much of a taste.  the noodle was not japanese one it maybe Chainese noodle ??.......it was too soft noodle.
I will try ohter Ramen shop .........

2042.review: I would have given it 4 stars. The service was very polite and nice but inattentive. I waited forever to place an order, and waited forever to get attention to get the dessert menu, and almost knocked the waitress serving the next table over, actually she almost knocked me over, as I was trying to leave.  Food was pretty good. Ramen soup (tonkutso) was excellent, and yummily garnished. I had the matcha ramen and was good. succulent texture. Hirata bun was oversized, fluffy and pillowy, and chewy, but there was something indecently inelegant about it. Pork belly was ok - doesn't quite melt in your mouth and of course you couldnt go wrong with the mayo. Mmmm. I also tried the gluten free hirata bun and they microwaved it!! So the ends ended up being very hard. But where I could chew it was actually tasty and the texture quite good - not as soft and pillowy but decent and tasty! If you are going for the gf hirata buns (which only comes in chicken), ask them not to microwave but to steam it.  The matcha tea was absolutely disappointing. It said stoneground in restaurant but it was hardly tasty - i felt like i was drinking plain water.

2043.review: I was in London on holiday craving some ramen and found this spot listed on a lot of dining lists for top ramen spot in London. I decided to check it out and ordered some standard miso ramen and an order of pork buns. The pork buns came out first and it was not yummy at all! Seems like the pork belly was old and the buns were not soft at all - instead of being nicely steamed it tasted and looked like frozen microwaved pork buns. The ramen was underwhelming as well. The eggs were not cooked how I liked (yokey yellow and brown soy sauce soaked). The noodles were ok, I've had much better. The noodles tasted like they were sitting out in room temperature for too long. The broth was very watered down. I was so upset after reading good reviews about this place and left 80% of my order untouched.

2044.review: Disappointing, both relative to other ramen restaurants in London and as an experience in and of itself. I found my main dish average (though for full disclosure, I ate the Tori Kara-Age Men which is not made with their famous pork broth) and the surrounding dishes (with the exception of a delicious Chicken Bun) unexciting. The sashimi sampler tasted as if had been sitting out for a while. And the fruit flies that were buzzing around during our meal also didn't help the ambiance... Needless to say, I was expecting more from my meal at Shoryu. And good service from a pleasant and attentive waitstaff could not make up for mediocre food.

2045.review:
I was strolling through Piccadilly Circus area on Sunday on my first day in town on business.  It was about 1230 or so and I got seated quickly.  After looking at several choices, I picked the Tan Tan.  A fantastic silky tonkatsu broth, with nori, egg, scallions, pickled ginger and loads of chili oil :).
As I was finishing I saw a crowd by the window.  I hadn't realized it but the placed filled up to capacity right after me and there were 15 or so people waiting in line!  
It was a very good bowl of ramen and worth the visit!

2046.review:
Let me start by saying I am Japanese, spent the first 18 years of my life there, and have spent the last 25 in New York City, where there is plenty of and an increasing amount of ramen competition, that most ramen connoisseurs would be proud of.  I adore ramen, and am comfortable claiming myself as a connoisseur.
I am not trying to be racist, but there is a non-Japanese manager at Shoryu, who does not understand how ramen is properly consumed.  I ordered the most simple combination of a bowl of ramen and an order of gyoza.  As any seasoned ramen eater knows, each of those dishes are good on their own, but eating them together is what makes the experience whole.  Well  I received my gyoza within 5 minutes of ordering (great), but did not receive my ramen for another half hour (not great).  Given the standard ritual, I of course held off on eating my gyoza until the ramen came, and by then, it was cold, greasy, and to be honest, slimy.
Now the ramen.  The soup (I had the piri piri tonkotsu) was not bad.  The noodles felt and tasted a bit like soba noodles, i.e. too straight, and too hard.  And worst of all, they make the same mistake that so many foreign ramen outposts do - they pile on the vegetables and other stuff, taking away from the taste of the ramen itself, perhaps to fool you into thinking you're getting a good bang for your buck.  True ramen, as most know, shouldn't be adulterated by too much "gu" , so you can let your tastebuds focus on and appreciate the simple noodle and soup combination.
When I complained to said manager about the half hour gap between the gyoza and ramen, she simply said sorry, and quickly stuck another customer in front of me - they make you share tables, so as not to slow down business.  So those of you who feel weird about eating at a small table for two with a perfect stranger sitting eighteen inches in front of you, maybe you should venture elsewhere.  Very different from sitting next to someone at a counter, even though you are just as close.
With very mediocre ramen and horrible service, I will continue to wait for the awesome ramen shop this city so desperately needs.

2047.review: Nothing short of amazing ate here twice while I was in London nobu never lets me down!!!

2048.review:
Our Monday night experience at Nobu was MEH and only made it to A-OK thanks to attentive staff and management. The food alone would NOT have made it to A-OK. 
Going to Nobu for her birthday after the completion of The Championship (aka Wimbledon for folks that are not interested in tennis) is our friend's tradition. So we looked forward some treats. All three of us love sashimi, but for variety, we thought the seasonal tasting menu would be a good idea. Wrong! The tasting menu was MEH at best. I rarely had worse. And it is hard to get less value (£100 per person). The tapas size dishes were generally over-sauced. On the seafood starter plate had salmon, but - in my opinion - salmon doesn't belong on a sushi/sashimi plate (unless you are feeding kids that are afraid of raw seafood). The marinated hamachi was one of the few enjoyable bites. It would have been better without the marinade as I like to taste the ingredients. Do not get me wrong. We all love spice and spicy dishes. I mean extreme spicy as long as the spice doesn't cover the ingredients' taste. Here Nobu generally failed. It got worse with their Wagyu course. No idea where that old cow came from. There was no sign of tender fattiness that Wagyu is famous for. Just pieces that remind one of shoe leather: both in texture and taste (and I am only exaggerating slightly). It was time for a call to management. They actually brought us a replacement dish. A Peruvian  style beef dish that was simmered rather than fried. It wasn't a great dish either, but the cooking method seemed to be more compatible with the beef they offered. The spice - a sauce that tasted a lot like tabasco from a bottle - didn't really agree with beef. The manager said that it is a traditional Peruvian spice. If true, I conclude that I do not like Peruvian spice. 
Frustrated with the food so far, we ordered a few pieces of sashimi and finally Nobu didn't mess up. Mackerel and o-toro were excellent. The scallops might be good for the location, but living in New England spoiled us, and therefore cannot win awards. The razor clams were out. Otherwise, the fish choices seemed pedestrian. Mackerel and o-toro are the winners. 
On the beverage side, I asked about their Daiginjo. Our waitress said that the Daiginjo is very bland and she recommended one of their other dry sakes, Onigoroshi (at half-price). As I was hesitating, she offered to bring us two cups to try. The recommended sake was not bad, but had too many strong flavors with a hint of a bitter, chemical aftertaste. We stuck to the Daiginjo and were very happy after three large carafes for three people. The standard Nobu Daiginjo has a typical, clean, delicate Niigata flavor. Definitely done right! May be too delicate vor the Peruvian side of the restaurant. 
Eventually we made it to dessert, which was pleasant and covered some of the earlier pains. Picture to follow ...

2049.review:
Went for my birthday dinner and loved everything. 
We had the "classic" omakase, which consisted of a good balance across starters, cold dishes, hot dishes and a dessert. Everything was fresh and flavourful, particularly the signature miso cod. 
Ambience was nice and modern, though it did get quite noisy toward later in the evening. I wish it had a bit more of an exclusive and quiet feel to it but otherwise, enjoyed the simple yet posh environment. 
Service was spot on. Our waiter was proactive in explaining the menu and prompt throughout the evening in bringing out drinks and dishes. 
Would most love to return

2050.review:
There once was a place called Nobu.
It was so new it no one knew.
That one day to the next
It would change from the best
To a place filled with rules
So sad that the fun
Left forever
That is the modern Nobu. 
A shadow of its former self.
With twice the assholery.

2051.review:
Came here on a Saturday afternoon just as it opened, and there were plenty of tables available. I had the set lunch menu with 2 apps, 1 main, 1 dessert. For my 2 apps, I got the sashimi selection and tuna tataki; I got the teriyaki for my main, and there was only 1 option for dessert. 
Everything was fine and the service was not bad. It's not worth the price, but then again you don't come here expecting to eat the amount you pay for. I was worried the hosts would be very snobby but that wasn't the case. I'm giving it 3 stars because really the food and service don't stand out; I'm glad I was able to try the infamous Nobu but I probably won't come here again until I start earning my meager accounting salary.

2052.review: Believe the Hype....Exceptional service, exceptional food, LOVED NOBU, cant wait to try another NOBU next time I travel.

2053.review:
Good and solid japanese food.  Consistent with their other locations around the world. I feel if you you been to one, you been to them all. My advice: Try a Nobu that's not in the city you reside in, just for the experience.
We ordered all the usual stuff:
beef tataki
sashimi(uni/toro/hamachi/scallop/abalone/cuttlefish/wagyu/ etc)- very fresh
sashimi salad
rolls - avocado roll and tuna roll (the kids loved them)
salmon avocado hand roll - substantial and bigger than expected
black cod - cooked perfectly
wagyu w/truffle 
Worth it, however there's other places also worth trying.
Lunch menu is good, too.

2054.review:
Great food - consistent with Nobu anywhere in the world. Good service. Good bar selection. Although it would be nice if the bar had high stools, or bistro style tables with high stools. While you're waiting on your table or for the rest of your party, you're practically sitting on the floor on the very low stools, which I didn't love as a tall person.
Also, the signage to the restrooms are slightly lacking. And if you use them on the way out, expect to get lost when you exit on the floor below and have no idea where you are relative to where you entered, unless you're a regular.
Aside from some tuning on the venue, the sushi is good, fresh, tasty, and well plated. It's Nobu - you can't leave feeling too disappointed.

2055.review:
We decided to try walking in for a Saturday night and was fortunate to get a table (2 of us).
Definitely was skeptical due to the loud music and fancy decors, would the food let us down? 
Fortunately the legendary Nobu lived up to the hype. The scallops were fantastic and some of the best we've ever had. Fresh, sweet and all the flavours on the plate complimented each other. Specifically the kelp was a textural and flavourful delight. 
All the sushi we ordered was fresh and very well prepared. Even the pork belly was delicious, with great texture on the skin and flavours coming through the preparation.
The pricing was reflective of the Mayfair location and Nobu fame. Well worth it however for a special time or you wanted to treat yourself.

2056.review:
It isn't really Japanese. Everyone from the wait staff are Eastern European. I doubt they speak Japanese. I could barely understand their English. The food isn't really Japanese, except they use soy-sauce.  Okay food richly decorated.
The salmon tar tar is just soak in plain soy-sauce. Yuck!
It is loud. One cannot carry on a conversation. Every time a customer walks in all the wait staff will yell out something that could almost be confused with a Japanese greeting (いらっしゃいませ). At least they did it with convictions.
I would skip this one if you are look for food instead of an event.

2057.review: The sushi/sashimi at Nobu's is not the freshest and would make the best sushi chefs cry. But, overall, the chain produces a consistently pleasant dining experience, with some signature dishes that people happily go back for: kelp salad, artichoke salad, rock shrimp tempura, miso black cod, chocolate bento, etc.

2058.review: The decor is tacky. Food is good, but I doubt it's worth the price tag. A bit of a disappointment. But it's ok, it was a business lunch and I didn't pay for it personally.

2059.review: Great service. Just what you would expect from Nobu. The tiger prawn tempura is my favourite. Top quality food. We were well looked after. Subtle yet great atmosphere.

2060.review:
I've LOVED Nobu!! I was taken there for my birthday treat and it really was a treat!! 
We arrived on a Tuesday lunchtime so it was fairly quiet and were seated immediately. Prior to entering the restaurant, you can give your coats and bags to the cloakroom and then go up the stairs to the main restaurant. 
When we sat down we were given a choice of still or sparkling water (however I would've just gone with tap but I felt too shy to say at the time) and given a drinks and food menu.
