 2. No tipping! As they don't tip in Japan, any money mistakenly left on the tables is given to a London homeless charity. This hippy-esque approach only serves to increase my newfound love of the place, I'm so happy to report the food was as good as the philosophy behind it.
 So, excellent pricing structures, a smile on arrival and a great location will make Tokyo Diner my next pre-cinema dinner choice.
 Dinner: around £9-15 per person for food and tea.

2303.review:
The best Japanese food I've ever tasted.
The bento box set meals and katsu curry are not to be missed, and try the eda mame if you want to try something new and tasty.
Can get quite busy, but the prices are very good, especially for central London.
If you're ever in the area, and are feeling peckish, be sure to drop in.

2304.review:
For photos please refer to
hungryinlondon.com/2010/…
 
 Ironically in the middle of Chinatown there is Tokyo Diner, a cheap but decent Japanese restaurant. Even though the owner appears to be English (if you agree with me that Richard Hills does not sound terribly Japanese) the place has a distinct Japanese atmosphere to it. I have just been to Japan couple of months ago and Tokyo Diner feels very much like one of the Izakayas I went to in Kobe. I am talking not only about the furnishing and (as far as I can judge it) Japanese waiters but also the fact that, just like in Japan, tips are not taken, that you pay on the counter when you leave and that green tea (I think it was Hojicha) is served free of charge.
 The menu is really weird but at the same time rather entertaining: you can spend ages reading the detailed description about every dish as well as some trivia about Japan and Japanese food. In addition the menu contains 5 whole pages with allergy information regarding the nuts/seeds and gluten content for each individual dish.
 The food only partly lived up to my expectations. I was a bit disappointed actually by the Hoso-MakiI Set (6.20). The rice was too sticky and the salmon didn't taste that fresh. The vegetarian cucumber and pickled radish maki were much better actually but also they did not quite satisfy my palate which has become used to the outstanding quality of sushi in Japan.
 I love all kinds of Japanese noodles and particularly when I am hungover, as I happened to be at this particular occasion, nothing is comparable to the healing powers of a Japanese noodle soup. I chose the Curry Udon with Chicken (8.20) which was a very decent bowl of soup drenched with the rather mild but strangely addictive flavour of Japanese curry. The udon were not quite Koya quality but really not bad at all.
 It is not the best Japanese restaurant I have ever been to but considering how cheap, friendly and uncomplicated it is, it is well worth a visit for a quick pre-theatre bite or for a hangover cure.

2305.review:
Tokyo Diner is everything you could wish for if you're looking for a no-nonsense delicious Japanese eatery, and comes with an elaborate menu and background information on all the (authentic) dishes.
 The vegetable curry udon were juicy and aromatic, the Tofu Katsu Ju, apparently one of the chef's own creations, brings a smile to my face with its crispy breadcumbed tofu and flavoursome miso based sauce and the edamame are nice and fresh. As a vegetarian, or even vegan, you're more than welcome and they mark vegan dishes especially.
 Then there's the free green tea that the friendly staff top up without needing a prod, free large rice portions (ask for an oumori portion), and the refreshing 'no tips' policy, and I'd say it's a winner. Sugoi!
 (PS: Wouldn't necessarily recommend it for a fancy dining experience, but at the prices offered, it's definitely fantastic value for money)

2306.review:
Average.
The sushi menu was limited.  I read a little anecdote on display about how the Japanese will travel across the country (of Japan) for freshly prepared soba noodles.  But, um, the soba noodles I got were so obviously not fresh.  
Is this a dishonest or an ingenious marketing strategy?  I can't decide. 
In any event, Okawari is just down Lisle Street, and it has a bigger sushi menu and lower prices.  If you want a more stereotypically Japanese dining atmosphere, stick with Tokyo Diner.  But you'll get more for your money at Okawari, and that's what counts, I think.

2307.review:
I'm sorry, I just wasn't feeling it. I wanted to like it. God, I wanted to have an awesome meal when I took friends out to thank them for helping me move, but it just didn't happen.
I went with a couple of friends for whom Japanese food is not a specialty and so weren't sure what to order. I gave some advice, but their tastes (ie meat!) are different to mine so they asked the waitress. Very unhelpful. There was just no sense of 'oh try this' or 'if you like that then this is for you'. It was as if she hated being there and was nervous about anyone saying anything that resembled a question and didn't know what to do when it happened.
We ordered edamame to get things started.... which was fine until one of the party found a live maggot crawling over them... ok, so you don't eat the skins, but... just..... no. not for me, thanks. After the earlier 'conversation' with the waitress, we felt at pains to point it out, and we were tired anyway so didn't want to kick up a fuss.
The rest of the food was fine. Nothing spectacular but a good cheap option in a great location, just set back from Charing Cross Road, a minute from Leicester Square station.
I'd like to go and try it again to see if I caught a new girl on a bad night, but I just don't want any more maggots on my food.

2308.review: Simply astonishing! Authentic dishes, might the most delicious food I have ever eaten. The food is just amazing, portions are as big as they come and on top of that there's green tea for free. There is a wide variety of food to chose from for some reasonable prices. Recommended!

2309.review: This restaurant is great it looks so japanese! The sushi was soo good I really love it. The green tea was for free. I cant wait to visit London again and have dinner at Tokyo Diner?

2310.review: Fantastic. Friendly and informal but not in the least bit scruffy- as soon as we sat down we were given a complimentary cup of green tea and rice crackers and our food arrived very quickly. My udon curry was delectable, I've eaten plenty of East Asian food in my time but this was something else: flavoursome and spicy without being too hot and a generous portion to boot. Excellent value for money given the location and drinks are VERY well priced.

2311.review:
Before bentos, katsus, sushi and noodles became ubiquitous in London thanks to the like of Japanese Canteen, Wagamama and Wasabi, there was Tokyo Diner. 
Tucked away in a corner in Chinatown, Tokyo Diner is an authentic Japanese-run restaurant serving unadulterated and homely staples of modern Japanese cuisine including katsu curries, udon noodles, donburi, sushi and bentos. The menu and dishes are straight forward, but the quality here is far superior to that of the aforementioned chains. You will actually see Japanese people eating here, which is always a good sign, as are the tight crowds during the evening rush. 
The food quality here is superior to that which I've seen at 99% of the 'Japanese' diners in London though this is in part reflected in the prices. You can get away with spending under 10 pounds but I often find myself going closer to 15. 
I love the Japanese touches which make the dining experience here particularly welcome and authentic. There is no tipping or automatic service charge, you can request a complimentary large-sized portion of rice if you're extra hungry and the nifty automatic door which is cleverly disguised to look rather old and run down is a nice trick too.

2312.review:
"We do not take tips" 
The above words are what you see first. The food is ok. I had the Mini Una Don ( Grilled Eel served with rice and sauce ) and it was tender and tastes good. 
Don't know why they said "NO" to Tuna but serving eel as both are getting on well are on the endangered list!!! They serve hot tea; which I liked as its aids in digestion. 
The first restaurant I visited in China town. I would recommend food lovers to try it.

2313.review: This is very japanese style restaurant with no tip required. The food is worth the money and there's green tea served unlimited. The atmosphere is very cosy and it's very nice during winter or cold days. Open most of the days and hours, it's definitely a good restaurant for money value and city lives.

2314.review: Having been to Japan I find this the closest to the dining experience there. From the sliding door, great noodles and paying at the desk when you leave. This is as close as your going to get to eating in Tokyo without going there. If you like Japanese food definitely give this a try.

2315.review: Great cheap meals always to be had here! Their portions are very generous and for 10 squid you'd get a full meal. I love their salmon donburi, the freshest salmon sashimi over a bed of rice. You can also ask for more rice free of charge, but the restaurant asks to make sure you are able to finish your meal as to prevent food wastage.

2316.review: This place is quite small and you will probably have to wait if you go during a busy time, but it's worth the wait.  It's got character, lots of maneki neko and decorations from Japan (I want their sushi clock so bad!) and good service.  I had sushi one time and udon noodles another time, and both were very good.

2317.review: Really love this place. best japanese restaurant in london so far. will definitely return when visiting the city again

2318.review: The food here is really good. Traditional Japanese. Really good katsu curry. The only reason it doesn't get a 5 star is the price, though the serving size almost makes up for it.

2319.review: Not bad! I wasn't sure what to expect, but dishes were authentic and good. It's not fair to compare it to Japan, where the ingredients are better quality, but I am glad that a place like this exists, if only because I abhor Wagamama. This is where you can get things like hiya yakko (cold tofu), katsu curry, tsukemono, and una don. Very good value, great hours, and central location.

2320.review: Very good japanese diner. The place is china town in London Soho. The dishes are cheap and cheerful. The servants speaking japanese and english. Awesome ambient. All in all my favorite japanese restaurant in Soho! A good space for discussions of japanese studies.

2321.review:
Maybe it was an off night, but I did not have a very good experience here. It's too bad, I had really heard nice things!
 I went for a chicken and egg stirfry-type dish. The panko was soggy and the egg cold. It just seemed like it had been sitting out for ages.
 My friend had the salmon sashimi which looked a bit better, but he wasn't raving by any means. couple those with one beer and one tea and the bill was nearly £30!
 I would have been ok with half that.
 I'll go back just on the off chance that this was an anomoly, but I was not impressed with Tokyo Diner.

2322.review:
Kind of quirky Japanese restaurant that's really all about the food.  There's no décor worth mentioning, but there's a cozy feel to the place nonetheless
Their Bento boxes are all really fantastic and they have a whole selection... each one comes with sushi and a refreshing seaweed salad.  I always go for the veggie box, but my friend swears by the delectableness of the Katsu chicken box.  I also recommend the edamame here - well-steamed and sufficiently salty.
The staff is always extremely fast and efficient, but the establishment is so popular that it still tends to get crowded fast... I've never waited, but I also usually go at pretty off-times.  
Even though the service is great, in-keeping with Japanese tradition, the servers don't accept tips... however, if you insist, they will donate the money to charity - which I just think is so generous and kindly - a real reflection of this place's vibe and ethos.
This philosophy, which flies in the face of greed, is also reflected in the prices... everything is supremely reasonable... especially for sushi and considering the level of quality you're getting.  It may not be the swankiest sushi joint in London, but it's certainly an all-around delicious and enjoyable place.

2323.review: Not bad for a casual and quick dinner.  We had oyakodon bowls I think.  Pretty good.  They confused our orders at first and I had to wait a while for my order.  It's small in there, but warm and cozy to get out of the cold in Leicester Square.

2324.review: Great food, unpretentious environment in a very convenient location. I recommend this place to people who like Japanese home cooking.

2325.review:
Sushi is my favourite Asian food. I recently found out where I can have the freshest and most delicious Sushi. In middle of Soho, at Newport Place, there is a 2 floor petite Japanese restaurant called the Tokyo diner.
Japanese run the restaurant, the service is attentive when needed and discreet when not. Remarkably for Central London the prices are very reasonable.
On arrival they serve green tea and rice munchies. I strongly can recommend the broccoli, eel and the bento boxes (a selection is made for you already). 
This little gem I recommend to couples or a small group of friends. I keep it as my secret hideaway for me and my best friend to catch up after work every week.

2326.review: Think we stepped on the wrong foot upon entry by asking if this place was Japanese -run. The look on the waiter's face was priceless as he said, "Yes, I'm Japanese is there a problem with that"? Personally, I only eat sushi from Japanese places. Just like I wouldn't go to a Muslim joint to order pork, I don't eat Chinese sushi. Anyway I had the unagi set and then a salmon set after. I wasn't sure if the waiter was going to put some extra unwanted ingredients on my food from pissing him off at the giddy up, but It wouldn't be the first time. The unagi was tiny and for the price I could have gotten a whole eel in Tokyo. The salmon was decent but skint as well. I'd go back if I happened to be in the area but not going out of my way. The menu was interesting if you're into greenpeace and saving the whales and all.

2327.review:
Service, Service, Service. 
You've maybe never had a meal where your hosts were so attentive to your needs, and in a humble restaurant that appears to pay close attention to the ethics of serving food. They refuse to serve some popular sushi fish because of the unsustainable fishing practices that have depleted their stocks; they provide smaller portions for most dishes with the option to get more for a small price in order to prevent wasting food that people don't finish, and to top it all off the price that they ask for the meal is final and there's no haggling over a tip for the service. It's included.
I suppose I should have gotten to the food by now, which is great! Even if you can't have your big eye tuna sashimi, their sushi rolls are tasty and the noodle soups can be quite filling. They also serve beer and sake.
Tokyo Diner isn't very big, and it's not exactly a secret as these reviews and the front window, almost entirely obscured by stickers from various London food guides, can attest. Still, it's a great find and a choice place to stop for a lunch or dinner in the area.

2328.review: Quite decent food, for very basic expectations. You get a meal for £10 that would cost £3 in Tokyo, but nevertheless nothing particularly wrong with what they serve. That particular day, the waitress was unacceptably rude, especially for a Japanese restaurant, but perhaps it was simply bad luck.

2329.review:
A Japanese friend discovered this restaurant and it soon became a favourite of ours (me and my husband). We have eaten here over a period of at least 10 years and have never been disappointed with the food or the service.
 The restaurant is on 3 floors, but the service is excellent no matter which floor you are seated in. 
All of the food is fresh and of excellent quality, and you can have noodle dishes, bento boxes, sushi and loads more! The cost is very reasonable and it's a great place to take friends, especially if you are attending a film in any of the nearby theatres.
 In proper Japanese-style, they don't allow tipping.
 This is one restaurant I always recommend to any friends visiting London.

2330.review:
One of those rare central London things - a cheap (for London), reliable and good quality restaurant. Not a place for an occassion, but perfect if you've been out shopping, or are going to the cinema. My favourite is the Salmon Don, warm rice served with salmon sashimi, omlette and seaweed.
 This is a place I often visit on my own, often before meeting friends for afterwork drinks (we all know the dangers of drinking on an empty stomach).

2331.review:
I love this place. You sit down to crackers and unlimited green tea and read through the menu which tells you that large portions are free, tips are discouraged (or donated to charity) and that until tuna isn't being fished to extinction they will not be serving it. The restaurant serves a delicious range of food at some very reasonable prices. If you can get there during the week at lunchtimes it's even better value.
 Try it out!

2332.review:
This has to be one of the yummiest and cheapest Japanese restaurants in central London, serving food day and night Tokoyo diner is usually always bustling.
 There is a great range of bento boxes, sushi and rice dishes, the only problem is choosing which one to have. But i recommend what ever you have to team it with a plum wine!
 The food is well priced and they do not except tips!
 Nestled on the corner of China town and 2 min's walk from Leicester square make this small restaurant a little gem.

2333.review: Edamame was tasty as it normally is, and the broccoli was really good - cooked in a dashi broth with small pieces of fried tofu - it was served cold, which was surprisingly nice. The sushi was all fresh and the nigiri were a good size. They give you free green tea with your meal as well, and in Japanese fashion, they don't accept tips (anything extra you leave behind goes to a homeless charity). There's also no tuna on the sushi menu as they refuse to serve any unsustainable fish. This part of town is full of little Japanese restaurants but this is one of the best I've been to - it's not fancy inside but the service is friendly, fish is fresh and it's pretty moderately priced for sushi.

2334.review: Authentic, good food and excellent price / value relation. "No tip" policy, free green tea and free large servings on request. Wide selection of typical food including Bento Box menus for GPB 11.50 to GPB 16.40 or an Udon soup for GPB 6.90 all incl. tax and tip!

2335.review: After having to walk across half the city due to student riots (go Tories - radicalize! radicalize!) I decided to stop in here for a quick bite before the long bus ride home. I have been wanting to go here for a while since I saw their vegetarian bento box, advertised as absolutely vegan, and partly intrigued by their marketing strategy of "no tips - it's just not japanese" which is prominently displayed on signs throughout the restaurant. Because I was on my own I was shown downstairs, into a somewhat depressing cellar space. Before ordering you can specify that you are extra hungry, and get a larger helping of rice for free (apparently if you do this too late you are out of luck for some reason - why you can't  get this if you ask later is beyond me. Another nice addition is the free Japanese tea; though I did have to go out of my way to get them to refill (service was only OK and it was one of those places where you can't seem to make eye contact with the wait-staff). The cost of the bento box is not cheap - 10.50 Pounds - but that's probably about standard for this area. The food itself was so-so. The four tiny sushi were just ok, and definitely not fresh. There was very little in the way of wasabi. The rice was OK, and the cooked vegetables tasty, if not stellar. The sesame seaweed salad was excessively oily. The best thing about this place was that it was reasonably filling, and there were no hidden costs; the downside is that the food just wasn't that nice. If you can get a table upstairs the ambiance would certainly be better.

2336.review: Good option for Japanese comfort food in London's Chinatown. I like the tonkatsu and the katsu curry here. Tokyo Diner was a regular stop on my more recent trips to London when the pound sterling hit stratospheric heights against the US dollar.  There is seating on three different floors, but the best, IMO, is the ground floor.

2337.review:
This restaurant has a great location just off Charing Cross road near Leicester Square. I've been twice to this restaurant and I'm glad I went the second time because the first left me with a bad impression.
The secret to this place is that it is not about sushi. If your looking for a Sushi restaurant instead of a Japanese food restaurant I suggest you look elsewhere.
The second time I went I ordered the Chicken Katsu Bento and it was extremely good. The only thing keeping it from 5 stars is the sashimi portion, which consisted of two slivers of low quality salmon.
The service is fast and friendly. All food, excepting the sushi, was great quality, well prepared and very tasty. The price is very reasonable for what you get, so although it isn't cheap (or expensive) it is very high value.
Not a michelin star "foody" destination but a great place to enjoy an efficient, tasty and good value meal.

2338.review: Perhaps the most authentic Japanese restaurant in London. I do not find the food as cheap as some reviewers implied, unless you are ordering from the off-peak deal. Misato, another Japanese cheap eat not too far from Tokyo Diner does cheaper food at larger portions. Tokyo Diner serves decent Japanese food but unfortunately not memorable. However, I do like their no-tips policy. Coming from Asia, I don't particularly agree with tipping, especially under pressure. Will I be back? Probably.

2339.review: Wonderful place - good, simple sushi, great location and a great price - and how refreshing to find a sushi restaurant that will not serve tuna for ethical reasons!

2340.review: Excellent value for money in central London, Tokyo Diner serves, unsurprisingly, tasty Japanese food. The bento boxes are particularly good with a nice selection of different things. The chicken katsu curry was also good, served with a mountain of rice, crispy on the outside but not too grreasy, succulent on the inside. You can also go large on your portion size for a nominal extra. It's also open quite late which is good if you find yourself starving after the cinema or a late one at work, although it doesn't quite stretch to post-pub hours.

2341.review:
Great value. Simple (and seemingly traditional) Japanese food served up in big portions. 
Friendly and straightforward with nice extras like free tea and free extra rice when you ask for 'omori'. 
Highly recommended for tasty interesting food on a budget.

2342.review: I've spent many a happy evening at Tokyo Diner. London is fully of pricey Japaneses, catering for poncey business people, but this is a fantastic option for people who like Japanese food but happen not to be investment bankers! The sushi set andkatsu curry are especially good value, and there's a great choice of Japanese beers, eg, Kirin, Asahi. It's a very cute little cubby hole, and all the staff are Japanese. You really do feel like you could be in a little corner of Tokyo somewhere. Like restaurants in Japan, they do not take tips. Overall, the management obviously prides itself on providing a great, good value service - 100% recommended!

2343.review: I will always love the Tokyo Diner as it was the FIRST place I ever ate sushi. It's a fantastic little place - run by an Englishman who lived in Japan for a long time. It's the perfect place to introduce someone gently to Japanese cuisine. The sushi nigiri sets are lovely and very reasonable. Great katsu and curry too. Nice decor and ambience - really wonderful little gem in the heart of Chinatown

2344.review: Tokyo Diner is one of the cheapest restaurants in central London with terrific-value katsu curry and free omori portions of rice. A couple eating here will come away with change from £30 after eating a main, a miso soup starter and having a drink each. The katsu curry - whether chicken or pork - is the most popular dish here, but the sushi is also excellent with good salmon and tuna. It's also big enough to be able to find tables for people even on a Saturday night. This mild curry is made in generous portions. It is mild with potato and carrot forming the bulk of the dish. The breadcrumb-covered meat sits atop the curry.

2345.review: For a quick and easy oriental meal, Tokyo Diner is very consistent. Good food, reasonable prices and a friendly atmosphere make this a pleasant stop for a quick meal. The food is good, with a menu covering a variety of Japanese meals and a selection of sushi. Its at the bottom end of China town, near Leicester Square and so can be visited without needing to wade into the chaos of China town itself. Not much else to be said  it does what it says on the tin!

2346.review: supremely average in every way. The sushi is bland, and as sign of a poor sushi place, has no yellowtail (hamachi). I also ordered udon noodles with chicken - the chicken was great, but the soup was tepid, and pretty average. I found the copy writing on the menu to be condescending (slurp your soup and open your mouth a little to take in air as you slurp - it improves the flavour.. (awful)). Ah, but the green tea is fabulous. I will not be going back

2347.review:
Lovely little Japanese diner 2 minutes fom Leicester Square station. Very cheap for central London, but great quality food and fantastic service. I was on my own and felt totally comfortable sitting in there at a little table - no double takes or incredulous/pitying looks! They have vegan dishes here too which although I didn't have any the table next to me were cooing and exclaiming over their deliciousness!
I had some sushi, tea and a glass of wine and it came to less than a tenner, I would heartily recommend this little place (and it is little).
I love their no tipping policy too - they make it perfectly clear that the price they sell for is the price they want you to pay and state that if someone accidentally leaves some money on the table they automatically give it to St Martin's in the field - but to save the embarrassment, why not just put it in the collection box by the till anyway?
Someone else on here said they felt patronised by the little written comments like We don't mind if you slurp your noodles whereas I just found them funny and sweet notes meant to put you at your ease.

2348.review: Low prices, high quality. This is one of my favourite hidden gems of central London. It's open late (limited menu after 11pm) and the food is fantastic. You get free unlimited green tea and a little something to snack on while you wait for your food. Everything is prepared fresh, in house. One quirk is that they don't accept tips. If you try to be sneaky and leave a tip anyway, they will just donate the money to charity. Lovely people, lovely place. Notably, they're open 365 days a year.

2349.review: very nice good ! and very thypique , i like this !

2350.review: Waited patiently for 45 mins for a meal that never arrived. Won't be rushing back

2351.review: Good solid Japanese cuisine with no qualms. Totally unpretentious, reminiscent of a Tokyo noodle house. I like to have the katsu don, which is a solid meal of pork cutlet and rice cooked together with a savory omlet, tasty with their brown sauce. I've never had to wait for a meal (no reservations), and the prices can't be beaten. Great place to go if you're out on the town and feel the munchies coming on.

2352.review: Tokyo Diner is such a relaxed spot. It is styled like a Japanese restaurant in the middle of Tokyo. From the side way sliding doors, natural wood interior and Japanese waitresses all waiting to take your order, you'll feel like you've just arrived in Japan. I've been here several times because the place is non-complicated. The menus have everything you'd expect from a sushi restaurant with ramen and great bento box dishes to enjoy. I usually come here for the lunch time bento box and I find them very filling. I recommend this place to my friends and to you as it is a hassle-free Japanese zone. However, it does get busy during the evenings so coming during the day when the sun is out is probably best. Lots of Japanese calligraphy on the wall and a good view of what's happening downstairs in Newport place. It is a good place to have a conversation with your friends and there are also pegs on the walls for people to hook their jackets and bags for extra security. The price ranges from £7, which is good enough for such a lively and peaceful atmosphere. I found that the sunny days in the upstairs area were the best days to come here. This is a good place for couples, yet you might have to book in advance if you'd like to bring a group of four. The Tokyo diner is not large enough for big parties unfortunately.; (

2353.review:
Came here after a visit to the British Museum and was able to sang a table. The service was excellent and prompt, and I opted for the two course menu. The house wine was also good for the price.
The scallops were perfectly cooked and paired well with the apples. The duck really shined - the skin was crispy and the meat was succulent and delicious. I also had the tarte tatin for desert, which was not overly sweet and paired with a very nice custard.
The atmosphere was cozy and warm, and the prices were reasonable for the location. Definitely worth checking out if you're in the area.

2354.review:
Poor service and bland food. I'm pretty easy to please but neither the food or service could make this a place I would recommend. 
This is an overpriced tourist trap at the best. 
The French onion soup was bland. How does a French restaurant serve bland French onion soup?
Our fries were brought out 20 minutes after the rest of our food. 
So many better places to eat than this and at much better prices.

2355.review: Came here with a large group for dinner. We all got the two courses set because we were hungry. Sets come with fresh bread with oil (yum!). We also ordered two bottles of wine. Service was slow but polite. The atmosphere was incredibly relaxing and it felt like one could stay at the table all night talking and unwinding. I got the braised lamb with stuffed mushrooms as a first course. The mushrooms were well seasoned and topped with a generous helping of herbs and goat cheese (double yum!). The lamb was cut into thick, juicy slices and resting on a bed of roast potatoes, steamed carrots and green beans, mashed potatoes, and ratatouille. Absolutely fabulous. Everything tasted amazing. The only incident was the small deep fried ball of meat that came on the side of my plate. I thought it looked like some sort of deep fried organ so I didn't eat it... I wonder if it landed on my plate by mistake during serving.

2356.review: Fabulous little bistro we happened to find while getting away from the normal tourist trap establishments.  Owners were working hard as staff was either on holiday or out ill.  They did a terrific job and we loved our delicious meal and wine.  Everything was fresh and made to order.  Prices were extremely reasonable.

2357.review:
We headed here after spending an afternoon at the museum. We were slightly early for our booking, but were seated immediately, while waiting for our friend to arrive.
Service was lovely. They only had 2 meal menus, but since we were hungry, they allowed us to order extra starters.
The food was excellent. From starters to desserts - pate, lamb kidneys, the sea bass, lamb and duck - each one perfectly cooked. And some of the best French fries that I've eaten in a very long time. 
They had some excellent wines and the whisky cheesecake was outstanding!
Wish I had found this place before my mum and dad visited, would have loved to take them here on one of their many visits to the museum.

2358.review:
This was a delightful and cozy spot! We we thrilled to find it! We love French food and this place hit the nail on the head. 
The food is incredibly reasonable especially considering how amazing it all tastes! 
The staff was wonderful - they answered our questions happily and were very attentive. They even offered some suggestions of things to go on our trip to Paris. 
My husband and I shared some wine, French of course, and were pleased! 
For appetizers we had the goose rillete and  baked goat cheese - it was an amazing start to our meal. 
For dinner my husband had roast duck, which was perfectly cooked, and I had seared sea bass which was delicious! The skin had a crispness to it without drying out the fish. 
We ended the meal with cheesecake which honestly, was the best we've had! The texture was almost whipped it was so smooth and light.  
Without a doubt I would recommend this restaurant. There is nothing about the experience that I could give lower than 5 stars to. If you ever find yourself in London, on or near Bloomsbury way, stop in for a bite. You won't regret it!

2359.review:
What a treat! We ducked in out of the rain and found a table - our good luck. The service, the food (bouillabaisse x 2, bread, salad, wine, coffees), and the setting were wonderful, it's a very charming place. 
   Other choices include a veg prix fixe menu and assorted food for carnivores. Good value, a great meal.

2360.review:
I travel to London fairly often for work so I am usually out dining alone. The food was fantastic and the service was pretty good. I had two lovely ladies waiting on me, however, I asked the less experienced waitress for a wine recommendation and she had no idea what to say, so I ended up with a bottle of house wine, which was perfectly fine, but I would have loved a recommendation on a proper french wine as I'm always looking to broaden my palate and learn more about wine in general.
Still, a wonderful experience overall, highly recommend it!

2361.review: This tiny French cafe was a great choice during our stay in London. We were craving something fresh and yet still delicious. They have a pre-fix lunch menu with a salad and a meat option. The salad the day we visited was a roasted pear salad, it look so good but I wasn't hungry enough for multiple courses. I did end up with a salad though and so did another guest in my party. I ordered a butternut squash and goat cheese salad and it was perfectly dressed and a larger serving- I would recommend! The other salad ordered was a warm chicken and avocado salad- which was also very tasty and a large portion. We also had a steak and Brie sandwich on a fresh baguette- it was perfection. The bread was so fresh and soft yet the outside perfectly crispy. Everything we ordered was great and I would highly recommend this spot! The upstairs area is smaller and doesn't have air conditioning, which is fine normally but we were visiting on an 80 degree day- so just keep that in mind! The downstairs area is larger and cooler, but lacks the charm of the upstairs area, however this would be better for larger parties! Go here!

2362.review:
Maybe I was just unlucky, ordering the wrong dish... I couldn't eat more than half - it tasted weird. The bread had little gnats flying on it too and was too hard, like it'd been cut up hours before. 
I like the ambience of the place though, and the waitress, though she seemed stressed. I hope she gets a vacation or something good soon.

2363.review: We really enjoyed Savoir Faire.  Although our children are not fond of French food, the menu had enough options to please everyone.  The waitresses were very helpful and friendly. We found the food to be good, and the atmosphere pleasant.

2364.review:
My friend and I had a late lunch here around 2:30 pm on a beautiful Sunday afternoon. We came from the British Museum, which was just a short walk away. It was fairly empty at the time, so we had our pick of indoor and outdoor seating; we picked a small table inside, right by a window, and got a nice view of the street and nearby buildings. There was also plenty of seating, as well as toilets, downstairs, although no one was sitting downstairs because it was so sunny outside (the downstairs area was quite dark but would probably be cozy in the evenings). We were greeted promptly by our server.
Both of us ordered the butternut squash and goat cheese salad (my friend is a vegetarian). The food came out pretty quickly. I was pleased with how generous they were with the toppings; they had completely covered the greens with goat cheese, sliced nuts, and squash. The salad came with dressing on, but I'm sure you could ask for it on the side. It was really tasty; there might actually have been too much cheese, but as goat cheese is my favorite, I was pretty happy with it. The salads came with 1 basket of bread that we split; we wound up ordering more, since there wasn't that much in the 1st basket. The bread was accompanied by some seasoned olive oil, which also had sesame seeds in; it was pretty addicting for me as a bread lover. However, as it was a French restaurant, I was expecting the bread to be better; it was good, but I wasn't as blown away as I have been at some other French/Italian/Spanish restaurants.
For dessert we split (well, I had 75% of it) a pear tarte tatin (when asked, the server informed us the dessert special of the day was mango sorbet). The tarte was a good size and really tasty; it was served warm. If my friend had been hungrier, I would've wanted to order 2 desserts, as the tarte wasn't really big enough to split equally between 2 people (although I have a big appetite so your mileage may vary).
The restaurant had a great atmosphere and a nice view of the street. We were allowed to take our time and weren't bothered much by anyone throughout our leisurely meal. The facilities and tables were clean. The ceiling was decorated with some humorous sayings, so look up if you visit. Our meal came out to be about £15/person, including 1 glass of wine, 1 dessert, and an extra basket of bread. I really enjoyed my lunch here and would happily return if I'm ever in the area again.

2365.review: Lovely lunch where everyone left happy and satisfied with their meal.  Excellent service.

2366.review: Great French food. Good value and price for London. I love when you can get your own carafe of wine. I had the fish special and my husband had the lamb. Both were delicious. Highly recommend.

2367.review:
A cute spot to grab good food and a drink or two.
I enjoyed the Aperol spritz. It wasn't too bitter and it was refreshing. 
The bread you get with dinner is nice and soft. It's served with oil for dipping.
For dinner I ordered a mixed greens salad and the vegetarian tagine. The mixed greens (smallish) included frilly greens, a few slices of tomato and a creamy dressing. It was alright. The tagine was pretty good though. It included cooked carrots and apricots in a flavorful sauce with mint over couscous. I just wish there were a few more different veggies in there. 
My sister ordered the large vegetarian butternut squash and goat cheese green salad. It was super flavorful and the portion was generous. She also ordered the fries (chips), which were a little thinner than I normally like but not bad. I do like how there are several vegetarian options.
Our waitress was pleasant and helpful. 
The decor is fun and nice. I enjoyed the quotes written on the ceiling.
If I come back to London I would visit Savoir Faire again.

2368.review: Loved it! Great food, reasonable prices, great service. Very small place and not a chain. Would definitely recommend!

2369.review:
SO. GOOD. 
I've been for lunch a couple of times and simply cannot fault this place. 
The service is exceptional and they are even accommodating when I have a baby with me. 
The food can take a while to come out but when it's as good as it is here, I can't complain. 
The lunch deal is a steal. 
The staff are incredible. Thank you.

2370.review: I had the vegetarian 2 course special. The goat cheese caprese was good. The Aubergine "cannelloni" were amazing. They were strips of eggplant rolled around a mixture of ricotta with olives drizzled with tahini, and surrounded by green beans, potatoes and roasted tomatoes. If someone would cook like that for me, I'd cheerfully become a vegetarian. One of the best things I've ever had. The service was friendly cheerful and the whole experience was great.

2371.review: After a day at the British Museum we found this location via the other great reviews on Yelp, and it didn't  disappoint.

2372.review: Visiting London for the first time, a friend and I tried this restaurant. It was in close walking distance to the London National Museum. The food was food and they have a two course special for early dinner. However, if you do not have a reservation you are not allowed to sit on the ground floor but are quickly whisked away to the basement to dine. The food came out quickly, however the waitress disappeared for a long time when we were dining and it took about 30 minutes longer to finally get our check.

2373.review: This quaint little French restaurant was one of my favorites that I had visited in London. The food is authentically mouthwatering, not to mention for a great price. The staff was exceptionally nice. The whole evening was elegant, unpretentious, and definitely something I'd like to repeat. Flawless!

2374.review:
This place is indeed an affordable French gourmet restaurant. They have a 24£ 3 course meal deal that is very good value for money! Usually when you choose a set menu you get very limited choices but this place has so much to chose from it was hard to pick just one! As a starter I had the chicken liver which was REALLY yummy. As a main I had the  beef bourguignon which was really tasty. We ended the meal with a chocolate mousse which was good. 
The service was really good. Our waitress was very friendly and made great recommendations when asked. 
The place is a bit tight and if you sit downstairs it is windowless. 
I would definitely go again and highly recommend this place!

2375.review: STELLAR SERVICE. They were open Xmas day, didn't need a reservation, the food was delicious, the ambiance was "quaint Parisian cafe," and the service was exceptional.

2376.review:
This was the best meal my wife & I had in London.  We arrived just after lunch service had ended (after a long day of wandering around the British Museum) and were still able to order off the lunch menu.  We had the restaurant to ourselves for a little while and we felt welcome and very comfortable in the cozy and inviting dining room.
My wife had the steak and brie baguette with onions and horseradish mayonnaise and I had the steak frites. Both of our meals were simply amazing. I followed it off with some chocolate mousse which was the best mouse I have had since my last visit to Paris last year.
This restaurant should be a must stop for anyone in this part of London.

2377.review:
Very clean (although small) tables, toilets, and nice service. Had lunch combo for £14+ it actually charges me £16+ maybe for the service fee. The combo comes with a starter+entrée or entrée+dessert, either way you like. I have the soup of the day for starter, which is chicken vegetables soup. It was really good. The soup is neither too salty nor greasy, with lentil, carrot, and some other veggies. I ordered fish soup for entrée and I think it would be better if they can squeeze more lemon juice in it. 
The carafe and water glasses are not very clean though. But the bread is superb. My boyfriend ordered Lamb kidney for starter and Duck leg for entrée, he said it was flavorless but I think they are okay. 
This cafe would be good for you if you are looking for some delicate food with light flavor, and also, if you have enough time since the waiting time is a little long than I have expected.

2378.review:
This is an amazingly affordable French restaurant with a set menu which include (joy!) a good selection of vegetarian options. The interior is cosy (but there is a downstairs eating area in the basement as well) and slightly 'shabby-chic' (which extends to the cutlery and glassware as well).
The main event is the food: the two course menu is £24, but there is a cheaper vegetarian menu as well. Desserts are £5.90. For the price, in this area of London, it represents fabulous value, as the quality is very good, mostly in the classic French style.
On two recent visits, service was very good - friendly but unobtrusive, and they made a real effort to seta us when they were busy one evening.
I shall be back.

2379.review:
We went without booking, but the waitress so kindly helped us get a table instead of just turning us away. Through the dinner, service was top notch, and I really appreciated it -- never take it for granted! 
Food was solid as well. I had pork belly, which was very flavourful and rich together with the purée. My bf ordered foie gras as starter, which was probably one of the best I ever had. 
Absolutely adored the ambience -- very artsy and cozy at the same time. Great lighting and perfect for dates. 
Would love to go back soon!

2380.review: With a quiet and quaint atmosphere, this restaurant provided genuine French cuisine. The Christmas menu provided only a few dinner options and only 3-4 alcoholic drinks to choose from. Of the small amount of choices, the food was savory. The price was on the heavy side of what usually is attributed to this restaurant (due to the holiday limitations). The staff was friendly and made accommodations for canceling an order midway through our meal when one of our diners decided they weren't hungry (no charge).

2381.review: This is the worst restaurant in London. We have the worst experienced, the receptionist lady is very rude and un accommodative, she showed us a table and prepare the table just wiping it with wet clothes and sat the utensils down on the wet table, so dirty We are very shocked by her action. The whole place looks really dirty and unhealthy

2382.review:
Excellent food and very close to British museum. This place serves the best French food in London for the price. Two course meal for about 23, might sound like a lot but the quality is excellent. The goose appetizer and lamb were the meal for me and it was delicious. 
Service can be very slow especially if you sit downstairs but the food compensated for it.

2383.review: This French gem is flawless. Food deserves a Michelin star for its high quality preparation and presentation. The service is also peerless. Staff is friendly and amicable. What else can be said---We've eaten here twice for dinner and once for lunch in just the last week. I can and would eat here daily if I could. If you enjoy a high standard like I do, this shiny little bauble is for you! Magnifique! London has so many great places to eat, but this place stands out for its quality sure, but the vibe is also great, no pretense, just fine food at great prices. Feels like a local Parisian bistro. Go!

2384.review:
This restaurant is a true gem! Loved the food and service. I highly recommend this place.
The steak was delicious as well as the bouillabaisse.  If you are in the area I would definitely try it out!!

2385.review:
Great French food and great prices. The server was very nice and knowledgeable about the food and the atmosphere was romantic. Perfect dinner for our last night in London. The foe grass was fabulous, cooked perfectly, every ingredient on the plate made sense. We had wild mushrooms with fresh goat cheese, pork belly, beef bourgeoning and bread pudding toffee, perfect way to end a perfect meal.
I am definitely recommending this restaurant to anyone that visits or lives in London.

2386.review:
Hands down--Wow! My husband and I were in London on vacation for 10 days. We were staying in the Covent Garden area and went to Savoir Faire for dinner one evening. Easily the best meal we had in London (yet nowhere near the most expensive). We hit some big name restaurants and none of the cooking was as spot on as Savoir Faire. The preparations were beautiful and delicious. 
Savoir Faire is a small, unpretentious, neighborhood restaurant. It is casual and comfortable, but the food is the epitome of French style. We had a very affordable bottle of Chateaudeuf-du-pape. I have to admit that I have forgotten after a almost a month away from home what we had for a starter. We both ordered chicken for dinner. It was moist and delicious with a wonderful array of vegetables, perfectly prepared. We shared a dessert. Everything was perfect. 
This is the restaurant I will be talking about and recommending to anyone I know heading to London. It is small, so make a reservation, but it is a must try.

2387.review:
So I have to admit...  I'm not really a fan of French food.  It's usually so rich and heavy and that's just not my thing.  When my coworkers and I were on a trip to London and the cuisine agreed upon by the group was French I was not super excited.  But this meal ended up being great!  
They have a two course set menu for around 23 pounds.  The various appetizers tried at our table were the grilled fig with goat cheese, the octopus, the mussels, and the fried halloumi - all were excellent and original.  I would give a recommendation, but really that's probably try them all.  The mussels may have been the most unexpected in serving and flavor - they came out of their shells in a special serving dish, and the sauce was incredibly garlicky and delicious.
For entrees, our table had the duck, beef bourguignon, lamb shank, and the vegetable plate.  Again, everyone loved theirs.  The sauces were delicious and balanced out the meat perfectly.
And after our fantastic meals, we couldn't stop without dessert.  Our table shared creme brulee, chocolate mousse, and tarte tatin.  And again, everything was excellent.  The chocolate mousse was very rich without being too sweet.  The tarte tatin was very different from ones we have had in the US - the apple was a different texture but delicious.  The creme brulee was excellent as well.
The restaurant itself was small and very cute.  A great ambiance.  There were paintings all over the wall, which were definitely different than what we would see in the US, but it was a great little European find for us on our trip.

2388.review: Food was not amazing. Just ok. We were looking for true French cuisine but this was pretty plain.

2389.review: Inaptly named. Nice food, poor service. In a restaurant w few people folks itching to get their bill. Food was tasty, especially chocolate mousse, and good price, just slow and hard to get attention w service

2390.review: Food was excellent but the chef was clearly overtaxed on a Friday night, leading to delays in food arriving. To make matters worse the owner and his wife, gruff white haired elderly couple, arrived and were served their food immediately, bumping me and other customers back (my entree didn't arrive until an hour after ordering).  Owner then curtly refused to take anything off the bill though his own meals had preempted the paying customers.

2391.review:
This was my very first dinner in London, and I was definitely satisfied. A few friends and I came here after seeing how it was so highly reviewed on Yelp, and when we got to the restaurant we were surprised (but I guess happy) at how empty yet small it was. There was probably only one other table occupied, and a total of 7 tables in the room we were seated.
The menu contained a lot of options, but I wanted something light so I ordered one of the vegetarian dishes. I can't remember what it's called, but it had mushrooms topped with mashed garbanzo beans/chickpeas and a side of broccoli and carrots. I'll admit that when the food first came out I was a bit skeptical since it's not the prettiest dish, but the first bite destroyed any doubt. The taste and texture of the mushroom paired with that of the garbanzo beans was amazing, and the broccoli/carrots were wonderfully cooked as well. I especially liked how the sauce was light and only used to enhance the taste (rather than drenching the food in sauce, which is kind of common nowadays in a lot of restaurants). After finishing I was well-satisfied and happy.
Overall a great place to eat if you like authentic French food! I loved my experience here (food, service, and the super cute decor).

2392.review:
I really like this restaurant,  the food is amazing and the service is friendly.  The prices are reasonable and the decor and atmosphere are both great. 
The waiter when we were there personally recommended one of the wines, and it was lovely to see some of the diners chatting to each other at different tables,  like it's a place to be socialable and actually talk to other people - something which is very special when you see it in London. 
I couldn't give this restaurant a higher rating though because of its 2 star hygiene rating by Camden council,  I don't really understand why such an otherwise amazing restaurant would take such a lax attitude to food satety but it isn't a good sign. 
Hopefully they'll take it on board and try to improve as it's otherwise a wonderful independent restaurant in central London, a welcome alternative to so many identikit chains.

2393.review:
Holy moly... Fantastic food!! So I guess I like French food? If THIS represents French then YES! I started with the baked goat cheese, moved onto the duck, and wow. The flavors are simply astonishing... Although the duck texture was average. Even still.. Epic dish! This is a return over and over places folks! 
Oh and... Price? It will make you spin your head... The prices are that of a typical chain... Not too high. How? I dunno but I am coming back tomorrow.
Ok update (3 minutes after posting!) the texture of the duck is killing me... SO chewy! But... Still 5 star. Why? Flavor... Unique flavor in the whole dish... Everything on the plate is so enriched in unique and DELICIOUS flavor I don't care. Plus it's only a few pieces like that.
Sorry 4-star review people who always do 4 starts even when they say it's great! (Why oh why do people do that?)... This is 5 star at its best!
Oh... And I hate the French. But you get five stars for food!

2394.review: I was looking forward to this meal due to the strong reviews...However I was disappointed. To start, I ordered the grilled figs with blue cheese and mint. The figs were neither grilled nor was there mint. In fact the figs were raw and cold. For my main entree, I ordered their honey glazed duck with red wine jus. While the flavors were good, the duck was way over cooked by French standards. If you order the duck you must you must clarify that you want it medium rare.

2395.review:
Cest tres bon!!
Well this was just a fantastic evening I have to say. The owners ever present in the dining room help to create a warm and welcoming atmosphere. Stepping off a busy London street you are immediately transported to a bistro that could be anywhere in France though I like to imagine myself being somewhere in Provence, wild fields of lavender filling the air with an aroma like to no other....anyway....back to the food!
For my starter I went for Goose Rillettes served with Spiced Plums, the rillettes had an excellent texture, neither too fatty or to smooth, there was still a nice consistency to it. I sometimes find rillettes made more like a pate, blitzed to hell and back. The goose with the sweet and spicy plums was a lovely match and very tasty.
For my main Herb-crusted Rump of Lamb with Celeriac Puree, Balsamic braised Beetroot and Herb and Tomato Jus. Im a sucker for lamb with a crust and this was done supremely well. Cooked with great attention in a pan then oven roasted to melt in the crust the lamb was still beautifully pink. Celeriac is one of my favourite vegetables and the puree was smooth and well seasoned. Delicious.
Washed all of the lovely food down with a bottle of red, reasonably priced and delicious.
Finished the night with a French coffee and toddled off into the night very content.

2396.review:
The reviews turned out to be spot on. This is some extremely fine french cooking for an affordable price. There are two menus, the lighter menu is 15 pounds and includes an entree and your choice of a dessert or appetizer and then there is the 23 pound dinner menu that includes an appetizer and entree. Both are available at dinner periods and both are delicious (I ordered off the pricier dinner menu while my partner ordered off the 15 pound menu and we were both beyond satisfied). I had a glass of house red (£4) and we both shared a dessert afterwards (£6.50) and the best dinner I've had in London came to a well-spent £50.
Service was prompt and friendly and they were even able to fit us in without a reservation, though we came very early. If you plan to eat here after 5:30 I would definitely make a reservation. Off of the cheaper menu I highly recommend the duck legs and off the more expensive menu the lamb shank is delectable.
PROs:
- Great french cooking
- Not dirt cheap, but for what you get it feels like theft
- Very close to the British Museum, 5 min from the main entrance. About 10 minutes walk from Holborn station.
CONs:
- It gets busy quickly, even on weekdays. Make a reservation unless you are willing to take a risk.

2397.review:
I had lunch here 6 weeks ago after visiting the British Museum and loved it so much I came back today and brought my parents.
The fig with ham and goat cheese is absolutely amazing, as are the beef bourguignon and the lamb shanks. The bouillabaisse is amazing if you are looking for a lighter option.
Get the house wine by the glass, it's great too.
Overall amazing value for money.
Only con is food takes a little too much time but 100% worth it!

2398.review: Strange decoration but excellent food. All ingredients are self made, including the sauces (hence the name). Good value too given the quality of the dishes. Try it.

2399.review:
We ate here on our first night  in London. The bistro was a short walk from the hotel. We also had lunch here on our last day in London. 
Ambiance: small casual restaurant, dining on the street level and a dining room downstairs. Not very lavish but quaint. The location is great for people watching, located on a busy intersection. The narrow staircase and lighting on the way to the loo could use some work.
Service: two servers at dinner were very helpful, efficient and welcoming. The servers for lunch were not as pleasant, one hardly said a word but smiled a lot. The other server yelled at tired Japanese tourists who sat on the chairs outside. Not very hospitable.
Food: we really enjoyed our dinner here. I ordered the baked mussels which came in an escargot dish and had the traditional butter, herb and garlic butter. Great for dipping the wonderful bread. My wife ordered the steak frites and I had the calf's liver. Both were very good. No dessert. 
Lunch was not as flavorful. We ordered salad, Caesar and the house salad. Neither were exciting, lettuce was not crispy and the vinaigrettes were not very flavorful. Add the less than enthusiastic servers, I wish we went elsewhere for lunch.

2400.review:
I came here with a friend for a bit of a nicer dinner out. We are both students and they advertise this place as an inexpensive gourmet French restaurant...perfect! 
The service started off as very attentive and we ordered a bottle of house white wine. The waitress quickly brought us a bottle, poured it, and left. Before we knew it we realized she had poured us each a glass of red wine-not what we ordered. This issue would have also been prevented if they showed us the bottle of wine and permitted us an initial taste as every other restaurant does. After much confusion with another waitress who was on her first day and barely spoke English, she was able to help us to amend the issue and she then brought us our white wine. She filled the glasses to the brim-no exaggeration.
The starter and main meal was delicious. My friend got the mussels which I would highly recommend. The lentil moussaka was also delicious. Salads were pretty standard, nothing amazing. Overall I would recommend this restaurant.

2401.review: It's a casual French having only a course menu for dinner. It's reasonable but tasty and a big portion!! I liked the soup with smoked salmon and cheese and British traditional beef stew.....

2402.review:
3 Stars = "A-OK" and that's how I felt about this place. The food was good (4 stars), the atmosphere and decor makes it more of a homey places. Basically, the two didn't match well together. It almost seems like a great top chef lost his job at a Michelin Star restaurant and went to work at a "normal" restaurant.
Whether or not this is a good or bad thing is up to you and your personality. I usually expect the two to match because of the company I'm with, but if you are just a casual dinner looking for great food, this is your place. The food and it's presentation is far beyond the way the restaurant looked and operated.

2403.review: This is a gem of a restaurant. We went before the theater and had wonderful food- the mussels were wonderful as well as lamb shank and duck. Very reasonably priced also.

2404.review:
It's rare for me to return to a restaurant on a second visit. But this restaurant is nothing short of divine.
I still dream of the mussels cooked with garlic and Pernod and lemon essence. Everything else left me in a dreamy haze!
Run, don't walk here!

2405.review:
Beyond love, beyond adoration, I truly venerate this place. 
When in London, I stop for multiple meals here. That's me in the alcove to the right of the entrance and someday,   I'll probably just take up a fortnight's residence there.
From kidneys, to foie gras, to whatever the special is, food has always been amazing and service attentive.  
The only sad thing, is I walked by this place for years before dining there. When I think of the  delightful meals that could have been, I could cry, but I'm making up for it now. Mea maxima culpa. 
Eschew the high street chain and the mediocre and dine like royalty in a relaxing, unfussy bistro.  Last meal? Dine here! Who needs heaven when you've tasted the food of the Gods.

2406.review:
I do not regret choosing Savoir Faire for my birthday dinner, even though it was a complete leap of faith as neither of my friends who accompanied me on the special occasion nor myself had been there before. The place is small and a little quaint, and quirky with the, interesting, wallpapers. It seems really underwhelming upon entrance, but the food we had was truly phenomenal especially considering the prices.
The two-course prix fixe menu was a great find in an otherwise such an expensive city. I had mackerel as an appetizer followed by sea bass. Both were cooked and seasoned really well. We also had a bottle of tempranillo and finished the meal with crème brûlée and lemon tart. It truly felt like fine dining on a shoestring, and we got the best of both worlds. My friends also raved about everything they ordered (caesar salad, lentil moussaka, etc). 
I believe we overheard the servers speak French, which only provided a reassuring sign since there's a better chance the chefs are French as well. The service might be a bit lacking at times - or am I just too used to the American standards - but it doesn't detract at all from the overall value of the restaurant.

2407.review: Still at table as I write this. Mussels with garlic sauce presented like escargots was perfectly garlicky. Fig appetizer was excellent. Chicken was lovely. Duck breast was spectacular!  Love this place. Oh and the music playing is perfect.

2408.review:
There are pictures of naked ladies all around the restaurant, so I do not recommend bringing your adolescent son here for a meal with his school mates.
The menu is reasonably priced and the wines are, too. There are two levels and the bathroom is so small that it made me have panic attacks. Not really. I'm a man, I can handle that kind of stuff.
But seriously, the sink was so tiny if my hands had a nervous system, they would have panic attacks. Not really. They are a man's hands. Don't get it twisted.

2409.review: At first it doesn't look like much, but very soon it surprises in a very positive way. The atmosphere is very nice, the staff is friendly and helpful and the food... The food is one of the most delicious I've had in a long time in a restaurant. The meals might not be cheap but they're not expensive either - and for that taste they're worth every penny!

2410.review: Early dinner after the British Museum. Wow! In my 8 year old daughters words, "They are so nice, and they make very good food." We had the fried mussels. Like escargot, with mussels, and excellent French bread. For entrees, we had the lamb shank, duck Magritte with chocolate ganache, and bouillabaisse. All were excellent! Dessert was necessary, so we had chocolate mousse and cheesecake, as well as cappuccino. I can heartily recommend everything.

2411.review: Outstanding!  We both had steak and fries with salad and half a bottle of the house red, all of which was delicious.  The cheesecake and crème brulee for dessert were both excellent. the service was impeccable throughout and the whole meal was very good value for money indeed.  I can't rate it too highly.  We'll definitely be back!

2412.review:
A cozy restaurant with fresh ingredients with a homecooked touch. I actually felt as if I was sitting in a house being served by my friend's family. The food is good, but waiting almost an hour to have it put in front of you was tough. I had a group lunch and we were on a tight schedule so we promptly ordered at noon hoping to be done before 1PM since we had class. We all ordered different things around the table and were served our appetizers while we waited for main courses. As we were sitting there, I could tell we were getting antsy and constantly checking the time because we knew we were running out and we were going to be late. Not really sure why it took nearly an hour for the food to come out, but I think it's something they should work on for people on a time crunch during lunch time.
When it comes down to the food, it was nice. Not exactly out of this world amazing, but it was definitely a nice light meal. The service was good since we were the only ones in the restaurant, but my only gripe is the long wait for the food to arrive at the table. Maybe I'll be back, but not when I'm in a hurry.

2413.review:
Came across this very nice and cozy place. We made a reservation for dinner. It was sooooooo worth it.
First- The service was very nice and helpful. The food came quick even though there were a lot of people. 
Second- The most important part... the food!! It was excellent. Its French cousine. I got the ceasar salad. It didnt have the ceasar dressing but they had something better, balsamic vinegar dressing. It was delicious. My mom got the escargot. She said it was good. 
 For the main course, i got the beef burger with a mini-salad and fries as a side dish. The patty was cooked to perfection and the fries were not greasy at all.
We also got the cheesecake, and it was good. 
 Overall, I would come back.

2414.review: Heaven by way of mussels and lamb shanks. I just stumbled upon this place thanks to yelp. Cozy French casual restaurant in Bloomsbury. Good value for gourmet food and the staff 's really attentive and nice. I will come back!!

2415.review: Great food and drinks at a reasonable price. Service was a bit slow, but other than that would highly recommend!

2416.review: Went for dinner before a show. Surprisingly, there was plenty of availability on a Friday night. The staff was friendly, the 50's French music added to the ambiance, but the food was only slightly above average and the service took a bit too long given our theater time constraints. The best part, though, was the reasonably priced meal.

2417.review: Really good Rillettes, Foie Gras, duck, rib eye, Creme brûlée

2418.review:
I thought i'd walked into the wrong restaurant.  Be warned this place is not classy or refined ...its rustic to put it nicely. Further perhaps because it was 5:30pm Tuesday, the place was empty except for 5 senior couples.  This part i didn't mind but a 6th old couple walked in and decided that from the 10 empty tables they wanted to sit next to us ...and then proceeded to stare and eavesdrop for the next 30mts whilst we rapidly finished our meal.
Anyway to backtrack a little, when we sat down were were given 4 menus including the price fix menu, pre-theater menu, al la carte menu and drinks menu.   After consulting yelp and foursquare i decided on the goats cheese and the lambshank and the wife got the sea bass.  The food was excellent and made up for the above shortcomings.  The prices were very good given we were just outside convent garden tourist-ville.  We will definitely go back...but maybe after 7pm next time to try a different vibe!

2419.review:
Bijoux is the best way to describe this gem serving hearty food in cozy, slightly eccentric decor. It almost seems a bit out of place on the bustling New Oxford Street, yet step inside and you are miles away from the the noise and chaos of the city. This Bloomsbury neighbourhood favourite is a bit a France in the heart of the city. 
The traditional French bistro menu is simple food cooked very well. And at very reasonable prices! As the locals seem to know. Our mid week supper felt like a feast here.

2420.review:
First things first: the food is glorious. It's also reasonably priced, especially considering the quality. 
I had my dinner outside, so I could watch the passersby and enjoy a cigar. The interaction was almost as good as the meal. I was asked for directions and change. Thank goodness the server was well versed in local geography and blessed with patience, as I was essentially useless for all queries, save those regarding my cigar. I was scolded by - I think - a Cuban expatriate for smoking Castro's cigars. Just for the record, it's Honduran. 
The half-carafe of  house wine is better than passable, but not exceptional. The service, while relaxed and non-hurried is friendly and enjoyable. 
I don't post nearly enough recommendations here on Yelp, but here ya go: I recommend Savoir Faire. Oh, and the free wifi is nice. It is, in fact part of the reason you are reading these bon mots. Bon appetite!

2421.review:
The food was good, but the service was really slow. 
There were two reasons for this, it was only the second day of one of the servers, and we were one of the two couples that were downstairs, and I think it was a little of out of site, out of mind.

2422.review:
My mother and grandmother were visiting London and I was tasked with finding a place near them for a nice meal on a Friday evening. 
I am pleased to say that Savoir Faire ticked all the boxes we needed for this situation: we needed decent food but not too expensive, with a decent atmosphere but not too loud, walking distance from Russell square, and able to take booking at short notice. We tried a few Italian places near by, but they were not picking up the phone. Their loss, as Savoir Faire allowed us to book online with very little notice; and all four members of our party enjoyed ourselves.
The menus were printed on a couple of sheets of A4, in about as slapdash a fashion as you could muster, and then stapled together. But that didn't detract from the selection of great sounding French dishes. The selection was a little modest, but it did have a "light menu" of smaller plates and salads. Ideal for the varied crowd at our table.
From the photos I expected quite small but beautifully executed gourmet French dishes, but in actuality it was more classic cooking at affordable prices. That is no bad thing: I cannot resist a beef bourguignon and this one did not disappoint. Flavoursome beef just melted in the mouth alongside creamy mash and rich sauce. Even the most basic of seasonal vegetables; carrots and broccoli, were lovely. Everyone else seemed very pleased with their lamb shank, chicken salad, and duck breast.
The service was great too; numerous waitresses were very attentive, swift with drinks, and then left us to chatter long after our last course was finished. The freedom to relax and finish drinks after a meal is a real plus on any venue, I absolutely detest being hurried out of the door or hassled for the bill.
The menu as I mentioned was a little on the small side from what I'd expect, but it was by no means bad, and everything we ordered food-wise was excellent. The only real complaint I could give was that the Irish coffee I had afterwards was pretty foul - but I'm not going to get on the back of French restaurant too much for this mistake.
If you like classic French dishes, a good atmosphere in a relatively small place, and a good bite to eat at short notice, you should definitely pop in here.

2423.review:
I wouldn't go as far as calling it French, but a interesting menu none the less. 
The menu is printed on a single piece of paper and therefore limited. This was my first time here, but I'm thinking they change it often. Regardless I like small menu's, because - as we proved again this evening - it normally means everything is freshly made
Everything we ordered was fantastic and not to expensive either. You can get away with a 2 course meal for £20

2424.review: We enjoyed our dinners between the Caesar salad and French onion soup.  Then we had salmon and beef bourginon that were excellent.   Service was excellent   They gave us time between courses.  We would highly recommend this restaurant.  We came without a reservation and they were very accommodating on a Saturday night

2425.review:
Well when the kids like the foie gras you know you're off to a great start!  
Excellent meal--we had the sea bass, steak, chicken and mussels and everyone thought it was yummy. 
Our server even helped avoid a meltdown from our youngest with a quick discussion about drink choices. Well done!
I would highly recommend this place.

2426.review: I've just eaten a fantastic traditional beef bourguignon in this restaurant... It was server with vegetables and "purée". Reallly good! I'll come back here asap!

2427.review: Amazing! The baked mussels were incredible, you may need extra bread to soak up all the goodness. The duck with cranberry was cooked perfectly.  The clementine compote was so flavorful and sticky toffee pudding with whiskey creme sauce was the perfect way to end the meal.

2428.review: This place is great! service is impeccable and the food is made with precision and care. ordered the liver and beef daube and it was excellent. perfectly cooked and presented. also order the creme brule and choclate mousse. All desserts are made fresh daily!

2429.review:
This review covers two different visits:
1- After our exhausting British museum visit one afternoon, my friend and I stumbled upon this tiny restaurant and recalling that it had been packed the previous night we figured it would be a good place for a much needed dose of caffeine and sweets.  At the time we were the only customers there.  Turns out they have the best latte and Banoffee pie in town, and with a French name you'd expect nothing less- except when we got their business card we noticed that the owner is actually Persian!  Classic switcheroo!  Service was also good (by one of the owners I believe).  There we rested like weary travelers of the days of yore, connected to their free wi-fi, snapped a pic or two, and eventually headed out, highly satisfied with our experience.   4 stars
2- We returned a few days later, in the evening this time- hoping that the delicious offering on our previous visit was a prelude to amazing things to come on the dinner front.  We made a reservation and when we showed up the place was packed, which we took as a good sign, but there was an eerie tension in the air - most customers either looked irritated or were actually complaining about something - it looked as if many had been waiting for a really long time for their food to arrive.  This time, our waitress had a bit of an attitude problem, which for a small family run restaurant was a little unusual, but luckily wine came to our rescue, there was no great delay with our food and when it did arrive, while not mind-blowing, was above average.  The place definitely has an 'intimate' setting, not necessarily in the romantic sense- well perhaps that too- but it definitely feels cramped when busy, so be prepared to get fairly up close and personal with your neighbour.  As a result, it doesn't score highly for me on the comfort front.  3 stars
p.s.  nowhere is this size inconvenience more... ummm... inconvenient, than the shockingly small bathroom - absolutely horrible- it's midget sized I tell ya!  Avoid a call of nature at all costs - or perhaps try it to fully appreciate my horror!  
Overall 3.5 stars but since we can't do halves, I'll round it up to 4.

2430.review:
Savoir Faire is a great value French restaurant that remains competitive, despite the emergence of superior alternatives elsewhere. I've been here three times now for my work's Christmas lunch over the years (including 2013) and have been happy each time. 
Savoir Faire's chief strength is its impressive value and quality for the prices charged. Sure, it's been overhauled by Le Mercury on Upper Street, but it's nevertheless much better than most restaurants in its price range. Meat is tender, vegetables well-cooked and desserts satisfying. Service is friendly and accommodating, to the point of allowing us to this year stay a little longer to indulge in some post-lunch quiz action.
Here's to Christmas 2014!

2431.review:
Completely unfancy in setting and presentation, but delicious and lush in taste! The menu is amusing in that it's 2 photocopied papers stapled back-to-back. Odd to say the least. The dishes are offered as a set menu or with a few a la carte offerings.
The food was just yummy. The rest of my group had hot dishes, but I went for the unique sounding chicken salad. It was the nicest salad I think I've ever had! So many fresh and well-prepared ingredients and beautifully char-grilled chicken to top. The creme brulee wasn't the best ever, but it was tasty (and I can rarely resist a creme brulee)!  My husband had the beef bourguignon and raved about it. 
A quirky little place, but one I would be more than happy to visit again!

2432.review:
Loved it.  Thought the food was completely reasonably priced for the quality of the meal!  Also, was nice to have a break from fried food or Italian.  
It was a comfortable place to eat, and was in high demand.  Make a reservation!!

2433.review:
After reading all the great reviews about this restaurant we decided to give it a go recently. Overall an ok experience, but nothing really that stood out, hence we probably won't be going back.
So to the details... As we arrived we were seated downstairs and the whole area smells of a cellar or a damp basement, which isn't very pleasant but you quickly get used to it. One of the reviewers mentioned images of 'naked ladies' plastering the walls, which we've seen none of - a bit disappointing:)
