The service was very friendly and attentive, but the food took forever to arrive, so make sure that you allocate plenty of time if you decide to visit. We ordered a french wine (unfortunately I don't remember the name of it), which was recommended as 'owners favourite' and it was in fact quite nice and affordable.
The dishes are quite big, so even the most demanding stomachs shouldn't be left disappointed, while those with smaller tummies make sure to NOT eat the bread that's brought in at the start, I know it's fresh, with a crunchy crust and tasty, but otherwise you won't be able to finish your dishes:) 
I had lamb following recommendations of numerous reviewers and my wife had duck. Both dishes were quite nice, but they were very much like home-cooked food I haven't felt anything exquisite about them.
So to sum up, the service is great, food takes a while to arrive, the dishes are more like home-cooked rather than French exquisite cuisine.

2434.review: Wonderful lunch after a visit to the British Museum.  Reasonable prices and delicious. Very kind people and accommodating to my children. Eat here!

2435.review:
Was looking for somewhere near the British Museum to get an early dinner, and came here because it had so many good reviews on Yelp. Thanks, Yelp.
The prices are very reasonable for central London and the food was great, with generous portions (I went for the mussels and then the steak, two courses for £21). Add what turned out to be a very nice bottle of wine for £20 and it was about £70 for the two of us. We ended up staying much longer than planned, and never got the feeling we were being chivvied out of the place. I'd definitely go back here if I was in town, and I'd recommend it to others too.

2436.review: We were in London for  week and staying in a hotel near the British museum. There were not a lot of choices for dinner within walking distance so we searched YELP for help and found this one. It was just down the street from the museum so we called to book a table and they had one for us.. We strolled over and were promptly seated at a charming table by the window. It was a relaxing atmosphere and the owners were wonderful hosts making sure we were well taken care of. I had the pork belly for dinner and it was beautifully crisp on the outside and succulent on the inside. Yum! The best meal during our stay.

2437.review: We had lunch here after a visit to the British Museum.  We are foodies who have visited Paris, and the fare here is delicious.  We enjoyed the Roast Beef and Brie sandwich, the roasted Chicken with Avocado and Tarragon Aioli sandwich, and the Chicken Caesar Salad.  All three were delicious, as was our Crème Brulee and Mousse au Chocolat for dessert.  House white wine was quite good.  Prices were very reasonable for a London restaurant.  Highly recommended.

2438.review:
Yelpers. you did not steer me wrong!! Honestly, I am so happy with this place and this is coming from someone who normally isnt a huge fan of french food.  
a) Service:  We came in on a Saturday night with no reservations and were greeted with a friendly smile by a lovely lady.  She sat us within 5 minutes and actually moved our seats around to make us more comfortable.
b) Environment: This place is super cute without being pretentious with smaller tables, which I like so you can actually have a good private conversation. 
c) Food: Exceptional.  You can find as healthy or unhealthy food as you want, with lighter food options ranging from salads and bouillabaise (which incidentally I ordered), to proper  two and three course meals. I know it silly, but we actually  had warm crusty bread, which is one of my favorite things, and they DIDNT charge us -- SHOCKING!!  My husband had the baked goat cheese and tapenade and steak as a main.  My friend had the goose rillette with duck magret.  Everyone gobbled down their meals happily.  We had a carafe of the house red and followed by courvoisier and creme brulee, which I have to say delicious. 
d) Value:  All of the above was around 90 pounds. What a great deal for a VERY expensive city :)  
I will absolutely be here again with a delicious gourmet meal with beautiful presentation without the price tag.

2439.review: OK, but I really didn't understand the 5 star reviews for this place. Oddly decorated, slow service and very English French food... Meh

2440.review: Located in the heart of London's theatre district, Savoir Faire stands out for its warm and friendly atmosphere. A nice change from the abundance of large chains in London. The quirky decor is charming. I especially liked the ceiling. The food is delicious, and you can't complain about the portions. They are huge! The lamb shank was succulent with a delicious sauce, while my partner loved the rillette starter. I would recommend you go.

2441.review: French dining at its best.  The ambiance is casual and laid back, the food is fantastic and the service is great.  This is a must visit and easy to get to (especially after a visit to the British museum) I had one of the beef plates which was delicious. Their set menu is excellent value. The only thing is that it can feel a bit crowded and then around 9 ish the downstairs can get empty and you feel like it is midnight, so try to get a table upstairs.

2442.review: The food tasted homemade and delishous. We sat by the window which was nice - you could watch the street and the people outside. For me the atmosphere was quite right - this place is 20 years old and has been in private hands - a good sign with so many chains and cooperations popping up in this neighbourhood. Service was very friendly and good. I can totally recommend this place and would go back - maybe even will on my next visit in London.

2443.review:
Two thing I remember was their lamb and mussel served in escargot pan.
They were so good.
The service was good. 
Food was good and not pricy.
Service was fast.
Bread they served was yummy.
Overall it was great experience and I am so glad I picked this place.
If I ever go back to London, yes I want to go back:)

2444.review: Very nice and cost atmosphere with very good service. Had the lamb and it was very good. A place I will go back.

2445.review: Service was welcoming, helpful and prompt. As they suggest on their website, their emphasis is on value and quality. This is honest cooking from honest ingredients and served well, and it is not a fancy place. I mean to compliment them by saying their food was like "grandma's good Sunday cooking". We each had goose rilletes, then Burgundian beef stew and lamb shank both with creamy mashed potatoes, carrots and broccoli. The wine we selected was adequate, and priced well. The ambience is humble but clean and quiet enough to converse. Overall very satisfied.

2446.review: Came here for lunch after the day spent at the British Museum. The food is SPECTACULAR.  The service attentive without being hurried. The wait staff gladly made recommendations for wine that suited a variety of tastes.  The meal...from starter to coffee for dessert was spectacular!  I had the bouillabaisse and my daughter had the lamb shank.  We had goat cheese starter and split a bottle of the French pinot noir.  Will definitely try and return during our stay in London.

2447.review: We just finished a dinner at Savoir Faire and had a great time! It's tiny,completely authentic and the food is well cooked. We had the beef bourguignon which was amazing. Rosted bell peper soup was interesting but wouldn't order it again. Small place and super cozy for a wintery evening.

2448.review:
If you're looking
for a better restaurant with the same pricing but better customer service and
food come to Savoir Faire, hopefully you are fortunate and have a better
experience and itis all worth visiting. The
ambiance is nice and you should come if you like looking adifferent French
places.The prices here are very reasonable and the food was great! The food is
always top of the lineand in affordable prices.

2449.review:
We ended up stopping in here compliments of the Yelp app, which seldom steers us wrong. I'm glad we listened. It was affordable and delicious and the atmosphere was adorable. We felt comfortable just hanging out for a long while and enjoying a leisurely Sunday meal with friends. 
I had high hopes for the fried goat's cheese. It was good, but I'd give it a pass next time. Also, two people at the table ordered ceasar salads and said they tasted oddly salty. Other than those complaints, everything at the table got rave reviews from starters to mains and desserts. And the wine! Delicious. 
For location, good food, and price point, it's definitely a gem that we'd go back to anytime.

2450.review:
This place sits on the corner of a narrow but busy London three-street intersection. If you possibly can, get a seat on the street level floor in front of the picture window that looks out on that intersection, which it seems like all of London crosses thru.. It's like sitting in front of a wall-high diorama, one that always changes, with big red double-deckers rumbling thru one second, then taxi-cabs in the opposite direction the next, then more vehicles coming at you from the street opposite your corner and curving away the next, and then these bicyclist commuters pumping fearlessly away alongside these guys in this very narrow space.. and then pedestrians scurrying past you on the sidewalk..
Hey Yelp.. you led us right! Based on Yelp reviews, we dropped in here after exhausting ourselves with an afternoon in the British Museum. Like what everyone else says, it was a treat.. the *best* meal we had during our vacation (but.. well.. not that much competition really.. people are not kidding when they complain about British cuisine), reasonable prices (because we dropped in early, around 6 they gave us a special, lower-priced "Pre-show" menu, I guess with smaller portions and one course options that suited us just fine). Enjoyed our meal and wine and just sitting in front of that damn fine window looking at the world come and go so much we ended up ordering dessert and coffee.. just to stay a little longer.

2451.review: Felt like a bit of Paris dropped in the middle of London. We were looking for an authentic French meal and found it at Savoir Faire. The service was excellent, food selection to our liking. The prices were reasonable and we were able to get a reservation quickly.  The house wine went well with the meal. I will return to this restaurant during my next visit to London.

2452.review: We visited Savoir Faire recently, while staying in London and it was a wonderful experience. The prices are quite reasonable, whether you order from the pre-theatre or la carte menu. We started with salads and tomato soup, and continued with sirloin steak and salmon.  Everything was perfectly prepared, nicely presented. Dessert was chocolate mousse, and the lightest cheesecake I have ever tasted! Even the coffee was perfect. For us, it was a great way to cap off a vacation.

2453.review:
Just outside the much more expensive theatre district, this family-run little eaterie is a delight. My wife and I come here quite frequently for special occasions. 
The service is friendly but unobtrusive; the food is simply gorgeous (not too much and not too little--so you can just about squeeze in three courses); the house red (available in 4 carafe sizes) is eminently quaffable; and the proprietor, an ex-airline pilot, is friendly and attentive. It is the perfect place to sit and eat and talk as you watch the traffic go by on a rainy evening.
The mussels are always worth having; last time we tried something different though, and the asparagus starter was amazing. The steak entrecôte is great.

2454.review: Amazing food. Amazing service. I made a reservation for here for my birthday with several guests and they were incredibly accommodating to my unknown exact number of guests and need to pre-order so we could get in & out in 1 hr to make at 7:30 show. They also had great wine recommendations and delicious, interesting food.

2455.review:
Cute bistro on New Oxford Street with a great value dinner menu (just under £20 for two courses, £15.50 for an entrecote steak, frites and sald).  The interior is pretty quirky and it definitely exudes that family-run feeling that few places in London possess these days.
I went for the entrecote option (rare) - I thought it was ok, although noticeably tough.  The flavour was decent though, and the chips were good.  However, whilst eating, I just couldn't help but think of Le Mercury in Angel which has a similar MO and is simply fantastic (and cheaper).  However, I will return here at some point and try some of the other dishes on the menu as I'm aware that the entrecote item may not be treated with the same respect as the other dishes.  Update forthcoming...

2456.review: Euh, zis is simply my canteen when I am in London. As good as home. Ok nearly as good as home (in case my wife reads this), always better than if it's me cooking at home. You can't go wrong with the Boeuf Bourguignon or the Lamb Shank. Zey've added a fig appetiser which is worth trying. Every dish is tastefully executed and presented. Deserts not quite as good but if in addition zey had a patisserie chef zey'd have to raise ze price, so happy to keep it as it is. Done my best to make it clear zis review is coming from a Frenchman...

2457.review: We were at British museum and we were looking for a place to eat. We notice there was Pret A Manger everywhere but we wanted something unique in London. Luckily yelpers recommend this place La Bistro Savoir Faire because it turned out to be a hidden gem. The curb appeal definitely does not represent the food they serve. To be honest I probably wouldn't eat at this restaurant without the yelp reviews. Their menu is very simple. The guys had the delicious burger with fries which was huge and cooked just right. The girls had lasagna that came with the best seafood soup. If only I had the recipe! I was told London doesn't have good food but Savoir Faire was delicious.

2458.review: Had dessert here twice while visiting London. Best lemon tart!

2459.review:
Had a really nice dinner there.
The service was very friendly and attentive. My only gripe is that the French style of steak is thin and slightly tough compared with the meat in the US. But the sauce it was served with tasted great.

2460.review:
So we were at the British Museum and looked at Yelp for something close and this place had 4 stars with 90 reviews so we went and boy are we glad we did.  The foie gras was top notch and for dinner the beef borgunone (spell check does not work) was perfect with the fat rendered just right.  The duck was probably great for a non duck conniseure, but it is one of my favorite dishes so i judge harshly if not exactly right.  Overall the writing on the ceiling is entertaining and the atmosphere is laid back and comfortable, the staff were very polite and as you can see our experience is rated 5 stars.
I definitely suggest trying this place, if we are in the area and in the mood for French we will be back, most likely the next time we are at the museum.

2461.review:
Perhaps one of the worst things about Yelp is the expectations. I was expecting a lot out of this place from all the reviews, so I brought my sister here. I can't seem to remember what she ordered, but I had the escargot and a lamb dish. Both were decent, but were really not that great. The lamb was too chewy and the escargot was also lacking some hit-the-spot Frenchy goodness. 
Nonetheless, it is nicely located in central London and has a nice restaurant setting. I guess you could give it a try if you're itchin' for French food within the area, but personally, I wouldn't itch to go back here again.
I also might want to add how funny it was when my (also American) sister asked for a glass of iced tea. The response she received was a facial expression which read "what the hell? ICED tea?!," which obviously came from the English waitress who couldn't understand why on earth one would want their tea ICE COLD. The lack of frigidity to my drinks was definitely something I had to get used to whilst living in London :)

2462.review:
We went there on the very strong recommendation from our hotel as "the place to go" before heading off to the theater. How right they were.
First, the food. It was superbly prepared using obviously fresh ingrediants. Presentation was very nicely done. This is not some big chain establishment with a million things on the menu but a small, family run place that has a selection that is both authentic and just plain delicious. 
As mentioned, the restaurant is not some huge chain so reservations are in order. We had a small table with a setting that my wife and I would call romantic. This is the kind of place you go if you want an authentic bistro experience. We might not have gone in had we not known about it from the hotel but there is a reason they have a steady stream of regulars.
As for the people, our service was top notch and very attentive. Max, the owner, spent time chatting with us. Leaving aside that he is fascinating in his own right, that he visited with us is and wanted to make sure they were meeting our expectations, which they far exceeded, is a reflection of how we found everyone there to be. Our server was especially helpful for our dinner selections and she was very attentive during the evening.
I think it simple to sum up our experience. If you want a large chain menu and food, don't go here. If you want superb food with obviously hand picked fresh ingredients and expertly prepared dishes, don't go anywhere else. Max is terrific, the staff is terrific and our total experience was simply perfect. This unmistakably is a gem.

2463.review: Wonderful!  This place is pretty ideal for a romantic dinner for two.  The food is always top-notch while the prices aren't crazy.  The service can be a bit smug occasion but if you feel like a nice long dinner with lots of wine then this is a great place to go.

2464.review: We ate a lovely meal here on a Sunday evening. The food was delicious and original. The service, contrary to some other reviews, was prompt. I suspect that we were served by one of the owners, who was charming. In London, at this price, a gem.

2465.review: Hmm, maybe I ordered the wrong thing. The chicken, Pimms, and the staff were fine, maybe I was a little too American or something. The upstairs was very pleasant, and the downstairs looked like a cool place to hang out if you had a large group. Had some Pernod because it felt like the right thing to do. Will def go back but not really in a hurry. Booking via the OpenTable widget above was lovely.

2466.review:
Savoir Fair is a good place to eat if you are near the British Museum.  The atmosphere is OK but dated with red plastic tablecloths and stark un-curtained windows.  The food is good and the prices are very reasonable for London.  A nice wine list but the house wine by the glass or carafe was very drinkable.  A choice of a two or three course meal was made easy for me.  Good starters, solid entree and some great desserts.  They had the best (strongest) coffee I had in 
London.at
 a restaurant.  I would go back again

2467.review: There's an honesty about this French restaurant that is instantly noticed upon entering the tightly packed dining space. You'll be warmly welcomed, but without the sickly sweet cloying of some restaurants. Service is matter of fact and polite by staff who are obviously comfortable within the relaxed atmosphere. I can only speak for one dish on the menu, a dish that shall not be forgotten any time soon, the beef bourguignon. Truely a comforting experience, Heartily recommended.

2468.review: Dessert is great, meals are cheaper in lunch time.

2469.review: Unbelievably delicious appetizer and entree (I had duck as an entree), but the lime dessert pie was not good at all. Disregarding the dessert, the restaurant is lovely, service is amazing and multilingual, and food is delicious!

2470.review: Check your bill carefully, and count your change!   Came on at 17:30, had a nice meal, and obviously had to get going for a show, I had my cash out.  Gave us a bill that was 11£ to much, over charge was on a glass of wine.   Could have been a simple error but three servers were hunched over the area where my bill was being prepared.  There were only three tables of diners in the place.

2471.review: A sweet little French bistro in the heart of London offering a la carte and 2-course dinners. The foie gras was great, the duck succulent, and for dessert, sticky toffee pudding (not so French, but that's the beauty of being in London). Everything was reasonably priced, especially the house wine. My only complaint is that the pudding was a little dry.

2472.review: If you're looking for lovely gourmet French cuisine in a romantic little restaurant oozing with character, look no further than this surprisingly affordable central London gem.  I've been there three times now - it's a favourite romantic dinner date for my boyfriend and me - and will go there many more times, whenever I can come up with a good excuse!  One of the things I love the most is that even though the food is excellent and French, the atmosphere manages to be romantic without being pretentious.  The waiters keep an eye on you without making you feel like an uncultured heathen.  My biggest problem with it is there are always more things on the menu that I want than I can possibly consume!

2473.review: Excellent as always. My 15 year old son ordered a hamburger. Even it was excellent.

2474.review: Great food! Went there with family and we all enjoyed our food. Waitress was nice enough to give us the special even though time was up. It is quite refreshing to eat European portion size. It is a few blocks away from touristic area, so that is another plus.

2475.review: Very good place with authentic French cuisine! Highly recommended *****

2476.review: Cozy French place with good service and tasty food.

2477.review: Great food, nice service, small bistro and very reasonably priced. Not a fast place to eat, but have a glass of wine while you wait. The pan fried Foie Gras was yummy.

2478.review: Great value!  Offers a 2-course set menu for a little over £20 with lots of variety (starters and mains). I opted out on the starter this time, but the mains on their own are a good deal as well. Had the slow roasted pork belly which was perfectly crispy, meaty and fatty all at the same time, although perhaps a bit too saucy. For desert, split the banoffee pie with a friend - more banana than toffee, but the crust was crumbly and it was a nice way to top off the meal!

2479.review: Excellent little unassuming French place. Got the courgette and aubergine stuffed with small prawns... which was taste perfection. Then I got the pork belly, which was too much food and also the glaze was too sweet. The service was excellent. Good value as well.

2480.review: We had the garlic mussels, goat cheese salad, broccoli soup as starters and they were all good especially the garlic mussels! We then had the lamb shank, fish of the day and sea bass and again they were all delicious. I recommend this place for a good and reasonably priced meal.

2481.review:
You know, sometimes where you really look forward to try a place, it really lets you down.  This is what happened with Savoir Faire.
I am not sure whether it was the terrible weather or the fact I just came back from Paris, but I kinda expected bistro food at Parisienne prices and Parisienne quality.  That, unfortunately, Savoir Faire was not.  The price atmosphere and level of service was about right, but the food was a little off the mark.
It was also very slow, and who wants to wait ages for their food on what was perhaps the first real wintery evening of 2009?

2482.review: What a happy coincidence we found this great place for lunch! Welcoming and warm, food was excellent, served quickly and attentively. Beef Daube and duck leg with lentils; expertly cooked and served very hot. Well done!

2483.review:
What with all the five-star reviews of Savoir Faire here on Yelp, I was expecting to be served up a loin of unicorn with a side of fairy-dusted mash.
But it was not to be.  The food I received was thoroughly average.  The wine was potent and flowing, though, and the amount of time between courses was incredibly drawn out (and filled with more wine drinking).  So I wasn't entirely upset by the mediocrity of the meal at the time.  My fig and cheese starter was nothing special, and my fish main was overseasoned but cooked well.  I was too intoxicated by the time my dessert arrived to remember much about it.
In the end, I left with the impression that the courses were actually quite small for the price coupled with the inattentive execution of the dishes.  And I was kind of hungry.

2484.review:
Not far from the hotel I was staying in.  I passed this place a number of times as I wandered around London.  It was not until these glowing reviews on Yelp! that I decided to give it a try.
I had their 2 course special (a steal at ~17 pounds).  I started with their smoked salmon and asparagus starter.  It was beautifully presented and delicious.  I followed it with their rib-eye with Bearnaise.  It came with Potatoes au gratin (which I normally do not like but these were good) and some steamed veggies.
I washed it down with a half liter of their house red wine (also delish).  All in all a very good meal.  One of the best I have had in London.

2485.review:
It is a tad unfair to review a French restaurant after spending a week driving around the south of France in a convertible gorging oneself on French food and wine, but that's the situation I find myself in.  One must persevere in such conditions, although I suspect the juxtaposition of eating in the south of France with eating in the middle of the tourist district of London is why my star rating is lower than others'.
Savoir Faire is reasonably priced by London standards; 2 entrees, 2 mains, 1 dessert, and a carafe of house red cost under 50 quid.  I was underwhelmed by the food, however.  I had the beef carpaccio and the lamb shanks, and while both were fine, they weren't exactly screaming with flavor.  My co-eater had a tarte tatin for desert which was the least genuine tarte tatin I have ever seen in my life:  it looked like someone had taken apple sauce and placed it on top of pastry, and then covered the whole lot in custard.  Maybe it was designed for 80 year olds who had lost their teeth and couldn't chew?
There are some pluses though.  The cafe has a nice family feel and it was packed when I went which is always a good thing.  Also the waitresses actually spoke French which meant I could flirt with them in the language of love.  Normally waitresses in London speak Polish which I don't speak and is also the language of sausages, not love.
Overall not bad and if you were going to the theatre and needed a quick dinner beforehand you wouldn't be disappointed.  I don't think I'd take a date here.

2486.review: Excellent casual French restaurant!  I had the mussels for first course... out of this world!  Then moved to the sea bass entree... very good.  Service was friendly and more proactive than many places in London.  Atmosphere is intimate, yet the floor to ceiling windows around the entire front makes it feel like you are sitting on the street in this busy part of London.

2487.review:
Yelp, you are my new best friend.  This place is so unbelievably well-priced given its location and the quality of food they serve.  Actually, it's unbelievably well-priced even if it wasn't right in Central London.  There's really not much to say other than that Savoir Faire serves tasty, authentic French food without the fouf and the miserable service.
My husband and I each had a delicious starter and a main, and we were so pleased with our two-course dinner that we added dessert.  We asked our (very friendly) server for suggestions, and were thrilled with her recommendations: a delicious mango and basil sorbet, and the bannoffee pie, complete with a crumbly digestive biscuit crust.  Heaven on a plate.
We will be back.  We will be bringing our friends back.  But please, don't tell too many other people about Savoir Faire, because I want to be able to get a table next time I am craving their lamb shank.

2488.review:
Well Savoir Faire...you were a bit of a letdown. Not in a "Oh my gosh, I am going to see that Blair Witch Project film, it looks great!" way. More like "The last Family Guy season wasn't as funny as the others, was it?" 
The food was pretty good, but not up to what I had heard it could be. Although tasty enough, steaks were stringy and fatty. That lost a star from the review right there! I also felt that starters were lacking in portion size. Overall though, I did really enjoy myself, but that was probably due to the stellar company I was in! 
The ambience was pretty good in the restaurant, but décor was a little rough in places. Service was pretty slow and inattentive, but to be fair, this was possibly because we were tucked out of the way in the basement, like a pack of grouchy live-in mother-in-laws. 
All in all, I had a wonderful night, but that standard of Savoir Faire is more comparable to some of the 'Red Café' establishments around town, as opposed to being a newly discovered gem for me.

2489.review:
The food was DELICIOUS!!!! really really tasty.
between the three of us we had the fried goatcheese with stewed apples, the pumpkin soup (which was spicy and just perfect for the cool weather), the gnochi with sundried tomatoes and melted cheese, and a pumpkin/goat cheese salad where there were very hefty helpings of goat cheese. The ceasar salad was a staple and the stewed beef with mashed potatoes was perfectly savory. i LOVED!!!
we got one bottle of wine for about 17 quid, and entire dinner cost about 65 quid (tip included) so really affordable and delivers great taste for the cash.
The lowdown
- there are two floors for dining: ground level and lower level. the restaurant is situated on a corner, so on the ground level you can do good people watching and have access to the bar. Lower level is cozy, dare I say romantic and the walls are adorned with oil murals of tasteful nudity and big mirrors here and there. 
- the bathrooms are cavernous and are truly tiny, but cute. To enter the women's restrooms there are literally 3 different doors. The only time i felt claustrophobic was in there.
- there is NO music in the background. I didn't like that, and that is part of the reason why i took the 5th star out .
- the crowd is diverse in terms of age, so don't expect to go there and find collegiates in mini skirts, but rather groups of people wanting to have a laid back conversation and a good time without having any use for background encouragement. 
- I suggest you go with your partner for a quiet night out, or with parents. not the place to go for loud fun.
FOOD delicious!!! i will go back : ))

2490.review:
Where do I even begin to describe this fantastic meal? 
Maybe it was the fact that we had a 2 course meal for only £16.90? 
Maybe it was the fact that they had a half carafe of the house wine for £8.00?
Maybe it was because the food was so god damn tasty!?!!!?
This place is adorable, it seems small at first, but there is a whole other floor in the basement. It's the type of place where you could sit with a glass of wine outside with a good book, and just stay there all day. Or it's a place where you can enjoy a fabulously good meal.
Joe and I opted for the 2 course meal. I went with a goat cheese appetizer that was absolutely fantastic! For my meal I went with the pork belly plate and holy crap, it was some of the best stuff I have ever had in my life. With some mashed potatoes and apple sauce compote, my mouth is watering just thinking about that fantastic meal. Sopped it up with some soft french bread, this meal was definitely a highlight of the whole trip.
For dessert Joe and I shared the lemon tart. Again, just awesome. Perfect mesh of sour and sweet, with a little bit of crunch from the crust.
This meal was an absolute STEAL, with the amount of food we got and the overall tastiness, when I'm back in London I'm coming back here, and so should you.

2491.review:
Beautiful.
It's difficult to go back to eating regular, everyday food after dining here. Perhaps my meal was laced with crack and I need another hit. Seriously, I could develop a habit off their mussel starter, and I don't even like seafood that much, but it was so perfectly flavored. Dip the bread into the remaining pesto from the mussels and I guarantee there's nothing better. Ambiance was lovely as well, I enjoyed the quotes written on the ceiling; they could be great conversation starters on a first date.

2492.review:
I love Yelp. And I love it even more for directing me to the wonderful and divine Savoir Faire. This restaurant is like a breath of fresh country-air in the centre of a busy, bustling and let's be honest, slightly dirty city. Family owned and family run, this is a great slice of rustic French cuisine. 
I went here with a group of nine on a Friday night. Our table was ready, our waitress was superb and we were made to feel really welcome. The wine list was a hit with my partner (the aspiring amateur sommelier) and we kicked off the evening with a lovely Riesling from Alsace, called Rifile. This was so good (not too sweet, and perfectly balanced), and I even went to my parents local wine cavern Byrne's of Clitheroe, to find some more bottles of the stuff. Fab. 
I went for the foie gras - wonderfully rich and perfectly matched with the apple and brioche. For my main I went for the Sea Bass which was again, exquisitely cooked and the tomato and pepper sauce delicate and flavoursome. Between nine of us we hit most of the items on the 2 courses for £16 deal. Bargain. Other highlights included the salmon gateaux and the rich duck dish. Yum. We were so relaxed we even took in some desserts and coffee. My friend even venturing to try some grappa!!!
I did also venture into the small private dining area as I was intrigued by the murals. Now, I thought from previous reviews that the murals were hand painted BY Lautrec, now I'm no Art Historian, but they looked pretty new to be around 100 years old. So, I think they're probably a copy and homage at best. Still pretty though!
Quite simply, Savoir Faire is great, fab and brilliant all at the same time. A perfect place to chill with friends whilst sampling some top notch French food. This isn't haute cuisine, but all portions are generous, tasty and definitely value for money. I'll be back in a flash, as soon as I persuade some more friends to go, judging by their emails the next day about how fab the food was, I don't think it will be long.

2493.review:
This is a special place to take your loved one for a romantic meal. The restaurant is a family run business and you can tell by the care that is put into both service and food. The decor is also lovely with an ambiance that makes me feel within the renaissance era. The food is fantastic and quite authentically French. What is surprising is the price. For what is one of the better dining experiences in London, this restaurant is very affordable. At under £20 for a main meal this is excellent value.
I hear there are secret tunnels within the restaurant that you can dine in for a really exclusive feel. I will be back again to try this out.

2494.review:
I adore this place. I've been several times, and have never been disappointed.
My first time there was with a group of 6 on a Friday night--we had no reservations and the entire lower ground floor was reserved for a party of 40. Rather than shoo us out, the friendly (understandably flustered) wait staff seated us in a cavern-like room behind the curtain, under the stairs. (My friends and I affectionately refer to this room as the lair.)   Because it was such a busy night, the kitchen was a bit slow, but we were kept happy with the well-priced (not so bad) carafes of house red (their old-fashioned pimms is also mixed quite well). 
The food was (later I found out, always is) amazing--the lamb dishes and goat cheese appetizers are my favorites, and the desserts were wonderful (and good for sharing).   After we were finished, the waitresses (probably exhausted), let us sit for as long as we wanted to finish our wine. 
I would recommend this place to anyone--for a group, a date, or even by yourself because it's that freaking good.

2495.review:
Whoa there - 5 stars, are you sure?
Fantastic setting - check
Great service - check
Mouth watering food - check
Reasonably priced - check
Left venue with a high alcohol blood level - check
Seriously tasty food, all French themed and beautifully cooked. A little too central for my liking but that's only because I want it in my hood. Bum!

2496.review:
This place evoked so many feelings in me, some contradictory.
Apprehension. One of the first places where i decided to go solely based on yelp reviews (and i had 3 vegetarian friends with me)
Elation. The food was so good ... so tasty. I loved the foie gras ... and the steak ... yumm :)
Wonder. I am used to French food in London being pretty expensive. It came to be 21 quids per head ... very very reasonable.
Disappointment. This is a very veg-unfriendly place. There was only one vegetarian option among the main course ... gnocchi. My friends didn't like it and they ended up having a horrible dinner, made worse by the fact that i enjoyed my share of the food. So i ended up having to pay for all of them :(
So this turns out to be one of those restaurants where i would like to come often but i won't be able to since i can't bring my friends along. But maybe someday when i am all alone ...

2497.review: Exceptional value, and great food.  The Goose Rillettes entree was particularly delicious, but all dishes were prepared thoughtfully and of high quality.  It's a small place so reservations are a must.

2498.review:
Sacrebleu! Savoir Faire is more French than a baguette french kissing a croissant over a bottle of Bordeaux.
And I'm not talking Walt Disne-fied French. (Let's just say that the singing candelabras named Lumiere and the les poissons loving chefs were absent from the experience.)
Humble and unpretentious, Savoir Faire has been one of my favourite London dining experiences to date. Not because of fancy views or exquisite menus, but because these folks are living their dream and doing it authentically -- and that is beyond admirable. 
Savoir Faire is not a chain nor a franchise, but rather a 10-year old family run restaurant.  It was so family run that when I called for a reservation, I had to spell out the words "E-i-g-h-t P-M" so the French speaking host could decipher my American accent. 
Each table gets a basket of freshly baked bread, every menu item is made 100% in house, and they source only the best-wines-for the-money. In fact, the entire experience was quite affordable -- a two course meal for £16 seemed like stealing.
On that note, I stole the grilled mushroom with melted mozzarella and roasted pepper AND the Nile perch with roasted garlic and lime beurre blanc. Others indulged in grilled mussels, pan fried foie gras, lacquered duck magret, treacle-glazed pork belly, wild boar and mushroom terrine ... it's agonizing typing this out because it makes me want to turn around and go right back. 
Really, the experience was perfect. Quaint, unpretentious, delicious, affordable -- and to give credit where credit is due: all thanks to Tom E's talk thread suggestion!  ;) God, I love Yelp! Especially when it allows me to find hidden gems like Savoir Faire.

2499.review: Great food, and the set menu prices were really decent. The waitress even helped us find the cheapest combination for everyone to get what they wanted.

2500.review:
I'm sad to say that my romance with Yelp has been on the rocks recently. Don't get me wrong, she treats me right- it's me that has been the lazy one not putting the effort into our relationship. She give, give ,gives, telling me where all the best restaurants are and tracking my favourite reviewers. Like an ever faithful lover, she's always there when I walk in through the door at the end of the day, tired and emotional with no energy to type. And what do I do in return? Skim the cream of the crop for reviews before sneaking off to...watch TV! 
Well I'm a changed woman now. Savoir Faire has made me see the error of my ways. A restaurant this good needs to be Yelped with tender love and respect. Finding places like this is what made me fall for Yelp so hard in the first place and, it made me realise, I know we're meant to be together, through the good times and the bad...
So anyway, to the restaurant. Where to start? With the food? The incredible sweet cinnamon glazed duck breast with an oh so tiny cube of dauphinoise? Or the phenomenal (and pungent) mussels floating in garlic butter?
Or maybe you'll get a better sense of Savoir Faire if I tell you about the wine. Our fruity Rioja was the hussy of vinos. She went with all of us, snogging us hard before leaving us desperate for more. For the second time in this review- I was in love (so I wear my heart on my sleeve!).
If I've left you in any doubt, Savoir Faire is an amazing restaurant. Everything about the place is as French as you could imagine, from the staff to the decor. Stunning Lautrec murals are painted across the walls in the back room and baskets of home made bread arrive at the tables with the minimum of fuss. The prices here are incredible too. Two courses of tasty, tasty French fare cost only £16 and I am in no doubt that it was worth every penny. 
After this rambling review all that's left for me to say is Yelp, I'm sorry. I'll never take you for granted again.

2501.review:
Savoir Faire, C'est magnifique!  This cafe deserves high marks. Well-priced, food is anything but typical.  Great wines, unsnobby
atmosphere, lovely private dining with murals of Henri de Toulouse- Lauterac. 
I love family run business. Which gives you the special feeling of being part of their family. And to sharing their piece of love to you. 
Entrecote steaks, is known as rib steak. My favorite steak is their
best Australian rump steak.  Everything is the menu is worth trying. Be adventurous!! 
Reservations is recommended for large groups.

2502.review:
After telling as many of my friends as possible about Savoir Faire, I still don't know why most people have never heard if it.
It's a small ground floor French restaurant with a dungeon-like cellar perfect for groups. The cellar consists of the entrances to several former smuggling tunnels dug to take moonshine and stuff into Soho from outside the old city limits. These tunnels are mostly blocked now but the entrances make for wondereful private dining alcoves and each has been fitted with a large table and candlelight. If you are thinking of somewhere good to dine with a big group, then think no more - a private tunnel table at Savoir Faire is ideal.
Did I mention yet that the walls of some of the alcoves are painted with murals by Toulouse Lautrec?
Or how about that George Orwell used to come here to write his weekly Observer column?
On top of that location and history stuff, it's also an enjoyable meal. French food in London can run so ridiculously expensive for tiny portions with an astronomical wine list and snotty waiters - not here. The food is well-priced French classics, hearty yet elegant, the wine is carafe-served and affordable and the staff seem to be a decent bunch. It's like they want to break every stereotype for french restaurants.
The final bonus of this great find is that it's right close to The End and is a great place to start a big night out with friends.

2503.review: Found on Yelp and were not disappointed.  So close to British Museum that this makes the perfect stop for a lovely and not touristy dinner.  We had made reservations on line that were honored and service was great. We were able to enjoy good wine have a delicious French dinner and make our play on time!  Very reasonable for London.  You will love this charming spot!

2504.review:
3.8 maybe?
Thought I'd go here for my last meal before departing London, considering all the amazing reviews.  Came with a group of 7, they seated us in a very tiny and adorable underground cove area that was secluded from the rest of the restaurant.
Here's the breakdown:
Atmosphere: 5
The place is adorable, service is great, and when you're there, it almost feels as if you're not in London anymore, but a quaint restaurant off an alley somewhere in a French town.
Value: 5
The prix-fixed 2-course menu for 16.50 is amazing in terms of the variety that they provide for you for both courses -- appetizers ranging from asparagus salad to gazpacho to steak carpaccio to mussels and goat cheese; mains from braised lamb to duck with red wine sauce/chocolate to beef bourguinon to perch (our party ordered all of these, btw).
Food: 3.5
For what you pay for, this place is definitely worth it. In terms of the food alone, however, I wasn't all that impressed. The menu sounded promising, but I was actually disappointed with how the food turned out -- not that it was bad, it was just average to good at best -- not quite up there with the consistent 5-star reviews. My steak carpaccio was seared far too much; the sauces for the duck and the lamb tasted the same to me, the duck had too much fat and not enough crisp. Everything else was fine, but not spectacular.
Bottom line -- I like it, and it's definitely worth checking out, but doesn't quite go up there with my favorite places to eat in London.

2505.review: When I'm in London, I spend a lot of time at the British Museum and I'm voraciously hungry on the conclusion of my visits.  I avoid any other eating establishment on the perimeter of the museum grounds and eagerly make the short walk to Savoir Faire because their delicious fresh food, in an environment that is very cozy and soothing, revives the stomach and the soul.

2506.review: On a Sunday afternoon when many french restaurants are getting thin Savoir Faire shined. I found and went here based on a couple very favorable Yelp! reviews and was not disappointed. Wonderful, unpretentious ambiance and a delightful original menu. I had a smoked fish chowder full of flavor to start and a butternut squash risotto that was wonderful. An off the menu tarte tartin closed. R. had soup and then then a very nicely done sea bass. Kids were delighted with omelette du fromage and burger & frites.  The wine menu did present a bit more of a challenge than I would have expected with too many single grape new world wines but we were happy with our french bordeaux, young but a nice light taste that fit our fish and risotto. This could well turn into a sunday afternoon fav, especially at the price.

2507.review: We enjoyed our meal here at 6 pm on a Monday night.  My husband ordered from the pre-theatre/lunch menu and i went for the regular dinner prix fixe. The menu had some interesting and unusual items that would not be found at a chain restaurant.  Our starters were lamb kidneys in mustard sauce and mussels prepared like snails.   I didn't really like the latter more than the usual types of mussel dishes but enjoyed the novel approach.  My husband was happy with his bouillabaisse.  My lamb shanks were very tender.  The tarte tartin was less tasty than others I have had, with a rather soggy bottom crust.  Overall it was a good experience with attentive service and reasonable prices.  I would give it a 3.5 ratting if I could. Maybe it even deserves 4 stars, not sure.

2508.review:
My wife and I went to Savoir Faire on the basis of the 4.5 star Yelp rating. Thinking we were in a cosmopolitan city like London, the rating meant a lot to us in selecting the restaurant.  We were very disappointed.
We started with the mussels which were grilled and then served with a pernod butter garlic sauce.  The mussels were the best of the dinner and we rated them a 7 on a 10 point scale.  Things went down hill quickly from there.
The second course was the warm goat cheese and fig salad on arugula ("rocket") bed.  It was mediocre, despite our high expectations.  It could have had more arugula which would have added to the experience, and fresher  rather than wilted.
The third (main course) was the Entrocote Steak Frites.  We ordered it medium rare.  It was cooked to the right temperature, but the steak was as tough as shoe leather, despite the chef pounding it for a long time before cooking it.  The french fries were okay.
For dessert, we had Vanoffee which was a pie with toffee and banana and whipped cream on a graham cracker shell.  It was good but not spectacular.
The service was pretty good and we had no complaints about the serve staff.  
Finally, the ambiance was just fair.  No table cloths, paper napkins, etc.
In summary, Savoir Faire does not deserve more than a 2 star rating.  It is inexpensive, but very average.

2509.review: Tasty French food at a reasonable price. It was a busy Saturday night, but service was still good.  Was a great find for dinner.

2510.review: Cutest little french bistro in central London. Two of us were there for dinner on a Sunday night and it gets really busy so try and make a reservation ahead of time. Dinner comprised of a set menu of two courses with a range of options for the starter and mains. We had the grilled mussels and pan fried foie gras as our appetizers and they were both excellent. For our mains, we had the fillet of sea bass and the braised lamb shank. Although the lamb was good, the sea bass was definitely better - so good! Tried the creme brulee for dessert but I thought it was pretty average. There is also an extensive wine list to choose from. There can be a little bit of a wait for the food to arrive when the restaurant is really busy, but it's not excessively slow by any means. The food is excellent, the atmosphere is cozy, the decor is quirky and fun (there's writing on the ceiling!) and the service is friendly and efficient - definitely worth a visit.

2511.review: Good food, good service and reasonably priced. Savoir Faire is a lot more friendly than most French restaurants in London, and feels better for it.

2512.review: A block from Tottenham Court station. Their slogan is "Affordable gourmet food," and it's true. I had a carafe of tempranillo, fig and goat cheese starter, authentic beef bourgignon, espresso and chocolate mousse. £33 isn't cheap, but for that meal is affordable, because it all *was* gourmet. The decor is fun and colorful, the waitresses friendly and authentically French. It's possible to spend less there, for less dinner: the tempranillo was £11 of my total. But the mousse was especially good. :)

2513.review:
Yum! I had the Figs and Blue Cheese with Prosciutto for my app and the Gnocchi with sun-dried tomatoes for my main entree with a tasty little creme brulee for dessert. I must say over all, delicious. 
My 4 star rating comes from the service. We sat downstairs and as another review stated, we felt a little forgotten about. We were there to have a nice relaxing dinner, but by the time we were ready for the check we waited almost 30 minutes and then started to hunt for our server upstairs!

2514.review: We ate here before the theater. This is a nice but simple  place with good food and good service.  I would certainly return.

2515.review:
No disappointments here, as always, absolutely remarkable cuisine and ambiance. The staff bend over backwards to make sure your meals are most satisfactory and they don't skimp on portions either.
A wonderful place to take guests or just to enjoy a bottle of wine and escargot!

2516.review: Amazing food, huge portions, dirt cheap prices. My new London fav.

2517.review: I have eaten at Savoir Faire on and off for many years and when I am in London this is always worth a stop. Visitors I have brought here have never been disappointed. I favor the baked escargot, duck and the house red wine. Enjoy!

2518.review: I struggle to give this place a five, but it is solid and one of the few places in London where you get a lot for your money.  We were seated at the front of the restaurant, and every time someone walked through the door, you would hear a dinging noise go off.  A bit annoying.  The atmosphere is great and the waitresses were very nice and always smiling--what a treat.  The food was good , but nothing mind-blowing or spectacular.  It was an enjoyable meal, but nothing I am rushing to go back for.

2519.review: very nice little place. I had the rib eye steak which was delicious. My friend's lamb shank was nice too. We shared a goose rillette (nice as well) and a coffee brûlée which was amazing.

2520.review: Interesting place. It's a great deal, particularly considering the location. The food's average-to-good, but definitely nothing to write home about - classic bistro cooking, the flaws being e.g. too tough beef bourguignon, lack of flavour in a couple of the dishes. However, a few things let it down. First, the service, while friendly, is slow and inattentive (whenever we needed one of the waiting staff, there was no-one to be seen and I spent more time than I liked trying to catch their eye). Second, the decor is basic but a few things need some touching up, and e.g. the cutlery/glassware look very much like they belong in a school canteen. Third, the wine selection is very ordinary, which is shame for a French restaurant - we had one of the more expensive bottles and, while inoffensive, it wasnt very interesting. I'll definitely bear it in mind for the future, but you won't find me going out of my way to come back, and especially not with a date or someone I'm trying to impress. There are much better restaurants in this kind of category (Comptoir Gascon instantly springs to mind, as does Le Mercury).

2521.review:
Whenever I'm in London this is always my first choice place to go to eat. It used to be a Pierre-Victiore and has kept the cheap bistro fixed price menu ethos. At two courses for £10 the menu provides great value and often contains some exciting ingrdients such as duck breast or sucking pig. The staff are casual but attentive and friendly. It is often busy has a vibrant atmosphere.
Another plus point of the restaurant is the way that they respond to a problem. We had an awful meal there (on one of our 30 odd visits) and they could not do enough to put it right. 
Without wanting to sound too sentimental this restaurante has been part of some great memories for me and everyone should give it a go. Some of the best value food in London.

2522.review: Just came back from dinner at Savior Faire, and I am still thinking about the food we enjoyed so much. For starter, I had fried goat cheese with caramelized pears. My main entree was duck with caramelized oranges, carrots, and zucchini, and potato gratin. The food melt in my mouth. The flavor was scrumptious!! I would recommend that place to anyone who visits London. Our experience at that restaurant was very positive.

2523.review: Loved the authentic French cuisine and the price was reasonable too.  Can't beat that!

2524.review:
Well, it was our last night in London and we were looking for a suitable restaurant.  Being the Yelper that I am, I set about with researching.  We have some picky eaters in our group, so that added another element of difficulty.  As a bunch of Francophiles, I thought a French restaurant would be a good choice.  Based on the preceeding Yelp reviews, we finally settled on Savoir Faire.  I was intrigued by the basement grotto, so when I made the reservation on Open Table, I requested that we be seated down there.  This was good because we got a bit raucous and silly as the meal progressed.  
Well, we were not disappointed by Savoir Faire in the least. We all ordered the two course, prix fixe menu.  I began with the roasted figs accompanied by stilton and prosciutto.  They were just lovely!  Then I tucked into the magret de carnard, but I felt that the duck was a bit over-cooked (Erin agreed).  I also had a nibble of Maeve's beef bourguignon.  Delicious!  The gnocchi that Courtney had was a bit odd looking, but she said it was good.  Chris and Miguel both had the Creole chicken and they cleaned their plates.  We also had about 5 bottles of some white wine (Chardonnay, I believe).  For desert we ordered a couple creme-brulees, the banoffee pie (my favorite!), and a very sad chocolate mousse (more like a pudding cup).  The wait-staff was nice, but we often felt a bit neglected at times. I guess that's what you get for hiding away in a cave.  The murals on the walls also provided some amusement for our group and some of them were pretty risque! Overall, a tres bon experience!

2525.review: I stumbled across this place about 10 years ago and have been regularly returning. Very well prepared French dishes at remarkably reasonable prices. My favorite has always been the Duck Magret with on sauteedd Leeks and Potato with Orange and Balsamic Sauce. Always nicely done. If you're heading to Shaftsbury theatres they have wonderful pre-theatre specials and will see to it that you are out in time for the show.

2526.review: What can I say that hasn't been said?  This place is absolutely charming.  It manages a balance between a cozy cafe and a more sophisticated feel.  The painted murals on the walls make the small room seem larger and friendly.  We came in for a very late lunch and the owner (we presume) greeted us immediately, made a very good wine suggestion and defeated every stereotype of snooty French right away.  Our waitress was a bit cold, to be honest, and seemed irritated with us when she brought us the wrong wine...but really she wasn't RUDE, just not the smiley sort that another Yelper had mentioned.  We had steak with chips and salad...simple food that didn't seem entirely French in my mind, but was prepared so beautifully that I can't wait to go back.  Excellent value for money!

2527.review: Excellent French food, friendly and efficient service, nice atmosphere without being large or noisy, great all-around experience

2528.review: Good meat, nicely sized portions, sauvignon blanc priced well and tasted better than vinegar.  Made a reservation on open table and they treated me very well

2529.review: A traditional French bistro which does an excellent set pre or post theatre dinner. Try and get a seat downstairs if you can. Excellent set menu which represents good value for money and choices change on a regular basis. The staff are attentive and its always pretty full which is always a recommendation. This is the sort of place to take your mum when she comes to visit or a date for a low key dinner. The desserts are a definite highlight especially the banoffee pie.

2530.review: Wonderful, wonderful French food and a wonderful atmosphere. Great place for a leisurely romantic dinner. Highly recommended!

2531.review:
While visiting London, wife and I decided on a nice dinner in the city! Nobu didn't disappoint! Just a tip,  call ahead and make a reservation.  
5 stars for taste of food
5 stars for service 
We took an Uber so not sure about parking

2532.review: The food is great. The noise level is simply intolerable. It was so loud that every guest at very at every table had to shout, so the noise level was off the charts. They sat us under a big dome which is the WORST architectural feature ever for a restaurant. I hated every minute of this experience (excluding the delicious food). Install some baffles, and I'll be back. Until then, I'll avoid this place.

2533.review:
Food: 4.0/5.0
Service: 4.0/5.0
Value: 2.5/5.0
Decor: 4.0/5.0
Overall: 4.0/5.0 
Did the larger omakase option.  Pretty good meal with good service, but the food was honestly not mind blowingly good and the plates had smudges in them.  Not super surprised M took away the *.  Still a nice spot to try but its Mayfair, so.. be ready for that.

2534.review: I visited Nobu on New Year's Day, which could have been a risky move but it paid off as it was amazing. The restaurant was full and service was a bit on the slow side to start but once we got our food it was game on. My friend and I ordered two bento boxes, the classic and the deluxe and shared them between us as well as some California crab rolls as well. It was plenty of food and we couldn't finish it all. The highlight for me was the black cod, which I also had on my last visit to Nobu. We decided to squeeze in dessert and shared the cheesecake, it was amazing and a great way to round off the meal. The presentation was great and it was tasty and refreshing, I would definitely recommend it. I can't wait to go back!

2535.review:
No doubt NOBU is always a nice place, just about anywhere you go. 
This specific location is in the heart of Mayfair, which by default makes the crowed a good and professional one.
Food is very creative and original with a twist for just about every plate. 
Service is very good. 
Downstairs has only a bar (cool one) and a large couch seating lounge. Big stairs takes you to upstairs, where the dining room is.

2536.review:
This Nobu in particular had a really good dessert that I have been craving since I went. It was a chocolate ball with ice cream inside. The thin chocolate shell melts as hot chocolate is poured on top of it.  I was a little sad when I went to another location in Las Vegas to find that their desserts were different.Next time I'm in London I'll definitely come back to this Nobu for dessert!
Also, the appetizer salmon tacos are TO DIE FOR! I have to get them every time I go.

2537.review:
This particular Nobu restaurant seems to have lost quite a bit of its exclusivity and high standards in terms of service. Been to the NY location a few years ago and me and my family were extremely impressed!
Therefore, went today and was really looking forward to it. We were welcomed and everything was good, bathroom didn't look like the NY location at all, just very simple and generic.
We were seated on wooden chairs and I asked whether we could sit on a soft couch twice, on which the reply was; sorry that is not possible while there were plenty of benches available...
Their salmon & tuna sashimi tasted just like the one u can get at YoSushi; like plastic. Maybe this is more of an environmental issue but still then don't dare to charge a Nobu price.
After I refused to pay the optional service charge due to dissapointing fish quality and just rude seating arrangements, I was treated like a criminal - never again at this Nobu location that's for sure!

2538.review:
There's a reason why it's so hard to get a booking at Zuma and yet it's so easy at nobu...
It didn't start well. We were a group of 3, there were a fair few tables empty and yet we were given a tight tiny table for 2. I refused such a bad table and was given a proper sized table.
Service was terrible, slow and quite frankly useless from start to end. 
At an early evening booking, how do you run out of the rib eye steak? Or that there was no Sauvignon blanc by the glass? That's pretty poor.
Anyway, had the tacos, nothing particularly special. A selection of sushi and sashimi, decent taste with the fish as expected, the rice in the sushi was not the best made, fell off too,easily.
The shrimp tempura was fine, but Zuma is another level, much nicer, they serve the whole shrimp in a much better batter. The asparagus tempura was fine, bit greasy, slightly too thick hence they were still a bit hard to break on the end pieces.
I had ordered rice to come with the miso cod which was next. That rice never came so fish by itself, as tasty as the fish is, you need something else with it. Very disappointing.
Finally the last course of tenderloin steak with rice finally. That was cooked rare perfectly and hat a spicy kick to it that worked. 
Dessert was just green tea ice cream and petite fours. Was ok.
At the end they apologized for the slow/lacking service and gave the dessert free of charge but quite frankly 
, it shouldn't have been that bad.
The service needs to improve. Zuma will stay number 1 by miles in my book.

2539.review: Super trendy and super loud. Restaurant has two levels and it's packed, like a night club! Service is plentiful, fast and efficient. Food come out quickly after ordering. We took the liberty of ordering 4 dishes at a time , tapa style to share, as we didn't know how much we were gonna eat. Each dish were delicious! Love the Octopus Carpaccio and the Waygu Beef, as the most memorable dishes. Expect to spend ££££ money here! Yeah it's worth it!

2540.review:
How can you go wrong with Nobu? Great location for dinner and drinks, whether it be with friends, cowormers, or that special someone. Service was impeccable which you could expect for the price you pay. Have been to several other locations like las Vegas and San Diego, CA with lavish decorations and decor. This location seemed a bit lacking with the "wow" factor decor-wise. The food however is what you would expect from a 5 star restaurant. Every dish expertly prepared and plated. All sashimi was as fresh as could be and paired with a bottle of Brunello seemed to make everything taste even better. Wagyu is a must have and a recommended favorite! 5 stars for food, taste, and service. 
Be prepared to spend large when coming to Nobu. Dinner for 2 came out to about $480 pounds with 15% gratuity included.

2541.review:
Erm... Where to start? So much to say... 
So we decided to do the very cliche thing - go to Nobu for Valentines Day! We dont really put much importance on Valentines day, its more an excuse for a fancy dinner! However we did have high expectations in terms of food. I remember many moons ago being repeatedly told by a friend in Rome that Nobu was the best restaurant in London. I remember thinking it would take me quite a few years before being able to afford. Although ive been able to for a couple years now, never got round to it, so this was exciting stuff. 
I want to start by saying the food was amazing. Really absolutely fantastic - ill go into more details below. However, when you pay this much and when you go somewhere with such a reputation you expect more, much more. So lets beginning:
Absolutely no atmosphere, no vibe, nothing. This place has no soul. White walls, no decoration, nothing to excite you. Very bad very loud music, i guess thats what they might call "atmosphere", but you could barely hear yourself think and even less talk. Seats and tables were particularly uncomfortable. Lots of fancy people in fancy clothes but nothing else. Thats gotta be why it lost its star... Great food just isnt enough for michelin starred restaurants. You want an experience with insane food. 
Service was decent considering it was Valentines Day and surely a particularly busy evening. 
The food though... Thats another story, we had the Valentines Day 6 course menu, so didnt get to try the special and ph so famous black cod. However, i was not dissapointed with any ofthe dishes. They looked good and tasted good. Fancy japonese food at its best, combination of exciting flavours & luxury products (from a little caviar to classic lobster) cooked to perfection. Every dish was exceptional. Quick mention for the dessert, which i guess i expected less off. It was stunning, fresh & tasty. 
If we look at the food alone, i highly recommend, i wodeven want to go again and again and again. However you cant ignore the price tag, ita not cheap obviously. For thatprice id want thw food to be outstanding but also the restaurant also the atmophere... So overall, if you are looking for amazing food i would recommend, but if you are looking for an experience out of this world i wouldnt recommend. Honestly im not sure ill be back.  
However, super keen to try Zuma now!

2542.review: Not my favorite nobu . Tried it three times and I have a problem with the waiters ( I hate when it happens I am not eating for free please do your job or go work at a fast food) . The park lane one is better and ohhhhh man I miss nobu Malibu .

2543.review: Was taken here for a meal before Christmas and as usual it was awesome. The food is simply stunning and the service incredibly attentive. The sashimi selection and beef tataki were amazing. I would go more often if I could afford it! The only thing I would say is we were at a table that was a little tucked away from the main area so the atmosphere was a little quiet, however this did not hamper our experience at all!

2544.review: The Nobu restaurants are one of my favorites because of their usual amazing food and service.  However, I was disappointed when I recently visited Nobu Berkeley Street. Though the food tasted wonderful as usual, I was very agitated with the table service. I was sitting at a small table and servers continued to attempt to crowd the table with dishes, which made me feel rushed like they were trying to turn our table quickly. At other Nobu restaurants, dishes are served one by one so the guests can enjoy their dishes. The atmosphere of Nobu Berkeley street is loud: playing club lounge type music making conversation between those at your table difficult. If you are looking for Asian fusion, I would recommend you going across the street to Novikov's Asian restaurant where the food is delicious and service on point.

2545.review: I had a quick dinner at the bar last week and Nobu continues to be a great place for food and drink.  I tried the four horsemen cocktail which was a very interesting whiskey drink.  I had the field greens, salmon sashimi and a tuna roll.  The food was fresh and delicious and the salad is one of the stars of the menu.  I could eat the dressing by itself it is so amazing.

2546.review:
One of London's best Japanese restaurant!
High-end food and  service, makes it a great experience, you can't really go wrong with the order.....what ever you will get would be taste and full of flavours. I Highly recommend to visit this one Michelin star restaurant.

2547.review:
Had my first meal in London at this spot. This place has a nice decor, food was  good and the service was excellent. My GF made reservations in advance, so seating was a no problem when we got here. This restaurant is classier, so if you're trying to save or eat on a budget, don't bother coming. One dish you must order is the Black Cod. It is flavorful and melts in your mouth. It is the one dish that stands in my mind that i want again
yelp.com/biz_photos/nobu…

2548.review:
Came here for lunch for my Sisters Birthday. Greeted at the front of the restaurant very politely and someone took our coats. Didn't have chance to sit at the bar but it looked stunning!
Went up to the Restaurant where the atmosphere was great. Not too quiet so you can laugh and have a good conversation without being loud. 
Ordered cocktails, sake and two Deluxe Bento boxes which were stunning. The Mojito is easily the best I've had. Food portions are generous so you won't be hungry! All the food tasted of very high quality and the service was fantastic. 
Price including a fabulous birthday cake and service was £250. Don't be put off, you do get what you pay for!

2549.review:
Drink: order lychee martini,  it was good as most of thirty cocktail tend to taste sweeter.  But if u r into strong achoholic taste,  Nobu cocktail may be not for u, instead,  u can try their sake.
Food: heard about this restaurant for long time and their famous waiting time for reservations.  Compared to other fusion restaurant I have tried, the food here is better than average,  but also a bit over rated. 
The best dishes are the prawn tempura with their amazing three dipping sauces,  salads are good too with nice dressing, their seafood main courses r very good . 
But I am disappointed by their sushi compared to other similar restaurant.  There are gaps for improvement to perfection. 
Tacos are interesting,  the filling are good, but Tacos can be more crispy to make the dish work better. 
Desserts are better than normal restaurant,  but  less innovative compared to similar restaurant I have tried in London.

2550.review:
We really enjoyed our dinner.  Granted, it was £320 for 3 people, so keep that in mind, for that price, it should have been mind blowing.  Arrived promptly at 9pm, but our table wasn't ready, went to the bar for a drinks.  Half our drinks were good, the other half, not so much, so really hit or miss.  We tried a total of 7 at £16 a pop I believe.
Dinner upstairs, we had the tasting menu, 2 regular tasting menus, and 1 vegetarian with a chicken addition.  Funny thing was that the vegetarian with chicken was only £4 less than the regular tasting menu, and the regular tasting menu had the same chicken dish on it.
Anyways, our server was pleasant, water refilled, never a problem with service.  And atmosphere was great.  Can't complain.  Just be ready to spend when you are here, and it'll be a good time.

2551.review:
This place is spectacular!
The restuarant is based in Mayfair, London. So you would expect the dining experience to be above average, which it was. 
The staff know the menu very well and explained it to me thoroughly. I opted for a la carte rather than the tasting menu.
The food:
The flavours are astonishing and presentation is wonderful.
This place dropped the 1star michelin and to be frank, I dont think it effected the food, as everything I ordered was, indeed, tasty. The service was spot on as staff were attentative, given that the place was very busy.
Overall. Nobu is classy, but pricey. My experience here, was a good one. However, I would definitely recommend this place for a romantic date or a special occasion. Therefore, I can see myself coming back to dine.

2552.review:
The food was great and very well presented, the service was also brilliant with polite and responsive staff. 
The only problem I had was at a fun dressy restaurant it was a shame to see so many people allowed in wearing sweatpants and T-Shirts sitting next to very well dressed couples. A bit off putting but aside from that issue the food and service is great!

2553.review: Always an amazing experience at Nobu but especially this one! Came here on Halloween and the place was creatively decorated. We sat upstairs and had amazing service. The seating was a little odd because it seems that they try to stuff a bunch of tiny tables in one spot. The drinks are always to die for as is the desert. This location is literally in the heart of Mayfair and the crowd is pretty good. I would definitely return, seems like the only issue is that they try to stuff you in like a can of sardines!

2554.review: my favourite restaurant of all time. The shrimp tempura and black cod is just heaven and melts in the mouth. Highly recommend Nobu.

2555.review:
Favorite dishes in order 
King crab taco- mini mini taco but delicous 
Yellowtail with jalapeño- so good
Tuna tataki with ponzu sauce- good but then the flavor for me got tiring 
Black cod den miso- cooked well but a little bit too overpowering on sweetenes. 
Lobster wasabi- most expensive, too rich for my taste, and I think disappointingly the wasabi flavor doesn't come out very well
Drinks are amazing- the one in milk bottle was the best- naru bottle. Tastes like light creamy melted ice cream. 
Service and ambiance are great

2556.review:
I was expecting Nobu to be very fancy and full of celebrities, but it was just a dimly-lighted and not particularly wonderful looking place. I have been to prettier restaurants and there certainly weren't any celebrities there that night. 
I was hoping the food would be out of this world, but it was like other places, there were a few things that were really good and most were just okay. It didn't feel like a special dining experience or a culinary journey. 
The Creamy Spicy Rock Shrimp Tempura started out tasting okay, but the serving was quite huge (it is not cheap so I suppose that's why) and the more of it you eat, the more ill you feel. It is okay only in small amounts, but 2 people trying to eat a mountain of it is just ruining the experience. It is just too creamy and too heavy.
In general, Nobu had decent food, the tataki was good, but nothing to justify the price tag and it certainly wasn't exciting in terms of atmosphere.

2557.review:
This is the best meal I have ever experienced in my whole life. 
Everything from the food, to the wine and dessert. The funny thing is that I always order special sushi, but this time I went for nigiri and it is the best sushi I have ever tried.
The salmon tacos as an appetizer is recommended.
The service, venue and food was all worth the price and you pay for the overall experience. I can not wait to go back.

2558.review:
I've heard the cuisine at Nobu described as 'new style' Japanese, but never truly understood what this meant until now. The food is in a class of it's own - absolutely phenomenal! The seafood and meats are of the highest quality, which alone makes the food stand out. Add to this perfectly balanced flavors and textures and it doesn't get any better. Dining at Nobu was a tasting experience that I'd best describe as 'blow your mind' good, which puts this meal on my 'best things I've eaten' list. 
Everything from food prep to service was also spot on. The quiet confidence of the sushi chefs along the counter expertly and precisely preparing each dish is an impressive sight. And the servers are also on their game, working together to quickly usher each order from the counter to the tables as soon as they are ready. We ordered a number of things to share and each dish arrived at our table with perfect timing. 
My only small nit about the restaurant was the dome shaped ceiling design that resulted in some strange acoustics where we were seated. We could clearly hear the conversation of a table on the other side of the room. We ended up sliding our table over a few inches which seemed to dull the effect a little.
I can't wait for the next occasion when I return to Nobu (perhaps to check out another of their famous locations). Until then, I have the following sweet memories...
Run down of the dishes we ordered:
Japanese Julep Cocktail - Got things started at the bar downstairs with this refreshing twist on a traditional julep made with Yamazaki whisky. 
Crispy Rice with Spicy Tuna - Fun presentation! Crunchy cubes of crispy rice on sticks that you dip in soy and add a scoop of spicy tuna before popping in your mouth. 
Yellowtail Sashimi with Jalapeno - My favorite dish of the night simply because the sashimi was unbelievably fresh, some of the freshest yellowtail I've ever eaten.
Soft Shell Crab Roll - These crispy crabs didn't disappoint. Crunch, crunch, yum. 
Fresh Salmon Sashimi - Like butter. Need I say more?
Shitake Anti Cucho Peruvian Style Skewer - Surprising transformation of a simple mushroom. They nailed the flavors on this one. 
New Style Wagu Sashimi - 2nd favorite dish of the night. Wagu melts in your mouth. Our friends ordered a different preparation of wagu sashimi, which was not as good. Definitely go for the 'new style' wagu!
 'Dragon Eyes': Warm Chocolate and Zabayon Ganache served with Crema Catalana Ice Cream, Pistachio Garapinados and Mixed Berry Coulis - Ah, a happy ending 
Wine: Riesling 'Dachsfilet' D.Q Prinz Von Hessen  2009 Rheingau, Germanya - Great pairing with our meal. So good, we ordered a second bottle.

2559.review:
The venue is beautiful and modern, the hostess was was very welcoming and we were seated quickly. The service was top notch, yielding another delightful Nobu experience.
