It's like someone got a bottle of Hershey's chocolate syrup and went loco. Not what I expect from a French restaurant.
All in all Le Relais provides a unique experience in that it efficiently serves a single menu item at a good price. Just don't be fooled by the long name of the restaurant, this isn't fine dining.

2868.review:
I took my boyfriend here and he declared it his new favorite restaurant. No faffing around and you get a second portion without having to ask? Awesome.
I'm not sure what's in that sauce (besides lots and lots of butter), but it was delicious on my steak, fries and bread. If I had something else to dip in it, I would have. Sure it's not the highest quality of steak, but that's not what you're going for.

2869.review:
Not bad, steak-freedom-fries only, so don't go with other ideas in mind.
Staff a bit cheeky and linguistically challenged.
Good for a quick lunch Bistro style.

2870.review:
This place is very simple and clear. you go there knowing what you will get in terms of food and how much you will pay. 
You don't have to wait for long to check a menu then decide, it is only one dish plus salad
the service and food serving is very quick
portion is just OK, and taste is good. 
Ideal for quick lunch

2871.review:
A very worthy sibling of Relais de Venise in the City (Throgmorton Street), this one has a ri-di-cu-lous queue starting from the moment it opens. Especially on Saturday evenings. 
The secret is, of course, that it's open on Saturday, at least. The City one is shut.
Oh, and when you dine at either of them, keep your receipt, and you'll get 20% off your next lunch in Marylebone or dinner in the City. (there's a time limit of about a month or so)

2872.review:
Not remotely worth £20.
If you advertise yourself as The Place to Go for steak frites, you had better be good. First the good things: the ambiance was noisy and convivial, the salad was excellent and the frites were spot on.
The steak, however, came in a roughly 6 ounce serving, drowned in a pleasant but nondescript green sauce. The meat under the sauce could just as easily have been mushrooms chicken or tofu. 
There were seconds, which brought the total steak serving up to around 9 ounces.
So  £20 seems to me a lot to pay for a salad and frites, however good. Seldom has this happened, but I really felt ripped off.
Go get a steak frites at your local, you will almost certainly get better quality at a better price.

2873.review:
Here's one American who didn't think this place was all that amazing.  
Before I get lambasted, here are the reasons why.  
1) It was marketed to me as a great one-of-a-kind establishment, but it turns out they're a chain with locations all around the world.  
2) Rushed service - since everyone knows what you're basically going to order, wine/bread/salad/steak/frites are essentially dumped out in front of you.
3) I really hate it when waitresses ask you for still or sparkling, you say still, and they pop the cap off an expensive bottle of Evian.  Well, you won't get me again - I say tap water everywhere I go now.
4) Nothing was that amazing.  The salad had this garlic dressing (in all honesty, it's been a while, the flavor might not have been garlic, but it was really strong whatever it was) that completely overpowered the rest of the salad, the steak had only what seemed to be a watered-down curry flavor, and the frites were tiny.  I also didn't love when they gave me more food.  Now don't get me wrong, I do love getting free food, but the way they present it has all the trappings of shoveling gruel on your plate.  The desserts looked amazing, and I ordered this macaroon tower, but they also failed to impress.
5)  Finally, I realize they can do nothing about this, but does every freakin' person in the UK smoke?  Waiting in the 1 hour queue, we were continually blasted by smoke.  
On the other hand, the two people waiting behind us were a lot of fun - a great way to meet new people.  
Anyways, if I ever want to eat here again, (and I don't), I'll just go to one of the US locations...no reason to go to a US chain when I'm overseas, and I won't be making that mistake again.

2874.review:
Such a simple concept, but one of the most enjoyable evenings I've had in a while. They don't take reservations so you start by queuing outside the restaurant, but with the heat lamps and company it can be quite an enjoyable wait. 
Once you're seated you are presented with a fairly bland looking salad of greens, walnuts and mustard dressing accompanied by freshly baked French bread. But as I learned last night, looks can be deceiving. The mustard dressing is complex in flavour and makes the salad truly spectacular. 
You are then given one choice, how would you like your steak cooked... rare, medium or well done. It's positively criminal to order anything other than rare. But don't worry, although rare arrives very red in colour, it does not bleed all over the plate. The steak is covered in a mystery green sauce. I have no idea what's in it, but wow it's delicious. And of course the steak is accompanied by piles of frites. Just when you think you're starting to feel full, a second helping of steak and frites are served. I ate the steak (how can you not?), but had to leave the frites so I would have room for dessert.  
To accompany our meal we had the house red, again it was fantastic, perfectly complementing the meal. Desserts are also delicious. I would recommend the profiteroles that are served with ice-cream instead of cream. 
All this and just £20 a head + wine and dessert. Not a bad deal at all!

2875.review:
Just found this place by accident. What a find!  The menu never changes -- but who cares?  It's a great one!  Delicious salad, steak with yummy sauce and perfectly cooked chips.
Best to go early as a queue develops outside. Don't take reservations and won't seat you until all members of your party are present.
They do have a vegetarian option.

2876.review: This is quite the bizarre yet cute and cosy little place in Marylebone. I think that from over a hundred reviews it's obvious that it serves only one type of food - steak. I asked for my take to be medium rare and washed it down with a glass of red wine. It is as simple as that but the meal is truly worth it the long line that will surely wait for you no matter when you go. That being the main setback, consider the place a lovely dinner option and a real treat if you're a steak-lover like me.

2877.review:
After months of wanting to come here, but knowing about the queues, we were finally out and about in London and ready to eat right about the time they opened, so I figured it would be the perfect time to go (as no queue, right?) Luckily I was right and we got right in.
The menu, easy, steak and fries. And a salad to start. We get our salads and order our wine. The wine comes, the waitress opens it, pours a partial glass (for tasting I assume) and then sets the wine down on the table and walks off? What? Um, shouldn't you wait to make sure the wine is okay before you just leave in on the table and disappear. I mean, if it's not, I suppose we don't have to pour it and drink it, but given the servers come around practically never, that's really not an option. So I take a sip, and joking look over my shoulder, "Oh yes, that's great thanks!" Then the wine turns out to be NOT the wine we ordered. Luckily it was a cheaper wine, so we didn't feel so bad about drinking it, and it was quite tasty, but still, why can't the waitress remember what wine to bring? At this point I comment that perhaps they're going for the authentic French experience: rude waitstaff. Except that every place I've been to in France, they've been more than courteous and not at all rude, so clearly if that's what they're going for, they'd going for the stereotype.
The steaks arrived. They are arranged fairly unattractively on a small plate with a pile of chips on the side. It was decidingly unattractive and unappealing. You'd think a restaurant that does ONE dish would be able to do it in a way that actually makes it appealing to eat. It also seemed a bit small, but for some unknown reason (because it keeps the food hot maybe? I don't really know) they bring a second portion of the food around when you're done.
The food though, yeah it was good. The steak was cooked rare and the sauce was tasty. The chips were also great (and I used some of the mustard on them, tasty). Weirdly though, the steak itself was kind of chewy and not really that great. Again, you'd think a restaurant that ONLY MAKES THIS DISH would make it perfectly. I can cook a better steak at home. Who are the chefs that work here?
We get dessert: The other half orders cheese and I order the raspberry tart. I then get up to use the bathroom, and when I return, there are two strawberry tarts on the table. Um, I ordered raspberry. So I can see why they only do one dish now, because that way the servers don't have to remember what people order because clearly they can't. About five minutes later, the cheese finally comes. They serve my other half up some cheese (and it's a lot of cheese, be prepared if you order the cheese for dessert). I mention that they brought the wrong tarts. The server gave me the ugliest stare for even mentioning that it was wrong, but they said they'd bring me the correct tarts. Then they say they'll bring bread for the cheese. Afterwards, I turn to my other half and say, "Hmm, I wonder which they'll bring first, the tarts or the bread". Turns out I won, as the tarts turned up. I slowly start eating my tarts (which were quite tasty), and no bread shows up. Finally, I turn around and grab some random person walking by and say, "Can we get some bread for the cheese?"
She gets bread, then notices that they didn't bring a knife for the cheese (at least this one noticed), so she ran off to get the bread. The cheese turned out quite nice, but we paid the bill and left, and noticed the queue outside the door as we walked away.
Bottom line: The steaks were alright, nothing special. The desserts were good. It's worth the price, but not the wait, so go if you're planning on going early, but not if you're planning on waiting in the queue. The service is definitely not worth it (and given they only do ONE dish, you'd think they'd be WAY more organized than they actually are). And honestly, I had a better steak at La Petite Maison (and hey they actually take reservations, so you don't have to queue). I'm beginning to think that Londoners actually just really like queuing, regardless of the quality of product they'll be receiving (Monmouth coffee anyone?). Herd mentality, maybe? I don't know, but I'll be dining elsewhere for steak thank you.

2878.review:
Summary: Great steak, good fries, fun experience.
Came on a weekday night around 9 PM - and there was still a 20 min wait to get in.
Salad was good, but not spectacular. I ordered the steak rare, which it was. Fries were good when hot, but didn't hold their crispness throughout the meal, which was unfortunate. Seeing the servers and how they dealt with keeping the steak warm was interesting. I like the idea of keeping the meat warm - I personally think it's a waste to let a juicy, oozing piece of meat turn into a cold steak with congealed fat.
Would come back again with a friend if they waned, but probably not by myself anytime soon due to the inconvenience factor.

2879.review: Excellent.  Really fun place with a great but simple menu - salad, steak, chips and red wine.  Crowded, but worth the wait.  Friendly, authentic staff too.

2880.review:
Salad. Steak. Chips.  That's it.  One set menu for a mere £19 - take it or leave it.  And people are taking it... queuing up for it in fact.
I'm actually a vegetarian, so I've never dined here... but my friends *rave.*  They talk about how amazing the beef is... how the secret signature sauce is mouthwatering... and what a unique and impressive place this is to bring a date (provided they're a carnivore).
This London branch is a replica of the original successful establishment in Paris that's been a popular Parisian brasserie for nearly 50 years.  
I love the simplicity of the concept, the secrecy of the sauce, and the established Parisan history... it all sounds so neat... if you're a beef eater at all, I highly suggest ye get thee here...

2881.review:
Perhaps it's a case of the Yelp curse- a well-rated restaurant with reviews that set your expectations so high, even a great restaurant couldn't possibly live up to the hype- but I wasn't all that impressed. 
If you stumbled on this restaurant and had no idea what it was, you'd probably rate it 2 stars. Why? Let's see. After waiting outside (not terrible I must admit) you're rushed into a jam-packed restaurant, only to be sat at a table so close to the one next to it that it must be pulled all the way out before it's shoved back trapping you in the booth. Then you're met by a "waitress" who appears to be dressed for Halloween who asks only "how do you want it cooked." At this point you had better have figured out you're there for steak, or you're screwed. They then scribble your preference on a paper table cloth and are gone. Someone else comes by less than 30 seconds later, throws a forgettable salad down and disappears. Five minutes later a different waitress returns, tosses down a plate of steak smothered in watery green sauce and overcooked, soggy fries and is gone. Sure you get two servings, but I'd trade quality over quantity any day. 
In short:
Service? Non-existent, and my standards are low. 
Steak? I've had better off a George Foreman grill. 
Green sauce? Seemed a bit watery and rather flavorless given all the hype. This can't be the best London can do. 
Overall? Not terrible, but certainly not five stars. I thought the meal was "good," but certainly not exceptional. 
Full disclosure: I lived in Texas for a few years, so maybe I'm biased, but I've had better steak at even upscale chain restaurants like Ruth's Chris, and better fries at Five Guys. Go for the experience, if you must, but set expectations accordingly.

2882.review: I need to come back here more often.  I always go with rare (equals to about medium cooked steak in NY) and the house wine is quite good.  I don't know what's in that green sauce but it is absolutely brilliant.

2883.review: Some places lose a step when they aren't busy, this place, with the high art that is the timing of fries and thin meat, loses about about 10. The salad is still great, but not overly generous. All this even after I got a free bottle of wine. Hmm?

2884.review: Find something simple and do it well.  Relais takes this formula and does it in spades.  Tender, flavourful entrecôte topped with mouth-watering butter herb sauce, perfectly cooked fries, and fresh green salad.  Being first-timers here, we were pleasantly surprised when our server came by to offer us MORE slices of juicy bovine after we had already finished our first portion of what I thought was a generous helping already.  The idea is they serve half first, then keep the other half on a warmer so that your steak never gets cold.  The atmosphere is bustling; the waitresses pretty and efficient.  Oh and a French family were gorging themselves next to our table so that's always a good sign.  Thumbs up!

2885.review:
So upon arriving at this restaurant, we realized that there was a line. What we didn't realize right away was that line went all the way around the block. My friend and I decided we'd go somewhere else. As we were about to leave, we saw them letting in 10 people so we turned back around and decided we'd stick it out. My point here is that the line goes at a moderate pace. We ended up waiting about 30-35 minutes until we were seated.
The concept is simple, you sit down, you get a salad and bread as a starter, french fries and steak as the main course. You can get a second serving of the steak and fries but that's it. No thirds. 
The fries were delicious. I like the thin french fries instead of the thick chips they sell here in the UK. The steak was delicious and the sauce (bernaise?) was even better. 
I give them 5 stars for the food and 3 stars for their service. So....4 stars altogether.

2886.review: Excellent steak and endless fries! The special sauce is really delicious! It's hard for me to pin point what's in it. I've been here a couple if times and although its not cheap, I walk out very satisfied. It's a really nice place, the service is excellent and the steak is really perfectly cooked and served. The bread, salad and fries given are also very delicious and fresh. They have perfected every item that will be served up. Great place to take someone for something nice or for a small group of friends.

2887.review: Fucking amazing. Worth the wait, the line. Steak frites, meat baby ...yummmm.

2888.review: The meat they served was very well prepared (I got it cooked exactly as I ordered) and definitely of the good quality. Chips were good. However, the restaurant was very crowded and be aware for a long queue if u pop in at night.

2889.review:
Yes, I am a big fan! I love french food and really enjoyed my time here. 
They start by asking how you want the meat, I took a star off cus I got medium and it was a bit too cooked. Next time I will get the rare. Other than that, the frites and wine were pure bliss.
AND, for desert i had profiterol, and they were one of the most amazing desserts ever!! yum yum yum.
It was quiet pricey but well worth it when you have great company.

2890.review: I will be eternally grateful to my friend Aymen for introducing me to this place. The queue is worth it trust me. Just go and tell me otherwise. I thought about asking for ketchup and was quickly shot down. They take their food seriously here and so they should. The green sauce is amazing on its own,with the perfectly cooked steak and with the fries. The waitresses outfits are also cool ;)

2891.review:
Choice is over - rated, particularly when at the end of an over - stimulating day the perfect trifecta is a carnivore's dream served with a  heaping portion of crisp - to - perfection chips and a decent (drinkable) house red wine.  But wait, the surprise is in the second round of the same, so hold off on mediocre bread, and indulge in heaping round two. As you well know by the rest of these reviews, you are choice - less on menu options here, other than the temperature of the meat, and my advice  - just say bloody rare...
I admit that I wasn't entirley oozing with love of the service or the 'all -business, no mingleness' of the server but it/she, like the food was reliable and uncomplicated.  It is yes, as it sounds - the perfect affair, ticks all of your needs, remains consistent and is never complicated.   I would say just who doesn't love a bloody steak and mound of perfect chips, but I imagine Jains, Jivamukti Yoga practitioners and Heather Mills might become irrational at this suggestion. If in fact you are of the few which like your steak trimmed and well-prepared, and your sauces basic, it is a simple must try at least once.
8:30 on a Weds = queue which moves fairly rapidly, but be forewarned, if you want to eat with the rest of the neighbourhood consultants wear gloves.

2892.review:
It does what it says on the box.  Salad, steak, fries.  And an excellent sauce - something like anchovies, pesto, and more butter than even butter contains.
FYI, I like the City restaurant more than the Marylebone restaurant since it's less busy and you never have to wait.

2893.review: Set menu, starter and main. Really simple and really tasty.  Salad, steak and frites... what more could you want? Great for lunch.

2894.review: Set menu. You get a two course meal. First course: streak and frites. Second course: more steak and frites. You can have your steak prepared one of four ways: blue, rare, medium, well done. Don't even bother trying to deviate from one of the four options; medium rare is not an acceptable option and you will be scoffed at for the request. It's on the pricey side but definitely worth it if you're a steak fan. I am not a steak fan and I still enjoyed myself and the food. I'd definitely come back if I were in London again. Just a side note: dress schfancy.

2895.review:
This is probably one of my favourite restaurants in London. It is definitely fair to say that I agree with some of the poor reviews below but this is mainly down to fussy eating/not wholly realising the concept before going.
One thing to understand is that this is NOT a take your time over several bottles of wine place  the service is rushed and there is always a queue outside! The menu is fixed but if you are a fan of steak frites, this is definitely the place for you!
I think £20 for a three course meal is pretty reasonable in London. Admittedly some wine included would be nice but hey, treat yourself.
Perfect place to go if you want to squeeze dinner in before a show on the West End or have the evening sightseeing in London.

2896.review:
Gorgeous place - wait in line (its worth it...) -get seated - quickfire the waitress arrives -eat salad with mustard dressing and walnuts and french fresh bread-  very nice fries and thin beautifully cooked steak in green sauce arrives - have a glass of wine- share your dessert - and go on your way .  They don't rush you ..but you know the deal ..take an hour have a great meal ..rare ?medium? well done? 
A lovely professional French experience, will go here lots and lots. Perfect for Sunday lunchtime or any evening you can't think where to go. Delicious , More professional restaurants please !! Love it !

2897.review:
I'm pretty sure my husband would kick the world's cutest puppy just for a chance to go here every night of the week.  
Me... well, I think it's pretty good, too.  Not kick-a-puppy-worthy, but very good.  Big fan of the house wine (it's well priced at 15 GBP a bottle), the waitresses in their cute little French maid outfits, and the prompt service.  The oft-dreaded no-reservations policy is a drag, but the line always moves quickly.  Do yourself a favour and get there at 18:30, and there won't be a wait at all!   It's really one of the best values in London, the land of over-priced everything.

2898.review: Sooooooo simple, yet sooooo good!!!! Even the salad!

2899.review:
The best meal we had in London! Close seating like a Parisian cafe and efficient service. This place is a well oiled machine!
The food was great! No complaints at all, and I love that you get extra steak and fries :) We had the *delish* profiteroles for dessert even though I could barely fit them in my belly. Attentive, friendly service too. 
I thought it was a bit hard to find (being an outsider) so we took a cab- if you're coming from near Piccadilly it's only £6 and totally worth it!

2900.review:
I've long been a fan of the Relais de L'Entrecôte restaurants in Paris (3) and Geneve (1), but somehow until recently had failed to spot this one more on my own doorstep (all are run by members of the original founder's extended family).
A simple concept - "Steak/Frites Plus" - but well executed.

2901.review:
Let my forewarn you, dear reader, that my entire experience at this restaurant, as at so many restaurants, was spent in a very pleasant mental fog induced by copious amounts of alcohol imbibed over the course of a warmish English summer's day.  Thus this review is more of a hazy recollection of the overall sensory experience of eating at Entrecote rather than a blow by blow account of what was quite a good meal.
I arrived at Entrecote in my customary style:  stumbling out of a cab and most likely leaving the bill for some poor sod in my company to pay.  It's easy to sum up my first impressions:  "gee, that's a long line".  Entrecote doesn't take bookings and so unless you time your visit cleverly you will have to hang around outside for 20 or 30 minutes.  The most observant readers out there may have noticed that I was the slightest bit sozzled and might have inferred -- correctly -- that I was not the sharpest tool in the drawer at this point of the night.
There followed a rather unpleasant minute or two in which I wondered how it would feel to be 20 minutes soberer in 20 minutes time, when my next alcoholic beverage could presumably be procured.  I was fortunately saved from the deep depression this sobering thought (excuse the pun) engendered by a rather wonderful group of lesbians in front of me who most ingeniously went to the pub across the street and came back with a tray of drinks!  This made the wait in the queue pass in a most agreeable fashion.
Second impression:  good atmosphere.  Third impression:  where's the menu?  Entrecote serve...well, entrecote and frites.  And salad.  And wine.  And bread.  I think that's about it.  Your only choice is how you want your meat done.  Being "un snob bourré" I of course ordered mine blue.
Fourth impression:  my plate is empty.  Fifth impression:  my plate magically refills itself!  This is the only restaurant I've ever been in where you get the exact same meal served to you twice.  Most innovative.
The food was pretty good, and from recollection was 20 pounds or so which for London seems OK value.  Of course our bill was far more than that due to the wine I kept ordering.  Following Hemmingway's maxim "Any man who eats dessert is not drinking enough", I didn't have dessert so I can't vouch for that.  I did have another bottle of wine though.

2902.review: Really good steak frittes!  Got there right before the rush at 6:30.

2903.review: Like all the other reviews so, this place is an obsession.  Found it by accident, was wondering why there was a line around the corner.  Great neighborhood location by the way.  We got right in on a weekday night.  Knew up front no menu. You get a green salad with a walnut dressing, steak, fries that's it.  They have wine and beer too.  The steak comes with this magical green sauce that they won't tell you because it's a secret recipe.  We devoured our steak and fries and then all of a sudden you get more steak and fries!  This place was so addicting and am so happy we have one here in NYC because I need to go back!

2904.review:
Good lord, this place is amazing.  I ate here back in November and honestly it's one of the things I remember most from my brief stay in London.  I can understand why this place is a chain, there should be one in every city.  As for the details - expect to wait in line. But it is worth the wait. 
I went on a Friday night and as long as the line was, it kept moving. The food, i.e. the one thing you can eat there, is really something. Steak and fries with the "mystery" sauce, that's it. I say mystery because apparently it's a pretty well guarded secret.  I've found from talking with coworkers that everyone has their opinions as to what's in it.  It's a fun game to play while you eat. After you clean your plate and reflect on the great meal you just had, the waitress appears like an angel with the second helping. 
The house wine was decent and the price for the meal was well below the high quality of the food. We also tried a few of the deserts, which is crazy considering how full we were after the main course. It was worth the loosening of the belt.
Seriously recommended!

2905.review: If your in the Marylebone area, this restaurant is a must !  If u love steak & frites this is place 4 you!  Delicious ! Be prepared 2 wait ! No reservation.

2906.review: Perfect for a quick and tasty lunch, with a set menu starting with a tangy green salad, and then perfectly portioned slices of beef drenched in that yummy secret sauce that you'll crave even after being done with it, and a side of thin but flavorful french fries. There's a list of deserts you can end your meal with but I do especially recommend the crème brulé. The atmosphere can be great or dreadful depending on who you ask, being a loud, almost always crowded place can put off some but also, in the right mood, be quite fun! The lack of the ability to book before coming is unfortunate considering the queue that can go on for half an hour at times (though I didn't see one the last time I went), but you owe it to yourself to at least try that heavenly-sauce-drenched slices steak!

2907.review:
Relais de Venise is a Parisian born phenomenon. Its original Paris bistro opened in 1959 by Paul Gineste de Saurs, who merely sought a place to serve his family's Château de Saurs wines. Opting for an especially short and traditional bistro menu of a simple salad (lettuce, walnuts and potent mustard vinaigrette), steak-frites with a butter-based secret recipe sauce of herbs, spices and condiments along with a few particularly moreish desserts (save room for the profiteroles!), the no nonsense bistro soon won fans for its quality over variety dining experience. It also won a reputation for its strict no reservations policy. Legend tells of married couples meeting on queue and of people securing their next job while waiting for their Frenchy meat and potatoes chow down.
 Based on my experience dining at the Marylebone Lane Relais (but without yet having the pleasure of visiting the flagship in Paris or their other London location in the City), I reckon the food's worth a bit of a wait. The flavoursome frites - made of Bintje potatoes from France that are hand chipped daily on the premises using a bespoke chipper to ensure a signature 7mm thin slice  are out of this world, and the much speculated upon but never revealed secret sauce is a most delectable accompaniment. Here in London, the bistros serve Donald Russell steaks from Aberdeenshire beef (supplier to HM The Queen) for their entrecote steak (which they'll even serve blue).
 An order of salad and main course is priced at £20 per person and yields a more than ample amount of food. Puds cost around £5. A glass of house red is £4.25. Vegetarians are welcome, and as a substitute for the steak a selection of cheeses is offered and a dessert is included for the same price of £20. Service is perfunctory and fast.

2908.review:
When I've had a really bad day, I want to leave work and have a stress-free evening. This involves an easy choice of venue for dinner, reliably good food, maybe an affordable bottle of wine, and a food-induced coma putting me to sleep. For these nights, Relais delivers.
The two locations are convenient for me (The City, and Marylebone), and the food never disappoints. From the walnut salad to the expertly trimmed steak and decadent secret sauce, and just as importantly the very affordable, highly tasty house wine, it is a sure thing that always puts a smile on my face.
No reservations means the usual dilemma: (1) arrive before opening to beat the line, or (2) get in the queue and wait your turn. The line moves fast, and is expectedly shorter in the winter, so that helps, but in general, it moves very quickly. To facilitate this, though, you do give up some service during the meal, but as long as you have the right mindset going into it, that is manageable.
As for the price, at twenty pounds a head, its a little steep. But there's just nothing else like it, and when you see the demand, you can't really blame them.
Four stars for delivering on ease, food, wine, and coma. I'll be here often!

2909.review:
when in Rome...or when in London really, L'Entrecote is the best place in London to get a bloody (quite literally) steak and fries.
I'm a pseudo-vegetarian ie I love meat but try to avoid it
however, I splurged a few summer's ago when I had a not-s0-fully-cooked steak here. The place has this whole old school feel, lyke all Victorian era and shizzle 
Basically you drink wine like it's ribena (its cheap) and pretend you're in France for a dinner.
yeah the sauce is real good. real saucy.

2910.review:
I wanted to go to the Paris-based restaurant, but the lines were always so ridiculous that I never made it out there in the four months I spent there.
Before coming here, I had spent the day eating half the section of Borough and having cake at Selfridge's.  Since my visiting friend INSISTED on going, I took a little digestive nap (if that even exists) and dragged myself over here, still digesting the raclette and oreo cupcake from 3 hours ago. 
Oh my god I'm so glad I came. At first I kept grumbling about spending £20 on a set meal I wasn't even hungry for, but I killed this meal like it was my first in days.  You get the only choice of walnut/endive salad and choose how your meat is to be cooked.  When I received my first plate, I was a bit turned off by how small it was. But waiiiiiit, 2/3 way through I get a second plate. More meat! With some successful flirting by my friends, we get a massive dosage of fries.  The sauce is made JUST as sauce should be made in French steak de boeuf avec frites. I was so happy leaving here. SO disgustingly full, but so happy. 
It does get very busy and you may feel a little rushed at times, but who cares. Go.

2911.review: Don't you hate it when you have a favorite place that warrants 5 stars and some hater decides to say "I don't see what all the fuss is about"....after reading the reviews of this place I decided that I must try it (even if I have to go by myself)....well the boss decides to be a great guy and take us out for dinner and where does he take us????  To his most favorite place in the whole wide world....he was like a little kid on his way to a birthday party, practically drooling on the cab ride over going on and on about how we would love this place and that it was a "surprise"...well imagine my surprise when we got to the entrance with only 4 people in front of us.  Overall I had a fun time and enjoyed the food.

2912.review: The Steak is amazing and the sauce is simply the best I have ever tasted. Went to this place a couple of days ago and I know I will be visiting again.

2913.review:
deliiiiiiiicious, definitely deserves 5 stars for food, price, and venue.
i picked this restaurant for a friend's birthday and was duly praised for my awesome choice. the queue wasn't so bad (thankfully his birthday was on a Monday), maybe 20-30 minutes? then we were seated and offered a very french style salad, you know the mustard/oil/vinaigrette sauce. then asked how we wanted our steak cooked. not only do they have one choice of menu, they also only have rare, medium, and well-done. i asked for medium rare on instinct and was shot down immediately. most of us opted for medium, with one brave frenchman getting the rare. the medium was great- more or less like the medium rare that i like.. success! 
we ordered a bottle of house red on the recommendation of Ana H. that it was really decent wine, and upon approval of two frenchmen, decided it must be true (eyeroll). for dessert, we got the extremely decadent profiteroles. i got smashed for calling them cream puffs you can get at costco but i still think this part is true :P 
good food, good wine, good company, topped with cream puffs.. 5 stars!

2914.review: One of my all-time favorites. Worth the long lines. Love the food. Everytime I visit London, i have to eat here at least once.

2915.review:
I meant to go to the Paris location when I was doing my internship in London but it was closed for the summer =( Luckily my friend, who had recommend the Paris location, knew there was also a London location and took me here on a date.
It's sort of hidden when I think about it since we came from Oxford Circus and had to go through all these different streets.  I remember her telling me that it was near the London Cordon Bleu Culinary School and magically remembered how to get there so that I could take my parents later when they came to visit me.
I must say that even my father an avid steak snob, only succumbing to the likes of House of Prime Rib and places of that stature, was surprised how ridiculously fantastic the steak is here.  
Each piece of steak is cooked to perfection and the 2nd and 3rd course are just steak and more frites!  If I could die and go to heaven I wish that L'Entrecote would be there.  It is worth every pound!

2916.review: This delightful steak only (yes - only steak on the menu) restaurant in Marylebone is pretty unique in London. There's always a queue outside, but when you finally arrive at the front prepare to be greeted by some stroppy French waiter/waitress ushering you to your seat and slapping a delicious salad on the table that you hadn't ordered. Let's just say the service isn't friendly here. Let's also say that they don't do medium rare or medium to well done.Let's also say they couldn't tell my coeliac mum whether or not their delicious green sauce had gluten in it as it's flown in from France and is a secret (what a load of tosh). Inspite of all this, their steak is really delicious. Served with fries (and only fries) you'll get a first helping, followed by a second one about 20 minutes later. You'll greedily chuff it down even if you are full. I've never made it to the dessert menu but I'm sure it's nice. Just don't ask the waiters for anything out of the ordinary or they might slap you.

2917.review:
Great food, and experience.  You can't book so if you go for lunch its best to get there as close to 12.00 as possible otherwise expect a wait.  The deserts are as good as the steak n chips set menu so save room.  My favourite is the prailine legiones.  No, its the profiteroles.  
Beware the service is good but brutal.  Don't dither with your lunch orders and don't expect any leniency if you arrive towards closing time.  They are french after all.  Well worth a visit.

2918.review:
I was surprised by this place because we just kind of hungrily "stumbled" in the restaurant unknowingly. But I was in for an even greater surprise because they served two of my favorite things together- steak and french fries (or what the Brits call chips.) 
This quaint restaurant situated near the ever-popular Marylebone High Street was bustling with people and servers dressed in "french maid" costumes. Very fitting I would say! 
The whole concept of offering only a set menu of  steak frites and a green salad with mustard vinaigrette starter was a bit weird, but I liked the whole idea of not having to fuss over a French menu where I would have trouble pronouncing every other word. I enjoyed every bit of the whole entire dining experience from start to finish. The fries were quite tasty and the steak done either well or medium satisfied my insatiable appetite.

2919.review:
Fantastic spot - addictive food and underrated house wine.  By London standards, its a cheap meal out in an attractive location.  
Only knocks
1.  Agree with the reviewer comment that its billed as a one of a kind and you travel around France and see these all over the place (twice walking around Paris, once in Bordeaux).
2.    Compared to a good Paris bistro, the quality of the meat is pretty marginal.  
That said, great value for money and London needs more places like it.  Plus, I like fast service - it gets more people in the door,  "strikeouts are boring.  Besides that they're fascist.  Throw some ground balls - its more democratic"

2920.review:
What an awesome place on so many levels...
1.  They don't take reservations - Awesome... I'm such a disorganised bloke that I never really think about booking until waaay to late for nice restaurants, so a 10 minute wait outside is a small price to pay for leaving a nice dinner out with my mum to the last minute...
2.  There is no choice of mains - Awesome... My mum is sooo indecisive in restaurants that choosing from a medium sized menu can take most of the evening.  The fact that the choice is restricted to "How do you like your steak?"  severley cut down waiting times!
3.  The place is packed - Awesome... There is a queue of people waiting to get in (I'd estimate between 10 mins to 45 mins whilst I was there), the tables are close together and the constant burble of conversation creates an ongoing ambience of people getting down to the no nonsense, serious business of stuffing themselves silly.  A proper unpretentious eating establishment.
4.  The service - Awesome... Despite the busyness of the place, the servers are attentive and quick without being obtrusive.  At no point did I feel rushed, yet every time I needed something a waitress seemed to have read my mind and was standing there with what I wanted.
5.  The wine - Awesome...  It was both super tasty (from the restaurants own vineyard) and very reasonable.
6.  The food - You've guessed it... Awesome - The dressed walnut salad to start was delicious and the perfect size to whet my appetite without making me feel as though I was going to have to start eating the table.  The perfectly cooked steak with a divine herb butter sauce and heavenly fries were each simple, but together like all great meals far more than the sum of their parts.  NOTE: remember this is French, so if you usually like your steak medium-rare, go medium, if you usually go well done (philistine), then ask for it burned....
7.  The price - Awesome... I see someone has had a bit of a whinge in one of the earlier reviews, but I reckon £20 for a two course dinner, paired with £17 fine wine (Making it around £60 for food and wine for 2) is damn fine value!
I will definitely go again, the only question is whether I have to wait until I have an excuse to take someone or whether I will just pop in on my own the next time I walk past... It may well be the second!
Awesome! Awesome! Awesome!

2921.review:
omg amazing. there are no words to describe. some people say it's a bit pretentious (they literally serve one thing: steak and fries) but its damn good. 
i've been here a few times, both with friends and my boyfriend. its just simply excellent. you sit down, they ask you how you want your steak cooked (rare, medium, well). they bring you a salad and french bread, and then bring your steak and fries in two waves.
a few tips:
1.) you have to get here early. it opens at 6:00pm. if you are there before 6:45pm you are fine, otherwise expect to wait in line.
2.) order the house red wine. it's good and the cheapest on the menu.
3.) for dessert, i recommend the profiteroles and creme brulee and if you want an extra treat the dessert wine is also fab.
4.) they do not take reservations so don't even try.
love love love this place.

2922.review: Novel steak frite joint built Parisian stylee... You have to wait in a queue that evaporates quickly enough.  If you're a group of two you can get in pretty quickly.  Excellent steak (but you can get better, see Goodmans or Hawksmoor), great frite and tasty side salad, feels good value for £20 and normally in and out quickly.  Highly recommended for something a bit different.  Good date place if girl/man/man/girl like meat.

2923.review:
This place is pretty amazing. There's a no booking policy, but they shift people pretty quickly (it's not the place to come for a long drawn-out romantic dinner).
 But OMG the steak. They only serve steak frites, but they do it very well. Best of all? Once you've eaten your yummy dinner, the come back with a second serving. Yep, steak frites twice! I don't know why, but having steak frites twice is going to improve my evening. And I was having a pretty great time as it was.
 They do demi bottles of wine, which is a good thing - if there's two of you, you won't get chance to finish a whole bottle before they're asking for their table back.
 The profiteroles weren't great (ice cream instead of cream) but when you're paying £19 for dinner and you get STEAK TWICE, who cares about the desserts?
 Did I mention you get steak TWICE?

2924.review: Great food. The sauces a the meat are definitely amazing. The single menu and the great house wine make the ordering process probably the fastest in London. The queue and the price a bit higher than the expected move it down to 4 star.

2925.review:
This is a great place to have a casual lunch whilst at the same time feeling like you're doing something special. This is of course courtesy of the set menu and the tastiness of the food. Of course casual is not in the pricing, but then again, neither is steak-frites with a mystery sauce.
On the sauce: it's good, but not mind blowing; it's not that I've had better, I just don't know if that's as good as it gets.
Overall, nice ambiance, courtesy of the waitresses' uniforms and decor, and a nice place to get a special meal with family or a good friend.

2926.review:
If you can't deal with a long line or only one choice on the menu, this isn't your place. 
But if you love a proper steak frites served with a perfect sauce Diane and a yummy salad, a good wine selection, and many sweets to choose from after, look no further. 
The food is impeccable and exactly what it is supposed to be. If you don't like it, then you don't get it.

2927.review: Le Relais De Venise is known for its steak, frites and walnut salad.  It's pretty simple but the special sauce is rich and decadent and you get two portions!  It's a very comforting meal.

2928.review:
I have been going here for 5 years and its fantastic. If you like steak, chips and a fabulous secret sauce then this is perfect. Ok, the service is very French but overall, its a great place to go with friends, family, lovers etc. 
The house red is excellent value and the best tasting wine on the list. Fave pud is the gateaux du relais (chocolate cake 2 ways) 
Lastly, dont forget that if you want more sauce, fries or bread, they will gladly bring it to you as its all included.... if you can manage it!

2929.review:
I had high expectations of this restaurant since it was highly recommended by friends who've been to the original Parisian branch (which was unfortunately under renovation when I visited one Summer).
 Alas, I was rather put off by the service (snooty, impersonal French.. it's like being in Paris all over again!) and small portions.
 If you are a steak lover, you'll find the steak decent, but nothing to rave about. My impression was more of a factory production line, where the waiter asks how you want your steak done - medium rare, medium or well done. They then serve you from a tray of pre-cooked meats, rather than prepare your food individually.
 The result can be disappointing, as the meat is at times luke warm, and the standards can vary.
 I was rather incensed that the waiter served me a very small portion of beef, and gave a much larger portion to the couple beside me. We were all paying the same price! Not only that, when we were given the choice of a 2nd (and final) helping, my portions remained small! Call it bad luck, but I was NOT impressed.
 To be fair, they made very good thin cut fries, and you could have as many servings as you desired. But I was hardly there for the fries, and had not intended to fill myself with a stomachful of oily high-caloried potatoes!
 If you're after good steak, by all means try this venue since it's received a lot of thumbs up from other patrons. But I doubt you'll leave feeling much impressed - it's one of those been there, done that experiences. I won't be going back.

2930.review:
When I first lived abroad in Paris I had a challenging time finding, in two words, good grub.  Yo France, stop drowning everything in mayonnaise and cheese. What the hell?  So after munching on baguettes for a month I found three GO-TO places in Paris: a Lebanese restaurant where no one spoke French or English, a breakfast place called Breakfast In America (#1 and #2) and L'Entrecôte. 
I just had dinner at L'Entrecôte in London and it brought back all the fantastic memories of when I used to dine at the Paris location. 
The menu is simple. Sliced steak and fries...and if you want, a second order of the same. A salad to start and wine. You don't have any real choices, which is great when you just want to eat. 
Expect a line, and it's really cramped quarters, but that's a part of the experience.  They don't rush you but expect to get mad-dogged if you try to hang out for more than an hour.

2931.review:
We got there in time to beat the lunch rush and were immediately seated. The salad was OK, but the steak and fries were spot on. And just when I thought I had finished a petite European lunch, the second round of steak and fries showed up, perfectly cooked to order. 
Paired with a few nice bottles of red wine, it was the perfect Friday break for our group.

2932.review:
I know the original in Paris and was excited to see that it made it across the pond. Lovely atmosphere. Great staff and the food is delicious. Definitely worth the long wait. The famous green mustard sauce tastes slightly different from the original in Paris but still very tasty. The red house wine is a lovely treat. And once you had one of those amazing desserts you know you are hooked forever.
Enjoy!!

2933.review: Words alone cannot express what a joy the food is like at this place. They say when you get older food replaces sex as as the main joy of life...I now know why.....this place should have mirrors on the ceiling....  the food is that good. The price is fair and the house wine is good also.....and oh my god they give you second portions.  I only go occassionally for fear that my love of the dining here may lead to over exursion or public indecency due to over stimulation of my taste buds.

2934.review:
There's no menu at this place, they don't take reservations and only seat you when all of your party are present. But I've got no problems with that, because the food is so yummy. When you sit down, you get a starter salad with walnuts and some bread. Once that's done, you'll be served steak with some amazing sauce and seriously yummy fries. My favourite part is when they come back for a second round and give you more steak and slather it with more sauce. My kind of heaven. Dessert is where you can pick what you want, traditional French desserts like creme brulee, profiteroles or sorbet. I went with the Vacherin, a towering mound of meringue, ice-cream and chocolate sauce. You get lots of jealous looks too.
 Prices are fairly reasonable - all up I paid about £30 (includes 1 glass of wine and dessert). This place makes me a really happy bunny - I couldn't stop grinning like an idiot throughout the meal. Sooo going again.

2935.review:
I came by myself for dinner! That's correct, you read that right.  All by myself while everyone else in line waiting outside for a seat were either in pairs or a group. Pft - yea it's awkward at first but you start to not care after a while. Plus I found this place through yelp..gotta try what my fellow yelpers recommended. It was pretty good..not sure what they hype is though. The salad was GOOD...very interesting wasabi vinegarette..i likey. So not much else to say, set menu for 20 GBP - salad, steak and fries (2 servings), dessert will cost u more than the set 20 GBP, but none of them were more than 5 GBP.  (I had good creme bruelee - perfect for one). The half bottle wine that I bought...not sure it's what everyone says it is..it's ALRIGHT..but not great for 9 GBP. meah.
Hey..my first London review! yes!!

2936.review: Awesome and different. It loses one star for only letting you choose Rare, Medium and Well. No medium-well etc. But the desserts are to die for and it's a very unusual experience. Highly recommended.

2937.review: Wonderful.  Delicious steak frites and a green salad with a mustard vinaigrette are basically your only choice.  Service is business-like but not unfriendly.  It's an appealing setting and great food.  Well worth a visit!

2938.review:
Original (no menu), good (decent meat in London), exotic (French), the deal is clear and most people will like it.
 If I may say:
 - £20 for steak should include a glass of wine. If they dwelve on their French style, the wine is missing.
 - it's not the best steak you can eat. Come on, guys, are you American or what ? It's good, not exceptional.
 - on Friday and Saturday evenings, there is a queue outside. It can take you more than half an hour to get in...
 Don't go there with your girlfriend, but with your mates :-)

2939.review: Having looked at many of the reviews I felt an urge to put fingers to keyboard. I lived in Marylebone for sometime and was always very surprised by the ques of people waiting to eat here. If you are a steak fan and looking for great meat this is not the place to go. The meat is ok, covered in a "secret" special source that I managed to knock up my kitchen 2 days later to as near as perfect. The service is ok, but they are a high volume restaurant, dont expect to stay to long! They do, what they do, very, very well but I still dont understand the endless Ques! What is more surprising is that directly opposite you have what is widely regarded as the best fish and chip restaurant in London, the Gun hidden behind the high street and the Autre Pied 2 mins away, which in my book knock spots of this place.... Oh and its not that im ignoring the providores its just that if you dont want to Que for dinner then I wouldnt go (sunday breakfast used to amazing, then the papers ran an article on it and you now Que for hour to get)... Start at the Prince Regent and have great night in my old manor!

2940.review: This place has the same business model as a restaurant in Geneva - Le Relais de l'Entrecote - and it seems just as popular. We went on Tuesday night this week and as the desciption says all they do is walnut green salad to start and then steak and frites for the main course. Its superb, served in two portions for £19. When we left they were q'ing out of the door.

2941.review: Average. 2 hour wait for small sliced up steak! I'm a South African and I know my meat....I wont be going back for it. Way too expensive.

2942.review: You cannot find better steak than at this restaurant. Although slightly pricey at just under £20 per head for a meal (not including drinks), it is well worth a visit or two or three! The staff are extremely efficient, sometimes friendly, sometimes not, but that doesn't matter when your meal arrives. There is no choice about what you eat. You start with an amazing green salad, followed by steak, chips and sauce, followed by seconds of steak. There is however a choice of puddings, all equally delicious. This has to be one of my favourite restaurants in London.

2943.review: First you get a salad, then the only thing you tell the waiters is how you wish your steak to be cooked you are then presented with half of your steak and when you finish that your waiter brings the rest of it, this is complimented with chips and their authentic steak sauce. A beautiful restaurant right in the heart of marylebone village and a must for steak lovers!

2944.review: A very unique experience and food! No real menu, No reservations and only able to to be seated once all the party is present! You may think it will be a mistake visiting this restaurant, however, I can assure you the opposite is true!! You start with a decent Walnut salad but what really makes the visit more than worth while, is the Steak which is cooked in an amazing sauce, along with the best pom frites you can get anywhere in London! I promise, you will be licking your fingers afterwards!! They also have very tasty dessert list (alebit a small one) to finish of the evening with. This restaurant is simply the most addictive restaurant I have been to in London and there are only 4 of them worldwide, including Paris, New York and Dubai. I have also been to the one in Paris and it is exactly the same in terms of food testiness and set up! Cannot recommend highly enough!

2945.review:
This place is cute and delicious!! I came with my boyfriend and we each had a bowl of ramen as well as the fried chicken to share. It was all yummy.
The service was relatively quick and the ambiance is casual and fun :)
One of my favorite meals while I was traveling!

2946.review: One of the best ramen I've ever had. It beats a lot of the ramen places I've been to in New York. The spicy yozu ramen is SO GOOD. The noodles were the perfect texture and the soup didn't taste like it was full of MSG. When I went the line was crazy long, but there's a reason why people wait that long to get in. Honestly if I had to wait that long on line again I would. Wish I could've gone back at least one more time before leaving London.

2947.review:
Dubbed one of London's top ramen shops, I can only think of one word to describe Kanada-Ya: underwhelming. 
Perhaps it is London's pre-eminent ramen shop with lines flying out the door. Across, you'll find Ippudo, a world-renowned ramen chain that has hours-long waits in its NYC shops, sitting slightly emptier. Has Kanada-Ya taken the throne away from them in London? Maybe.
I waited about 15 minutes on a Tuesday night. It is a very small, quaint corner restaurant that can fit less than 40 people. As I was approaching the from across the street, I could already smell the heavy truffle aroma from their popular Truffle Ramen from the swinging door. The patrons leaving, too, smelled like truffles as they dashed past me. Being a truffle fanatic, I was so pumped for the Truffle Ramen.
I'm no ramen expert but this was far from the best ramen I've ever had. You might like this if you like light broths, but it's not creamy at all. The truffle oil felt more like it was there for the smell, and maybe some flavor. The pork was a bit on the dry side and took me awhile to get through. For the most expensive ramen on the menu (£14), I wish they'd included a Hanjuku egg or something because it felt...plain. Kanada-Ya is definitely overhyped. I can't speak for Ippudo in London, but I try to avoid it altogether like a plague since it's overhyped in NYC. London doesn't seem to have a very competitive ramen scene and that's sorta sad, given how many trendy Japanese restaurants there are in the area, I might as well have just gone to Japan Centre.

2948.review: It's kinda sad if this is the best ramen that London has to offer. I got their classic Tonkotsu X which was very very plain. The noodles were too thin and the broth didn't quite any punch. I should've ordered an egg to go with it, but the side black garlic sauce was a good choice.

2949.review:
I gotta say. I was kind of disappointed with the ramen here. Maybe it's my picky New York tongue, but I expected better out of supposedly London's best ramen restaurant.
I got the Tonkotsu and the char siu don. The Tonkotsu broth was good. It salt level wasn't too high, and it certainly packed a punch! However, the noodles certainly let the meal down. It lacked that special pizzaz that great ramen-yas have. 
The two redeeming factors were the meat and the char siu don. The meat was absolutely amazing; so soft like I was eating clouds. It was juicy and OMG my mouth is now watering just thinking about it. The char siu don (using the same meat) was equally as good. 
As weird as this sounds, if I go back in the future, it would definitely be to just crush three of those char siu dons.

2950.review: Great place to grab ramen on a cold evening, but not a place to go if you're in a rush, because of the wait. Once you're in the door, everything is quick to come and fresh! I had the spicy yuzu ramen and some karaage japanese fried chicken. Big portions, so I couldn't eat it all. Both were awesome! I would definitely come back.

2951.review:
From the reviews, best ramen in London. Not surprised as it was quite good. First off, it is a small place and they don't take reservations. Be prepared to wait in line (no wait list to sign up). There's a bench outside and they provide small cups of tea sometimes while you wait. The turnover is quite fast so don't be too intimated by the amount of people. 
The food comes out ridiculously fast. I got the only in London ramen and my husband got the truffle. The ramen is pretty bare bones in terms of toppings. If you want anything like an egg or garlic oil it's extra. You can pick your noodle toughness which is nice. Portion is just right so you can order something else. The broth is really thick and flavorful. I personally enjoyed the charsu and I normally don't.  
Karaage was pretty good. 4 pounds for three decent sized pieces. Nice crispy outside and good sauce. 
Not the best I've had but it was pretty good. If I was a local I would come back but not often given how expensive it is.

2952.review:
Great ramen option in London. We were swayed by seeing the line when we were initially planning to go to Ippudo across the street. The line moves pretty fast. Be ready with what you want to order before you get inside. You could always grab a beer at the convenience store next store and have it while you wait. 
Ordered the spicy yuzu which actually had a good amount of heat with the soft boiled egg which you must add to any ramen you get. I would even budget more stomach room for more eggs! Also ordered the chasu with garlic oil and egg. Both were amazing with hard noodles. The noodles are thinner than most ramen places. The chicken katsu was the perfect amount of salty and crunchy. Definitely filled my ramen craving. Also pretty large portions so be sure to budget stomach room.

2953.review:
Nothing special, and I still needed to wait in line for 30 minutes.
I hail from San Francisco where we have a very competitive ramen scene. After eating at Kanada-Ya, I have to say that if this is the best that London has to offer, I feel really bad for people who live in London. 
I decided to come to Kanada-Ya at the last moment, so when I got there about 15 minutes after they opened, there was already a line of about 20 people waiting to get inside. I waited about 20-25 minutes and was allowed inside. Because we were given menus while waiting in line, before I even sat down, I placed an order for the tonkatsu X ramen with noodles cooked hard, umeboshi onigiri and the chicken karaage. I figured that if I was only to come once, I was going to order everything I wanted to try. 
The food came out relatively quickly. The chicken karaage came out first and was the highlight of the meal (that's sad considering that the ramen is supposed to be the highlight). It was crispy, very well seasoned, and the dipping mayo was very good. I highly recommend you order this when you are here. It was a reasonable portion for the price. 
The ramen came next. I prefer the thicker ramen noodles, and these were the thin kind. The broth didn't taste very special. They claim that this broth takes a really long time to develop, etc., but it really doesn't taste like 20 hour (or however long) broth. There were no complex flavors that you would come to expect from a broth that took so long to make. The char siu was pretty good, but when I eat ramen, I expect the broth to be the highlight. 
I don't recommend the umeboshi onigiri. I grew up eating umeboshi and they give you the large, cheap, sour kind, not the expensive honey somewhat sweet and sour kind of umeboshi. Sure they were big, but definitely not worth the price. But honestly, what did I expect from a place that specializes in ramen.
If there is a line for this joint, I recommend going to the Ippudo across the street with no line. There is no reason for you to stand outside in the freezing cold (if it's winter) for 20-30 minutes to eat a bowl of subpar ramen. My friend did try this place out before me, and suggested I not go because this was nothing special, but I didn't listen to him because I just love ramen.

2954.review: Great ramen with a decadent and rich tonkatsu broth. Noodles were also al dente and perfect amount of tender chasu pork. Only issue was the lack of air conditioning! Slurping ramen in a 80 degree room was not fun hahhaha

2955.review:
After living in the Netherlands for a few months, I was craving ramen like no other. I tried to get it in Switzerland (major mistake, their ramen was from the instant ramen packages from the supermarket) and then tried it again in the Netherlands for brunch (also mistake, the noodles were soggy and the broth/meat had no flavor). So when we were going to London for a weekend, I decided that ramen would be our first meal. 
Kanada-Ya doesn't take reservations, so we got there around 7:45 and there were about 6 people waiting outside the store. We got seated in about 20 minutes which was much better than I expected. I got the truffle ramen and my boyfriend got the Tonkotsu-X, and we split a chicken karaage. This was too much food for the both of us but I really liked the chicken (not overly fried or oily). My ramen was good, but not amazing. I love truffle but I actually didn't really like it in my ramen, but the Tonkotsu-X was great. The ramen also doesn't come with an egg so make sure to add one if you want! They recommend you get the hard noodles which were perfect to me. 
Overall, great ramen spot in London.

2956.review:
Quite a delicious ramen place. From the reviews, I guess this must be one of the best ramen houses in London. I've been to ramen places around the world from Tokyo to San Francisco, Kanada-Ya is probably somewhere in the middle on my list of great ramen places (still pretty good!)
The seating inside is quite tight but that's pretty typical of ramen places. The broth they use is a classic and you can tell that they brew it for over 10 hours with pork. I absolutely love this style of heavy broth, it gives the ramen a richness that is quite unique compared to other styles of noodles. The chasu is decent but nothing that floored me.
All in all, a decent place for a bowl noodles. It is quite expensive but that's expected in the heart of London. If you need ramen in London, this is probably the place to be (as evidenced by the rave reviews and long lines).

2957.review: Possibly best you can have in London. Qualified evwn for Japanese. However please surely come to Tokyo for much better ones. Forget Ichiran or Ippudo

2958.review:
Very good ramen and queuing is worth it, doesn't take too long anyways. Chose the Tonkatsu with black garlic oil, which had to pay extra for. 
Also had the chicken karaage, which was very crunchy on the outside and chicken was moist. Highly recommend! 
Overall delicious taste. I would've given it five stars but only four stars as had to pay extra for the black garlic oil as well as a portion of the eggs on my bowl of ramen. I would go back, but not quite in a hurry.

2959.review: Amazing ramen but you will end up waiting a long time if you arrive at peak hours. Service is also great and friendly and I would agree with other comments that probably best ramen in London . We are now regulars here and have learned when to be there to avoid the queue

2960.review:
Kanadaya does the best ramen in the UK! Try avoid 1-2pm or 7-8.30pm slot as you will most likely be queuing for their seats. Early lunch like 12.30pm or early dinner at around 6.30pm are always good time slots with no queues. 
Even though their speciality is added truffle oil, I find the truffle oil smell a bit too thick and strong in noodle soup or with the edamame beans. My favourite dish is their Tonkatsu x with 'hard' noodles (yes, you can customise your noodle!). No matter how many times I dine at Kanadaya, I can't get enough of their noodles and I will always be back!

2961.review: The Ramen here is simply amazing, the best I've had. I tried both the spicy options at different times, and they both have a good level of spice, while maintaining great flavor.

2962.review:
Hi. We really liked this little place. There was a fast seating line - true to ramen houses.  We all had different ramens and I loved my chashu ramen. We also got a side dish of chashudon and the rice under the meat was so good.  
I think everyone wants to go back.  So far we've tried a dumpling house, fast Japanese food and Indian in London and surprisingly it was not good.  
So glad we found this little chain

2963.review:
The broth is kinda light, and mixed with noodle's smell. Go there 5 minutes before they open and avoid lining up.
Unfortunately, I can't finish their ramen because the strange taste of the broth.

2964.review: The spicy yuzu ramen was so delicious I had a dream about after eating it. The spicy, savory, tangy flavor was insane. Loved every bite of it! This is my new favorite ramen spot!!

2965.review:
Cute little ramen shop on the corner of St. Giles High Street.
Can only speak to the experience of making a light and early lunch out of a few side dishes, the chicken karaage (small portion for £4) and the truffle edamame (large portion for £4). I went there with the intent of having a nice bowl of ramen, but they were out of char siu, which doesn't make much sense for a ramen house since char siu is such an integral part of the dish in general. Every single one of their bowls contains char siu, and the Yelp photos suggest hearty portions, and to not have it available is like saying they're out of ramen broth or noodles, hence my reasoning for just ordering a few sides at that time.
When time came to pay the bill, I was told by the staff that if I want to ever dine there again, I have to order ramen. Okay, that makes sense, and I came with the intent of having ramen but decided against it since I would be paying full-price for a meal that lacked an integral part of its essence: the thick slices of char siu. So it was a little off-putting to be blatantly told this. 
Next time, I'll probably opt for a different ramen joint in the area with better prepared karaage and one that would have char siu in stock.

2966.review:
Pretty authentic Kyushu Tonkotsu Ramen, definitely one of the best in London. The broth could be heaven for some and too thick for others.
I've been here for many many times so you know how good it is.

2967.review:
Yes!  Finally, I have found it after eating hundreds of ramen.  The best ramen in London!  This establishment has only tables for about 24 people.  I suggest coming here early to ensure you are the first 24 go get in the door first.  If not, you will need to wait for one (or more if in a group) to finish the first round before the line starts moving.  The queue here is definitely long especially on a weekend.  I arrived 20 minutes before it opened and there were already at least 20 people queuing.  When it was time to open, I guesstimated that there were about at least 60 people waiting in line.  You definitely need to come early or you will have to wait in line.  
This place is a no fuss, quick and efficient place with a quick turnaround like a pure ramen bar in Japan.  The menu is also very short so you will already know what you want by the time you sit down.  I suggest when you sit down, order straight away.  They expect you to eat and leave so best not to hang around too long.  I got in alone bang on at 12noon and out 20 minutes after.  That's how quick it was.  
The noodles was cooked to your liking and this is what I love about this place.  I suggest the extra hard noodle so it is 'al dente'.  A lot of other ramen place has the noodles cooked too long and soft which is not what I like.  The broth is simply the best in the city and it leaves you wanting more.  Rich, creamy, smooth and so much flavour.  Do not bother with the sides as they are not worth it.  Just go straight for the ramen.  Make sure you get the mayu and marinated eggs together with your ramen.  Oh the eggs, so good and I usually have 2 of them instead of one.
The ramen here is definitely worth the wait for no doubt.

2968.review: This place specializes. Pork ramen is their thing. The menu is basically 1 pg, and that's for the best, because what they do, they do very well. Come here if you love ramen, pork, and dedication to craft. Don't come here if you give a shit about fancy decorations. Was hot and steamy inside like a bowl of ramen. The front window looks out onto a much fancier, much more expensive Japanese restaurant called Ippudo. Pretty sure this is the way to go though. Compliments to the chef.

2969.review:
Good ramen. Nice portion size and filling. But not sure if it merits the 30 CAD price tag per bowl. Service is friendly enough. 
No reservations. But there are benches outside. 
Repeat: Perhaps.

2970.review: I love the Truffle Ramen.  My second trip to London this year and I had to order this dish again!  I would say they have my favorite broth.  However, I wish they can do soft boiled Instead of hard boiled egg. My son got the spicy Gekikara ramen, which he also thoroughly enjoyed. The chicken karaage was also excellent.

2971.review:
Hands down, best ramen in London. Better than ippudo or shoryu. The broth is the real deal. Love the thin ramen noodles. The different flavors you get with tonkotsu x, yuzu and gekikara broths are so satisfying in their own ways. Tonkotsu x has a nice creamy taste and not too rich like some other places. I was able to finish the broth. Yuzu has that extra kick in it with a slight citrus (note: not lemon or lime.) More of a tart, pepper zesty taste. It cuts through the richness of the tonkotsu broth. Perfect for me. My fiancé had the gekikara and wow. The minced beef adds a deeper taste of beef to the broth. I think I have to get it the next time I go. 
I was able to come here twice on my trip. First time I had tonkotsu x and fiancé had yuzu. Second time I had yuzu and he had gekikara. Next time I'll have gekikara and he will have..??? :) probably spicy miso!  
Also I'm usually not a fan of chicken karaage. Actually I don't like it at all. BUT I tried it and it is better than most other ones I've tried. Not oily and very crunchy. Their onigiri also comes out hot! Very homey in the winter time.

2972.review:
Ok so im a Japanese ramen aficionado. In California I have been to all the top Japanese ramen spots.. This by far is the best i've had. Put it this way Ippudo is right across the street and I did not go there. Why? Because a line started to form before they opened so I walked over and started speaking to the locals and they said by far Kanada-Ya was better and I have to agree. This broth is so rich.. The broth is simmered with pork bones for 18 hours and you can really tell. 
I ordered the classic and just added eggs which were perfectly cooked, you know what im talking about, that dark yellow runny yolk in the center mmmm. It was perfect for the chilly 40 degree weather in London. Im a westerner I use fahrenheit so excuse me lol. I also got a side of spicy miso and added a little to spice it up! 
Kanada-Ya you guys know how to cook up a bowl of delicious, comforting ramen! Definitely recommend!!!

2973.review:
The place is very small and everyone is a bit crumbled inside, plus, there is usually a waiting time. But the food absolutely makes it up. Amazing ramen and fried chicken. 
Service is fine, could be much better. A really good non expensive option for ramen.

2974.review: I had the fried chicken which was just OK - not something I'd order again. The Spicy Yuzu Ramen on the other hand, was INSANE! So freakin' good. Spicy, with citrus and a buttery lobster-like broth. I ordered the egg add-on which was good, but not a game changer. The odd thing about this place is that they don't have takeaway containers that you can carry leftover ramen home in, so skip the appetizer and come hungry so you can eat every last bit of your ramen. This is a must-return spot.

2975.review:
The Good:
  :: it's a local business!
  :: this place is the real deal. you see tons of asians eating here, and we all know that is instant street cred. :D
  :: they have a simple menu and they do those few items really really well
  :: their ramen is LEGIT. the broth is rich, the noodles are cooked to your preference (soft, normal and firm), the fixins in the meal are tasty and fresh...everything tastes DELICIOUS.
  :: the karaage (japanese fried chicken)...so so so so good
  :: service is friendly
  :: clean and bright inside
The Bad:
  :: it can get CROOOOWDED bc everyone loves this place. prepare to wait in line outside, which can suck if it's really really cold out or if it's raining out. but remain steady bc the wait is worth it!!!!
  :: very small...not good for crowds at all. think you or you and another person, that's it.
The Ugly:
  :: none
Would I go back? A thousand times yes!!!! For an authentic ramen house, you won't go wrong here, I promise.
This place is IN.

2976.review:
I love Ramen. Whenever I have the opportunity to try out a new ramen spot, I go for it, so naturally, I couldn't just leave this one out. Having read a lot about this restaurant I wasn't sure what to expect and whether it would be the real deal or just a massively overhyped tourist-trap. Now that I've been there, I do believe the hype.
The first thing that caught my attention was the line in front of the restaurant, which is perfectly normal in Japan but rare to come across in the West. Like in Japan, you are handed the menu in advance so you can already decide on what you want before getting a seat as the line moves rather quickly. We opted for a classic Tonkotsu Ramen, a spicy Yuzu Tonkotsu and some Karaage (fried chicken) as a side.
I wasn't sure what to expect from the Yuzu Tonkotsu but it was absolutely delicious. The acidity added by the Yuzu was just right, combined with a hint of spiciness it nicely balanced out the fatty broth, adding a little freshness to an otherwise hearty and earthy dish. While the soups were stellar, what really stole the show was the Karaage. Coming with Yuzu-flavored mayo and a slightly spicy batter, the fried chicken was modeled after the flavor profile of the spicy Tonkotsu, which worked great. The meat was super juicy, and perfectly cooked through while the spices didn't distract too much from the chicken itself. Probably the best fried chicken I've had in my life.
If you like Ramen and you're in London, I'd highly recommend giving this one a try.

2977.review:
Super tiny ramen shop located right across the street from Ippudo and likely to have a queue during peak lunch and dinner hours. I came here at 1:30-2:00 pm on a weekday by myself and didn't have to wait which was awesome.
It's easy to make a decision on what to order since they don't have a very extensive menu. They make a few things very well. They serve some karage, some other appetizers, and 4-5 types of ramen. I got the Tonkatsu ramen, added some spicy miso paste (which came in a spoon so you could control how much you wanted to add), and added an egg. I like that you can specify the texture of the noodles (hard, medium, or soft).
The broth was rich and flavorful, and the noodles were perfectly al dente, and it was certainly one of the better bowls of ramen that I've had. But having just eaten at Ippudo in NY the week before, I just preferred Ippudo a touch more. I'd wait for this ramen again for ~30 min, but not sure I'd wait 1+ hour for this. Perfect for a grey, cold, blustery day. My total for the ramen, spicy miso paste, and egg was £16 so it's not exactly cheap, and it seemed to be smaller than the Ippudo NY ramen I had.
Come solo or with only one other person, and be prepared to eat communally at the bar or a long table. The space is small and fits only ~30 people, so if you have a party of 4+, go elsewhere!

2978.review: I'd say it feels like a typical Japanese ramen place. Ordered the Tonkotsu X and the noodles tasted okay (pretty thin noodles) and the broth was pretty good.

2979.review: I thought the ramen here was well worth the wait (approx 30 minutes during dinner time)! I had pretty high expectations for this place, as it came highly recommended, and it didn't disappoint. I had the tonkotsu x, and my friend had the spicy yuzu. Both were great. Quite a small space, so don't expect much wiggle room.

2980.review:
We continued our venture of Ramen in central London and we went to their original branch.
